number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												I liked Remember Me. The style of this game is fantastic. Its vision of 70 years in the future was interesting and believable with a lot of fancy new tech around, but not too far technologically advanced. Frequently it was fun to stop and check out the scenery. There are a lot of nice little touches that add a lot of detail and flesh this world. There is some real stunning visuals in this game. Unfortunately, there are a few texture and lighting problems that make some areas just overall look crappy and don't sparkle like most of the rest of the game does. There's far too much time spent in sewers and drab dark places. Also, the world does feel empty as there aren't a lot of NPCs to fill out the levels to make it feel alive. Honestly, the story was mediocre, but not terrible. And the actual format of the game has been done so many times before. Travel to a big room and punch up a bunch of dudes and then continue on until the next fighting room is reached. The fighting wasn't anything special, but I did enjoy it. The combo system made for some interesting fights that reminded me a lot of the Batman series. The story involves a chilling future scenario where memories are bought and sold like commodities and memories can be rewritten at will by jacking into peoples brains. The expression 'Remember Me' does have a significance to the story, but I kept getting the feeling the makers weren't exactly confident in the game they were making and they kept repeating the phrase in the game so people will remember to tell their friends about the fun time they had playing through this game. The game is fairly easy. There were only a couple of difficult boss battles. It took just over 12 hours to complete the game. I liked this new mechanic where someone's memory would play out on screen and as it progresses key details can be changed to alter the memory in sometimes insignificant, sometimes profound ways. It was fun trying different combos to see how the memory changes in sometimes wildly different ways. Tweaking to get things to play out just right. This game does kind of remind me of a kinder, gentler take on the Resident Evil series. Instead of shooting missiles at genetic mutant freaks and driving down zombies, you're punching security guards. And instead of blood and monster puss stained walls, everything is covered in neon. But the RE vibe is definitely there. It's a fun game and I recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												I recommend this game to anyone who likes futuristic urban settings, kick♥♥♥♥♥style gameplay, and a great musical score soundtrack and well-voiced characters.  The story is nothing short of amazing, as you take on the role of female protagonist, Nilin, in the year 2084 Neo-Paris.  She is a memory hunter, and the game starts with her imprisoned in the Bastille fortress, and the mega corporation Memorize, who has basically taken over the entire population's memories, is erasing her memories.  An underground resistance movement, known as the Errorists, breaks her out and their leader, named Edge, helps Nilin escape before they can erase all of her memory.  So, she starts off with a form of amnesia, which is fairly common in a lot of games, but this is one of the better adaptations, imho.Sadly, I can't explain too much of the game, because it would start spoiling the game.  I've seen some denounce the gameplay as repetitive and boring, but I find it fun and exhilarating, trying to figure out on the fly what disciplines I need to put my powers into, because you can reconfigure them even in the middle of a fight to fine tune whether you're regaining willpower, health, or doing extra damage...or a combination of two or three of them.  It can get a little confusing at times, but it's fairly easy to master.  I feel like if I can do it, then most people won't have any trouble.Then there are the Memory Remix segments.  The parts of the game that make it so unique and intriguing.  They are puzzles of an event that you have to watch and then figure out how interact with certain parts of the memory to find out the right combination to "unlock" your goal.  And that's just fun as you rewind and fast forward a segment of time and finally get all the pieces to fall into place.  It reminds me of the Batman Arkham Origins crime scene review mechanic, only Remember Me's take on it is waaaay better.The platforming segments remind me a bit of Prince of Persia (some of the more recent ones), with similarities to how it worked in Tomb Raider (recent ones, including the 2013 reboot too).  Just fun and interesting to play.  I give it an 85/100 and that's saying something for this little known developer (DONTNOD) that might be going out of business due to lackluster sales.  I feel like people really missed the point with this one.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Remember Me never quite meets it's full potential but it's still a robust experience overall.For starters, it's one of the most visually striking games I've ever played. The graphics and art direction are absolutely phenomenal. I'd almost solely recommend this game on the strength of it's visuals, it's that good.The game has a very uneven story though it's bursting with originality. The writing is smart enough to ask to right kind of questions and there are some truly memorable moments in the 9 chapters that comprise the story.Nilin, who already stands out from most video game protagonists by being a woman of colour, is written with the right balance of emotion and toughness. She feels vulnerable but is always capable of getting the job done. In between each chapter Nilin monologues about what's she done and how she feels; there are some genuinely interesting moments of pathos for her that flesh out her personality. She's much more interesting that other characters in these types of games such as Kratos or Dante.Remember Me's biggest fault is the gameplay. This is a character action game with a total of 5 combos. Changing what your combos do is a good idea in theory and having multiple enemy types helps but it doesn't change that you essentially are pushing the same combination of buttons for the entire game. This is going to be a problem for many people, especially if you're looking for a challenging experience. The combat doesn't nearly have as much depth as competing games in the same genre.If you're new to the action genre, or you want an adequate action game with a good story, then I recommend Remember Me. If you want a highly polished action game, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Remember Me is a nice surprise.It has a very unique et personal feel, and a peculiar atmosphere emerges from this title. The city of Neo-Paris has been throuroughly designed, with its architecture mixing past, current, and future elements. The result is a very plausible place, where you can feel both the frivolity of the rich an the despair of the poor.The story itself, although it does not boast any big surprises, is pleasant, and cleverly written to talk about very contempary topics, using sci-fi elements. Heroes forgetting about their past has been used extensively in video games, but it is brought to another level here, and twisted with gameplay elements to make it actually believable and useful.The gameplay is quite standard, with an interesting a-la-Batman combo-style combat system, and Darksiders-like powers to bring just enough fresh ingredients to make it interesting.The memory remixing is a very good idea, but it could have been used a little bit more. As it happens here, the scope is limited, but still enjoyable.If you go straight through the game, it will probably take you 10-15 hours to finish it. There is not much room for replayability unless you want to crack those achievements.All in all, I recommend this game. It may not be the game of the year, but it is enjoyable and quite unique in its own way. The game could probably have used more marketing, too.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												Wow, I was really surprised by this game.It starts off with a fantastic strong open that leads into one of the most beautifully crafted game worlds I've seen. The Combat seems rough at first but over time you realize how genius it is. Combo's become more than just button combinations, they become tactical. With certain combo buttons healing you, other doing extra damage and other granting cool-down on you special moves (S-Pressens) it becomes tactical to decide which combo to do next and how you want to build them. The game gives you many many questions and doesn't answer most of them until near the end. If I had to compare this to another game I'd call it a Character Action Deus Ex basically. The Cyber-Punk architecture layered throughout future Paris is woven together with the ancient structures of the past in a way that is beautiful. The main character is fantastically written as she doesn't just follow orders without thinking about the consequences but in the end she must follow them in order to regain her memories.9.5/10

												For some reason I find this one of the best games I've ever played. Perhaps it's the interesting and well written story. Not only about the game aspects, but mostly about the story and its implications.Anyway, it is despite being quite a linear game one of the most enjoyable solo gaming experiences I've had in many many years. I will make sure to keep my eyes open for anything else made by the same artists.

Posted: November 25, 2015
												Remember Me is a hard game to recommend outright. As a whole it is a largely linear campaign with plaforming sections. You basically go from platforming to combat room to more platforming. The game does try to be unique with the create - a - combo mechanic that was fun to mess with even though you'll be pressing the same two buttons most of the time.  The memory scrubbing that you do are like modified cut scenes that you play with going back and forth to find the best way to achieve the objective. Now, I am a huge cyberpunk fan. And the setting is the main reason why I bought this game in the first place.  The gameplay and story kept me going to the end. And, that is pretty much all I ask of a game like this. In the end, I am happy I played it.  I recommend it if you can find it on sale.  Since this such a short game, this is a game that is worth your time.

content:
Posted: March 8
												A short but sweet cyberpunk action game that will likely leave you "remember"ing the storytelling far more than the gameplay itself.In 2080-something, the world of Neo Paris is addicted to memories. All citizens have a device attached to their spinal cord that allows them to share and download memories from other people and other lives. Cool, right? Except for when the devices malfunction and spur mutations in the host, leading to "leapers", or half the enemies you fight in the game.You're Nilin, a 20-something kung-fu pro that has had her memories stolen and has been imprisoned. You spend the game running, jumping, and kicking your way to reclaim what was lost. The platforming is remniscent of the Tomb Raider games, except easy mode. There are AR-style icons to indicate where you need to jump next, and the magnetism is enough so that you'll very, very rarely ever miss a jump. If manual platforming isn't your strong suit, then no worries here, as it doesn't really add much to the game except a nice sense of verticality.The combat is much stronger, but still not the game's strongest point. It's solid and snappy, and dodging is very fluid and easy to do, so no complaints there. Unfortunately, while you can customize your combos in the sense that when you press 'X' here, you regen health or do more damage, your combos themselves are static, and there's only four - a 3 hit, 5 hit, 6 hit, and 8 hit respectively that unlock through game progression, and the button patterns are always the same. While this allows you to learn the combos quickly, it leaves very little in the way of innovation. More fun are the special abilities that you learn which allow you to take out certain enemy types with a consumption of Remember Me's equivalent of a Super bar. Without giving away too much, you essentially "hack" the world and enemies around you for extra-powerful attacks.All of that takes a back seat to the storytelling though, which is where the game shines. The writing is never longwinded, the characters are (usually) interesting and have their own strong motivations and desires, and you'll even occasionally discover some fairly poignant quotes and very well-written lines of dialogue. The plot culminates quite solidly at the end, despite some shortcutting in the final chapter that leaves a little bit more extrapolation of the final boss and his motivations to be desired, but all in all it's a satisfying and extremely pretty adventure that you might even want to revisit after the game's moderately short 8 hours with the new game plus feature.Pros:+Very good writing and interesting setting+Solid heroine+References to Gibson, Ghost in the Shell and other well-known cyberpunk franchises+Excellent graphics+Smooth combat+Collectibles and worth replaying for completionist statusCons:-Platforming is not challenging at all-Few puzzles with easy solutions-A bit short

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												I finally decided to give this a go. I must say it is much better than I had anticipated. It combines a number of scenarios and games as far as setting and gameplay are concerned. The envrinoments remind of Deus Ex, the combat and upgrade system is very close to the Batman Arkham series (memory restructuring equals 'Detective Mode' etc.), it also has something from Dead Space as far as the camera angles and mechanics are concerned, and of course there's a side of Assassin's Creed with perhaps a pinch of Tomb Raider.This does make for a great combo. The game itself is quite linear (meaning not open world), but the pace and storytelling are very compelling, and you don't mind the linearity of it at all. The various locations are introduced with a nice camera swoop, and the use of light and shadow does add drama.If you are expecting a 'but', you're right. While the in-game combat very much reminds of the Batman Arkham games, the controls are not as fluid. The same goes for the usual walking around. The best way to describe the controls would be to say, 'a little clunky at times'. This is not a game breaker by any means, but I wish they would have chosen better camera angles, and that the movements felt more fluent, especially since the protagonist, Nilin, appears quite athletic and believably capable of all the moves without the 'superhero flair'. Another gripe I have are the boss fights, but that is the same for the Batman games. I find them unnecessarily complicated, and the overwhelming count of 'foot soliders' is just ridiculous at times. You can't click as fast as you ought to, but, with some practice and patience, you eventually get past all of them.I have not yet completed the game at the time of writing this review, but I can already recommend it to anyone who liked the games I mentioned above, or simply enjoys a good game in a Sci-Fi setting that's neither improbable, impossible, nor too far in the future.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2013
												A very positive experience. Remember Me is a French sci-fi action adventure set in "Neo-Paris." Europe has descended into a corporate future where human memories are a commodity. There is no fascist regime but the people have become memory consumers out of choice. In one street scene there is a man buying a memory of a first kiss and many others want painful memories removed from their minds altogether. The lead, Nilin, is a strong character who overcomes doubts and anxieties to accomplish something larger than herself. She is capable but not a demigod and is not sexualized in any way. She has an unique skill of re-writing people's memories so their personalities and goals change. The process is, of course, incredibly immoral and Nilin is painfully aware of this.While the setting and other characters besides Nilin are what makes Remember Me so special, the gameplay is good too. There is practically no exploration involved but the platforming looks and plays great. Close combat follows the general Arkham Asylum - pattern as practically all post - Arkham games tend to do, but it is entertaining with some original twists. Graphics and sounds are stylish, with a cool temperature.I was surprised and disappointed at the lukewarm reception Remember Me recieved, but I enjoyed the 10-hour adventure very much, and would definitely try any DLCs or sequels.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I picked up this game because it was developed by the same studio who made Life is Strange, a game that I enjoyed immensely. Although nowhere near as good as Life is Strange, Remember Me is still worth playing if you can get past its shortcomings.The characters and the story are well developed and engrossing; they are the main driving force that will keep you playing this game until the end. Graphically the game holds up very well, and the art direction really makes the game world come alive. It is a shame that there isn't more freedom to explore the streets and the world of Neo-Paris, as the fictional world created here is really interesting.Gameplay, however, is where this game completely falls apart. First of all, the game is extremely linear. Although, I don't find that to be a problem by itself, but it renders the parkour elements in this game redundant as there is no chance for exploration or discovery at all. The combat is also extremely repetitive and frustrating in the worst ways possible. It is as if they looked at the combat from the Arkham games and decided: hey let's implement a crappy version of this. The enemies take way too many hits to go down, and you cannot beat multiple opponents with your combos, only one enemy at a time. In the end, however, the story and the world created in this game is enough to warrant a playthrough.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Ok, I'm gonna review this after only a few hours play, but short of any game breaking crashes or up coming mind-blowing gameplay, i think i can speak to this game.I had skipped it at launch, because of all the bad reviews at release. Its now been several months, so I assume that any problems have been patched. So far I have not encountered any technical issues. Will update if I do.What do I think? I think its an awesome game and a worthy successor to Deus Ex. Judging by the start only, its almost better than that lackluster sequel we had few years back. The story has a very strong French distopian feel to it, that only the first Deus Ex pulled off.  The maps are gorgeous to look at, but limited and linear..."game-like" not open world, but still very  effective.  More than good enough. If Splinter Cell can do it, why not this game?So why was everyone hating on it?  Probably has something to do with the fighting system. to be perfectly clear, I hate all button mashing fighting games.  Memorizing X Y X X, block, jump x is not my idea of fun. you may disagree.  The recent batman games looked amazing, but I hated that fight system. didn't stop everyone from praising those games! So why the hate here?  I don't know, feels the same to me. I'm probably missing some mind-blowing nuance that a fan boy reading this may point out to me.  I just set the game on easiest difficulty and enjoyed the story.And that is my final point, its a slick and beautiful to look at story experience. all the negative reviews have tanked the price, so especially on sale you can probably get it for song.   I would recommend it to any fan of futuristic sci-fi.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												So far I am really liking this game. The fighting is similar to the Batman Arkham games, only the combos are easier to remember and you can customize them to make them heal you or increase their damage, and dodging is easy and a lifesaver! The environment is really well done, the graphics are pretty, and the story is interesting. Although there are people around and stores and such, so far I cant really interact with them. The memory remapping is neat too once I figured out the controls(move the mouse in circles, dont just twist it :P ). Death, so far isnt frustrating, seems to be many checkpoints and no negatives to it. The only thing some people might not like is that it is not open world. There is a set path to follow, so dont expect freedom to explore like in Batman. There have also been instances where I want to spare someone, but it doesnt seem like I have a choice. I dont mind it though because the story is moving it forward and the sci fi feel is coming through. I would recommend people to try it, though if you are not sure, wait for it to be on sale. I cant wait to see what happens next! =)

Posted: October 21, 2013
												Trust the reviews on this one.  The gameplay is divided into two distinct sections: combat and traversal.  The traversal mostly involves jumping between ledges indicated by orange arrows, eliminating any sense of exploration or discovery.  The combat is repetitive, alternating between boring and frustrating.  The story is average at best.Credit must be given to the art department though.  Neo-Paris is a beautiful city, and one I enjoyed seeing, albiet in a completely linear way.  There are no open areas to explore sadly, but what you do see is beautiful and full of interesting details.  I wouldn't advise against picking it up on sale to check it out, but I wouldn't pay more than $10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												"Augmented reality at its best"I would like to say this for this game. but unfortunately Remembe Me has its flaws. It  is certainly a bold game. It has very ambitious elements in all directions, from story to the gameplay. But they are not very well implemented, putting the game in an position between average and good in a relative (to the player) matter.Gameplay can be defined in one word: simple. Button-mashing and easy platforming, full linear. Game gets most of its critism from this simple gameplay. However...Setting is unique. This is somekind of a cyberpunk game. But the focus is on the augmented reality via memory alteration and the glimpse of the world that we see is a rough dystopia rather than the embraced thrill of a cyberpunk.The game reminded me Omikron and the anime serie Ergo Proxy in some ways (through some atmospheric elements). It is a shame that we see very little of Neo Paris. What a wonderful game this should be if it were an open world sci-fi.I know there are people who would neglect the simple gameplay for a unique sci-fi/cyberpunk setting. If you are so, then I recommend Remember Me. Grab it on a sale and you won't regret. Game deserves a solid 7/10, and thanks to its interesting setting, you will "remember" the game.Note: You should play this game with a gamepad controller.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
 Close to perfect Remember Me is an awesome game. Set in "Neo Paris", a beautifully crafted Paris of the future, it tells the story of a woman - Nilin -  fighting a huge corporation that is controlling everything, including memories. The story is paced well, tense and interesting. Gameplay works well, consisting of a great combat system (basically the one from the Batman Arkham series with the added ability of creating own combos), climbing sequences, short puzzles and well designed, Inception-ish "memory manipulations", where you have to twist perceived reality to reach your goals.The only downside is that while playing you start to wish you could explore Neo Paris, as its great art style and graphics know how to impress, but the linearity of the game does not allow it.-> 9/10Note: I played the game on a different account, so the shown playtime - obviously - is incorrect.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												A fun game, a really neat concept, but it seemed to be lacking in content. Let me explain:Throughout the game you come across various shops and civilian npc's, however, non of it is interactable. Which is fairly disappointing since the game came out in 2013, 2 years after Dues Ex Human Revolution, (which is way more interactive). It seemed as though the devs were trying to win a race or they belived the system capabilities would not be enough to handle an interactive enviroment. A couple more years, (2016), and they would not be able to sell the game without this.Another feature of this game is that, bear with me here, it is French made. Let me expand on this: if you are looking for a violent platformer, might I suggest assassin's creed, but this is not the game for you. It has a VERY intricate story, arguably 2 "energy" guns (its an upgrade on 1 gun), and a WHOLE LOT of martial arts moves. It also has this wierd feel to it, its kind of hard to explain, that you need to damn near die to beat the game (there is no coming out powerfully on top, it will always be a pyrrhic victory), and I played the game on the easiest difficulty.Lastly, it is arguable that there are too few "bosses", and too many "swarms" where in place of a boss, they just pack the room full of enemies to Chun Lee your way through.Some other minor problems I have had might be because I'm using a mouse and keyboard, but the controls at times, such as dodging and selecting buttons. Also, there are a few minor glitches, (I only counted 2 and they weren't gameplay changing). You also can't skip cutscenes.I know I did a lot of complaining here, but overall, the game has a great story, a huge concept (the devs need to make a second one), and an overall good game.$20? No       $10? Maybe        $9 or less? YesP.S. I just noticed that there is some sort of dlc for this game, I didn't have it, so I don't know if it makes the game better or not.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												I'll be the first to admit that this is an odd action adventure game. The combat relies on the execution of well-timed combos. Combos which you can and must define yourself. An interesting idea that breaks with usual genre conventions, but ends up feeling not really satisfying. Maybe because this mechanic forces you to perform accurately timed button presses all the time, which keeps the player from truly enjoying some sort of flow of combat.Another quite interesting aspect is the ability to remix memories. Basically you have to manipulate an ingame cutscene, which you can forward and rewind, to ultimately change the outcome to the one you desire. From a purely gameplay perspective this is indeed questionable, but it's an interesting variation of storytelling and does build atmosphere. You don't get to do this often during the game though.The rest of the gameplay mainly consists of horribly stilted platforming, trivial puzzles and walking around a scrictly linear path. Doesn't sound too exciting overall. The reason why I still immensly enjoyed Remember Me lies in the unusual science fiction scenario that manages to build an immersive atmosphere. Certainly not for everyone!

Posted: October 21, 2013
												Trust the reviews on this one.  The gameplay is divided into two distinct sections: combat and traversal.  The traversal mostly involves jumping between ledges indicated by orange arrows, eliminating any sense of exploration or discovery.  The combat is repetitive, alternating between boring and frustrating.  The story is average at best.Credit must be given to the art department though.  Neo-Paris is a beautiful city, and one I enjoyed seeing, albiet in a completely linear way.  There are no open areas to explore sadly, but what you do see is beautiful and full of interesting details.  I wouldn't advise against picking it up on sale to check it out, but I wouldn't pay more than $10.

												With a very well developed story, combined with breathtaking visuals and great use of music, I would highly recommend this game despite it being marred by various issues.The game constantly has mouse sensitivity issues and you can find your camera flying to god knows where, especially during combat and when things get hectic. Remixing memories was also very hard because the game sometimes could not detect me rotating my mouse. I switched to a controller and everything became a lot easier to control. It seems like the game was not optimised for the keyboard and mouse.Combat was the most horrible experience for me. You are told that you can continue your combo if you dodge over an enemy, but half the time, your character chooses to dodge out of the way, making you miss your combo and precious PMP points.Overall, the game was presented and developed very well, and I applaud DONTNOD for their hard work.Story 8/10Art 9/10Music 8/10Combat 6/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												Ca. 14 hours until the end for me.I saw no bugs or had any crashes I remember. The game has good graphics and the controls are good.You are playing a woman protagonist in levels which are more or less corridor levels. There is always only one good way to go. Sometimes you find clues about secrets, then you should look at that clue, find the secret and go back to your old route.The fights are melee fights, where you always use combos. You can just try to ignore the combos but because some combos start with repeated use of the same attack you can even customize this.A combo consists of a different number of either fist or foot attacks. And each but the first attack has to be of a kind. These "kinds" are things like "concentrate on damage", "heal yourself", "gather points for your other special attacks" or just enlarge the bonus of the last attack.The farther behind in a combo the attack is, the larger is the bonus you get.Imagine something like normal+heal+enlarged heal+even more enlarged heal against a boss.You can change these combos all the time, even in the middle of fight when you realize all your combos suck against the current enemy.The fights are fun. There is no but to this.The moving is a bit like in Assasin's Creed, but not as good. You can do cool moves and climb and jumb and run but only when the game allows it for a certain spot at this time.So one moment you fight for your live or just want to jump on a knee high platform... not possible. The fight is over, you can climb there without problems. Two spots look the same, but the one is the "right" way, so to one you can do an incredible cool jump, to the other not, you die. That can be very frustrating.If you are used to the open worlds from Assassin's Creed then you should start the game with a VERY open mind, because it is really NOT like Assassin's Creed, even if the fighting and the moving are a bit like it.The story is ok or even good, not sure, it was good enough to keep me playing.If you get the game for non-full price, yes, try it, it might be your new favourite.But it might be you get bored after 10 minutes.This game was not half as good as I expected because of the vidoes and reviews.But still, it was fun. I'd give it a 6.5 / 10. Meaning, it is better than average, but not one of the "you must have played it" games.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
Forget you soon.The GoodDamn. Before I played Remember Me, I've been told quite frequently that it was a mixed bag, but nothing could have prepared me for this. After a short introduction, you find yourself in the incredibly stylised Neo-Paris, which is without a doubt its best asset. The visual design is one of the most beautiful locations I have ever experienced. Everything is perfect. The city itself, the buildings, the denseness of everything, the neon lights, the struggling people, the robots.  The atmosphere is amazing as well, both the environmental sound design and the soundtrack. Everything screams cyberpunk. But how about the inside, under the hood?The BadYou see, while the outside is one of the most gorgeous settings, the actual game is riddled with flaws. It's one of the very few games I wish had a film or animated film set in the same universe, because it doesn't play well. The incredible design of Neo-Paris yearns to be explored, to be discovered and appreciated. Instead, you're walking an awfully straight linear path, and most of the times basically a hallway with nice decorations. It's such a shame, and I wonder how greatly this game would have benefited from an open-ended design with a focus on exploration. Besides the linear level design, the combat system is also rather unappealing. Making your own combos sound pretty good on paper, but the fighting itself just isn't a lot of fun. Pardon the metaphor, but it feels like the mentally challenged niece of the Batman Arkham series. And to make matters worse, you'll be fighting pretty frequently. The enemy placements are illogical, there's no thought behind it, except for artificially increasing the game length.Besides those two big flaws, I've also experienced some smaller flaws. The story is pretty uninteresting, and the characters are even less so. Which is a shame, because th. Also, the collectibles are pretty useless, since you can easily and very quickly regain your Health and Pressens through the Regen and Cooldown moves in your combos. In short:+ Incredible visual design, one of the most highly stylised settings I have ever seen.+ Soundtrack is good.+ HUD disappears outside of combat, which makes for a very clean screen.+ Mixing memories can be pretty fun.- Extremely linear, a huge waste of Neo-Paris.- Uninteresting story with uninteresting characters.- Mediocre combat system.- Fighting the same enemies with little diversity is tiring.- Final boss is stupid and misplaced.- Collectibles are basically useless.

												SCORE: 7/10This was a fun game overall, with a very interesting story, and mostly enjoyable gameplay. It is part Batman combat, part Assassin's Creed parkour, part Life Is Strange rewind mechanic, and part sci-fi dystopian novel. The parts mostly come together and you can definitely see how Dontnod took the rewind mechanic and improved upon it in Life Is Strange. Still a fun game and solid dystopian story. Definitely worthy of your purchase and play on a sale.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Set in a not-too-distant dystopian future, Remember Me tells a compelling story, one that draws here and there on classic cyberpunk, particularly Ghost in the Shell.  The combat mechanic is generally fluid, though I was often confused about what I needed to do in order to defeat a particular boss and the camera, which whipped around crazily, frequently made me dizzy during fights that took place in narrow corridors.  The levels are also very linear, and the collectibles are a bit lackluster.  If the developers can fix the camera, open up the levels, and add some depth to the combat system, they could turn this game into a *memorable* franchise.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Remember Me has excellent visuals and a cool post-cyberpunk (is that a thing?) storyline, but its combat mechanics are fairly shallow (and indeed most of the depth in them is unnecessary for completing the game), and its free climbing is pretty much always limited to a single path that's spelled out for you step by step.The memory remix scenes are conceptually some of the coolest stuff to come out of games in a long time -- you can dive into peoples' memories and change little details to radically alter how those memories play out and affect them -- but in execution, it's pretty much just trial and error.Pick it up on sale and for the price of a movie ticket you'll get a story and effects worthy of a fun summer sci-fi flick. Just don't expect much of the mechanics.

												Very deep game.And it is a scary game if you think about it.Really scary.Scarier than most "horror" games, actually. It doesn't shock you outright, and it does not try to make you jump back from the screen, no. It makes you think. And when you realise, you freak out. This is called "fridge horror" by some...Pretty believalbe as well.Except that I personally find it unplausible for Nilin to end where you take control of her in the prologue, given who she is and what her... certain connections you learn near the end of the game are.Such people just don't end being dumped into vivisectionist prison as test subjects with zero chance of survival.Everything else... is realistic.And that is what makes this game so scary.It is not a "dystopian fantasy future" you are going to laugh about, thinking "well, that won't happen ever". No. Here, you'll think "oh my god, if such a technology is ever invented, it WILL turn out like this eventually, 100%."

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I picked this game up in a sale a while ago, because what I had previously seen and read of it sounded interesting, but initial reviews weren't really encouraging. It took me a long time to actually play this game - and boy, am I glad I finally did!On many accounts the reviews were probably correct, especially in regards to the combat system. The fighting is ARPG style, similar to other brawlers like Batman or the recent Shadow of Mordor, and mainly takes place in smallish arenas along the path. Fights can be quite challenging, because of the many emenies attacking from all sides, requiring you to dodge and evade, and stringing together an 8-hit combo can be rather tricky. The bit that falls flat is the "combat lab", which allows you to create your own combos out of different moves. All moves have the exact same timing, albeit different animations. The only difference is in their effect. Some moves heal, others reduce cooldown on your super moves or give you bonuses for your next combo. Overall this seems more like a gimmick than a fully fledged system. Because as mentioned above, stringing together longer combos is already quite tricky.However, it is not so much the combat that kept me playing, but the intricately realized, dystopian world in which Nilin, the main protagonist, tries to make sense of her purpose and fights to regain her memory and identity. The game is beautiful to look at. Vibrantly coloured, high fidelity environments give Neo-Paris a believable not-so-distant-future vibe. Between fights, Nilin will have to frequently traverse rooftops, building facades and other obstacle courses, Tomb Raider style. This breaks up the pace really nicely, and makes room to get the story moving while exploring.The story is another strong point of this game. The tale as such is nothing groundbreaking, but it explores some interesting themes through unconventional means, like the memory manipulation scenes. These sequences let you re-arrange an NPCs memory of past events, to effect a different outcome in Nilin's timeline. All of these are tied neatly into the overall narrative, and provide some very welcome depth to Nilins character development, which overall is very strong - for a game...I am very happy that I didn't just let this one pass me by! If you like Tomb Raider mixed with a bit of Deus Ex, you should have a look at this title.My scores:Graphics: 9/10Story: 9/10Combat: 7/10Overall score: 8.5/10Cheers.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8
												7/10    Remember Me caught my attention via Youtube, like many of us I hadn't heard any of it before that point. I bought this game much later though, last year to be exact as I saw it on Humble.  Remember Me is a game where you play as a memory hunter, Nilin, in futuristic Paris where everyone's memories can be changed or stolen. What first was supposed to be an utopia without misery, has turned into a nightmaris situation, just like what happens with any other too-good-to-be-true worlds.   Your job in this game however, is to gain your own memories back and stop whatever is destroying people's minds and memories.    This game is console ported game, and sadly it shows time to time with controls. Otherwise the port has seemed to work out alright. However, I recommend playing this with a controller if possible.  Pros:     - Beautiful aesthetics, background arts ect.   - Interesting, unique concept   - Satisfying combat - Soundtrack on point - Characters are memorable along with the story-line Cons:    - Not so well done console port, clunky controls on keyboard.  - Main charcter is main focus, you do not interract with other characters more than once or twice. - Ending will most likely leave you unsatisfied -  Quicktime events tend to start without any kind of warning, sometimes it's even unclear what you're supposed to press and where.- Despite the story-line being good, it was fairly short and left some questions unanswered or added more confusion to the cart.  This game could've been so much more than it is, but the flaws of it weight it down quite bit. It would've been awesome if the game had had more free, parkour like running instead of locking you to specific areas to go up and down from.   I recommend grabbing this game from sales. It is quite underrated game, but woth playing at least once.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
Product received for free
												Remember Me is an excellent action adventure with an intriguing story. The year is 2084, the human memories have become a commodity, as they can be traded or even removed from a person. This happens via the 'Sensen', a technology that not only allows access to the human memory to outside sources but also augments your reality, allowing you to see information literally floating in the air, e.g.: "Store is closed due to..." and can be used to communicate, like a cell phone. You play Nilin, a memory hunter that ironically has lost all her memories. You were the best in what you did, as you could not only steal memories, but you could remix them. While remix is perhaps not the proper word, in-game you'll find out that it means that you can alter memories by partially changing them. The gameplay is divided among 3 major categories, fighting, exploration and puzzle solving. -Fighting: Nilin will have to fight if she wants to survive and she re-learns that  early in the game. To fight you use certain combo moves, a combination of punches and kicks that depending on the combo are used in different sequences. The very first combo you'll have access is the triple punch. Now to spice things up, you can modify these combos with special moves called 'pressens', there are 4 categories to utilise, damage, healing, cooldown and chain. All do damage, but damage pressens deal more damage, healing pressens restore some HP, cooldown pressens reduce the remaining time of your special moves, and finally the chain pressen can deal any of the other three and further amplify its special property, depending what type of move was placed before it, in the combo. Also, the further a pressen is from the combo start, the higher its effect. So a 'punch-heal punch-damage punch' will do more damage and heal less than a 'punch-damage punch-heal punch'. Additionally, as the story progresses, you will unlock some ultimate moves, that once used trigger a cooldown that can be reduced by using cooldown pressens on your combos. Finally, you can edit your combos on the fly, be it in combat or even at 1 HP left. There are also boss fights, each quite unique and with different phases, all end with an interactable fighting scene, where you'll be prompted to use certain moves, failing to do so will result in the boss healing a bit and you'll have to do it again. Most boss fights will provide Nilin with an upgrade upon victory. As far as game difficulty goes, it just alters your enemies durability and damage. If you enjoy the combo system then I suggest you put the game on hard.-Exploration (or platforming): Sadly the game's world feels too linear, meaning there is only 1 way to move forward, and besides Nilins excellent wall climbing abilities, you are allowed to use only certain ledges, pipes or platforms to proceed. However, to cleverly fix this, the developers but several collectables to find in each area, making your time to explore worthwhile and makes you notice how awesomely well the level details are. Said collectables can increase your combat stats or unlock artwork. Most of the combat related ones are hinted by an image preceding them. As the game progresses these will become harder to notice and, if you want them, you'll have to look for them.-Puzzles: There are few of them overall. Some will be in the 'real' world, like altering platforms in order to make a path to proceed, and other will be in 'memories'. Memory related puzzles are truly the jewel of this game, you enter a person's memory and you have the ability to alter certain, seemingly minor, elements, be it a switch or making a bottle fall, the end result can surprise you! I strongly encourage you to try different combinations as most options have a noticeable effect and as each memory remix has its own bonus achievement! Sadly there are only 4 of these puzzles.The graphics are quite good as each area is well detailed, be it slums or high society. Enabling postprocessing will further amplify your game experience. However, I was amazed by the music! The soundtrack is simply amazing, I was in the main menu for 10 minutes just listening to that one track! The voice acting is also good, making the characters more lively and believable.The controls are quite simple and easy to get used to as the game will give you tips on what you need to do, especially if it's something new to your arsenal. The game supports both keyboard-mouse and controller inputs. However, only the keyboard can be customised, with the controller having a fixed layout, which left me with the dodge button being uncomfortable to use while combo-ing. But controller has a unique advantage over keyboard, on the boss execution/finish-off scene, where you'll be prompted to press certain buttons, the controller will display directly the button that needs to be pressed, e.g.: X/Y/A, while keyboard will display the move e.g.: punch/kick/dodge. While it's not a big issue, it may confuse players as some of these icons, e.g.: dodge, are rarely displayed during the game.The only negative areas of Remember Me are that combat can feel repetitive, which can be solved by setting the game on easy, also, while the outside areas feel and look massive, they are limited by the linear progression of the level. And finally, that there are only 4 memory remixes. However, while I certainly want more of those, given the level of detail into the 'action-effect' part of them I understand why these are only 4.On a grey area is the DLC, that, while it's certainly not a must buy, it will increase the number of pressens you have available and most importantly will almost double your chain pressens. The only real benefit is that you'll be able to make complete combos sooner in the game and have more complete combos later on.Overall Remember Me is a great game and a game that you will remember (pun intended). I enjoyed every bit of it and I'm going back to do the memory remixes again! It easily scores 8/10 on my list.-----------------------------------Introducing Gamephasiswww.gamephasis.com is a new gaming website featuring a talented team of game writers from around the world. Gamephasis features news, reviews, giveaways and much much more. Please visit us and join our Steam group. We're always looking for more talented gamers and writers to join our team.

												Pros: Intriguing story setting. Some of the outdoor environments are gorgeous. Memory remixes are fun and novel. Nilin is a stylish heroine. The English voice over is unforgettably well done.Cons: Extremely limited level design. "Invisible walls" everywhere. An outstanding example of the opposite of open world. content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Wanted to like this game though I'm not a big fan of the gameplay style but I just had to give up.The controls are way too bad... I tried both keyboard/mouse and gamepad but it doesn't work. Even in the easiest difficulty the fights are way too hard not because of the ennemies but because of the unresponsive controls. I tried changing the bindings see if a different key would work better but no it doesn't so it's clearly the game engine at fault. I'm stuck at one boss that I just can't pass because the only way to kill it is by aiming your special gun while moving and clicking to shoot at the same time and everytime the aiming button is not responsive so you press on it and nothing happen, you have to depress it and repress it to hopefully have it to work, but of course during that time you get hit... it's like this button would only work when the game allows it to in a way. And of course, getting rid of that boss is in 3 part and no checkpoint at the end of each part therefore if you die you have to start all over again and get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by those controls all over again.. till you are fed up with it and just give up. Too bad, I wanted to see where the story was going (even thoguh it was far from being very original) but won't be able to (unless I find a savegame that put me through that boss but then again I'd probably be stuck again a little while later) So my best guess is to find a playthrough on Youtube... I'm glad I got it in a sale. Would be very upset if I paid full price. Now, I understand why the studio went bankrupt... If you like the genre of action/platform with way too much fights and unresponsive controls, go ahead, otherwise you might want to try it out first.UPDATE: I finally managed to get through that boss fight thanks to some playthrough I found on Youtube. It seems to me that fight in particular really had a problem of lag with the Aiming button. The lag is always present but less noticeable in other fights. Lol, the fight right next after the boss fight I got stuck too... as predicted I might say but I managed it after a few retries. I'm glad I am able to go through the story and the game but I will not change my recommendation (as it either yes or no) because those fights are way too repetitive and frustrating in my opinion. I stick to my previous conclusion: try it first if you can.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Ironically, the game "Remember Me" is very forgettable. It's combat is very Arkham-esque, and it's very counter-intuitive. Unlike the Arkham series it draws from, combos are pre-determined and have to be timed. This leads to a really stiff and unforgiving combat system. The story itself is interesting at first, but it struggles to keep you engaged.  I myself didn't complete the entire campaign, so please keep that in mind, but at no point was I really emotionally invested in Nillin's story. Just bland and boring for the most part. The memory mixing is a great gimmick, in theory, but it's extremely linear and doesn't really allow you to mess around with memories. It's just "press button to do this specific remixing". The parkour and platforming elements are pretty rough, in my opinion. They don't feel very fluid, and tend to be frustrating. I'd give this game a hard 5/10. It borrows from other games, and it's story tries to be unique, but it just falls flat in it's execution and leaves me wanting more.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												This game sports a fascinating setting and gripping plot. It's future dystopia/paradise Neo-France and they invented the technology to alter and delete memories. Now we can erase all the pain without turning to booze, drugs, or sex! What's-the-worst-thing-that-could-HAPPEN. It's an action adventure game, so prepare to climb ledges and lunge from platforms like Just Cause. No guns though, so rev up that melee combo system. Combat is a real downer and at one point was so frustrating and poorly implimented I was about to quit. Damage increases alongside your combo meter but you can only RARELY execute the full combo without being interrupted which way more often than not makes it impossible to finish your combo. Too many enemies and crowds that attack way too fast. There are some KICKASS bosses and even a really interesting game mechanic where you enter someone's mind and alter their memories in a FMV sequence. The accumulation of your small changes to their memories results in HUGE differences in their perception. This is ingeniously executed and by far the most gratifying and unique part of the game.You can really tell combat is the weakest link in this otherwise forgotten (hah) video game. That's why their next project Life Is Strange catered to the studio's strength--the story.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Fun game, but it is first and foremost a brawler. If you don't like mashing left and right click several hundred times every few minutes, it will be very unpleasant.You can customize your combos in limited ways. Performing the 2nd-8th maneuver in a combo can give you either bonus damage, health, or reduce the cooldown on your S-Pressins (special attacks).The combos are as follows:Punch-Punch-PunchKick-Punch-Kick-Punch-KickPunch-Kick-Kick-Punch-Kick-KickKick-Kick-Kick-Punch-Punch-Punch-Punch-KickYou will unlock a number of the Pressins (slotted combo pieces) as you progress through the game, and each one is restricted to kick or punch. So if you only have free 2 health punch Pressins, you cannot make anything more complex than the simple 3-punch combo.Each stage of the combo does progressively more of the perk (i.e. a step 5 health Pressin will give more HP than a step 3 one), but don't expect to regularly reach anything beyond the 5-combo, because you will get interrupted all the time. You have to hit a stun S-Pressin or have 1 enemy remaining to get a long combo to completion.Some of the combos can just be easy cheesy, like Punch-Health Punch-Chain Punch. Such a combo will give you significant more HP than you lose by attacking an enemy that damages you when you hit them. Using a  6 combo of Punch-Cooldown Kick-Cooldown Kick-Cooldown Punch-Cooldown Kick-Chain Kick will allow you to completely remove the cooldown on the stun S-Pressin before it even wears off (you do have to perform it twice during the stun).There is some serious platforming, but the camera will change to fixed locations when you do certain areas. This can make it hard to see the indicator that you can make a jump or whatnot because you're looking at a 2D indicator from the side. When in these fixed camera locations, when you turn a corner, the camera jumps to a new fixed location and it can be disorienting, as well as your character will keep going on inverted controls for a second (pressing A to go left, then the camera changes, you character will go right while holding A until you let up for a second).The bosses LOVE to turtle. They will be unattackable unless you hit them with the stun S-Pressin, and will otherwise hurl explosives and minions at you endlessly until the stun S-Pressin comes off cooldown. Once you have managed to injure the boss to a critical state, the finishing move will be a Quick-Time Event. Failing the QTE will return them to non-critical health and you will be on cooldown for the stun again. A cooldown-heavy combo is highly suggested if you don't want to hear the boss repeat their lines for half an hour.Remixing memories is what we're all here for, and they're amazing how you can change little details to change a person's memory to a more favorable outcome for you. Unfortunately there are only 4 of these events, and pausing the memory on the glitches that you can interact with can be frustrating, as sometimes you have to hit the pause button before the "glitch here" icon appears onscreen.All-in-all, a fun game to get on sale. Replayability would be pretty subjective to the player, but I would think it to be low unless you just want to get all the collectables, as the cutscenes are unskippable and the fights tedious.

content:
Posted: March 14
												I really wanted to like this game. Its got a beautiful level design, interesting story, though it seems pretty forced, and some interesting mechanics. Regardless, I hate this game. I hate the camera which is either delayed on movement or in a number of locations you can't move it at all to try to see where you need to go. The arrow indicators to show you where to go are a curse and a blessing. Its good that it shows you where to move most of the time but there are areas where the up/down arrow indicators are wrong. I spent 10 minutesd looking for away to go only to find out the pipe that has an up arrow really meant for me to go down. Now, I could forgive all of these minor flaws, all of them, but I can't forgive a game that CONSTANTLY KEEPS TAKING AWAY MY CONTROL. I'm about 20-25% of the way through the game and it keeps introducing more information and new mechanics at the worst possible time. Yes, that is what I want to do, read 5, 6 or 7 informaiton messages right when I'm in the middle of a fight. Pulling me out of the game and story to contantly give informaton I should have been shown at the start of the game is not ♥♥♥♥ing fun at all. That, on top of all the constant cutscenes makes it frustrating to actually lose onself in the world they are trying to build. Maybe one day I'll go back to visit it and finish, but I doubt it, and I don't say that very often.

												The first thing I want to say: "Yes! ... It is totally overrated." I really tried to like this game. It all starts out well. The first cutscenes were promising. If you are in to cinematic games with minimal interactions, grab it. I won't recommend it for gamers liking to explore and having more interaction. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												It's not the greatest new IP to come out recently, but it isnt as bad as the scores may lead you to think. I've only just hit the final hours of the game, and it's definitely not worth the full price. Get it on a sale, it's too short to merit anything beyond $15, but definitely worth your time.-The graphics of the world are amazing in some areas, even with them on low I found the world to look rather stunning, it's a shame there's so little going on where you're supposed to be. I would have to interact with the enviorment more. It is indeed extremely linear, so if that turns you off just stop right here.-I personally loved the music and sound effects, though I do wish they had used some scores in more location or at least not where they did. I sometimes found myself listen to what seemed to be battle music in an average climbing section, though the majority of the time it fit the mood. I don't know if it was just me, but I experienced quite a few audio bugs. Multiple times I had duplicate sounds playing over each other, and the audio cut out entirely in some sections.-The story is definitely alright, but having just finished DX:HR my expectations may have been a bit high :P There are a few plot twists and I really enjoyed it, though I did wonder why I had to revist so many areas.- The combat, everyones favorite gripe. I recommend playing with a gamepad if you have it, I found some difficulty in managing everything, as unlike Arkham City or the majority of other games you dont have large amounts of time to react, or a counter. Unfortunately the dodge mechanic is rather lacking. I often found myself trying to dodge an AOE attack only to rebound over the back of the guy next to me and still be in the blast radius. Which is sad considering it's your only escape tool. The 3 hit combo is rather useless in my opinion, but being able to see the moves you'll use in the combo lab makes it fun to create the flashiest combos etc. I loved the design of the S-pressens, but losing all of your focus if you die was incredibly frustrating.-The controls are a bit finicky, as you can tell from my difficulty with the dodge in combat. Often in climbing I found myself headed back the direction I came when I wanted to back eject instead. Overall it definitely felt like it was designed for consoles in mind, but it's nothing too difficult.-DLC I found the majority of the dlc moves to be rather useless, but the Spinning Bird Kick is incredibly handy as the last hit of a combo, as it's rather an aoe meelee move, and as the last hit does alot of damage. The rest I never really used, but I loved that one.It's definitely not the greatest game ever, but its a fun few hours of distraction, and I hope we'll see a more expanded universe from this IP in the future.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												This is one of those games that is way more worthwhile than it's metascore would lead you to believe. It's not perfect, but it's engaging, it's gorgeous (especially if you've got a rig that can crank the settings up), and the story is solid with punctuated moments of impressive depth.The combat and traversal isn't wholly unique or innovative, really, but it's done well enough that it doesn't feel prohibitive to progressing through the story. The combat in particular, while it can take some getting used to, does allow for some creativity on the player's part, and can be customized through the swapping of individual strikes to form combos to suit your playstyle, or different situations.The memory sweeping mechanic is an interesting one, and probably had the most promise of anything in the game, however it winds up being under-utilized, with only a few points during the game giving you the opportunity to use Nilin's signature skill. The process itself is neat at first, but sort of unravels into a time-consuming trial-and-error experiment, with no real indication of which triggers that the player can control will actually have any desirable effects. Honestly, my one hope is that DONTNOD get's another crack at a game set in this world so that they can really hone this particular aspect of the game maybe create something really cool the next time around.Anyway, this game wound up flying under many radars, between the fledgling developer, the new IP, the middling reviews... But it's definitely worth your time, especially if you're looking for an action/adventure game featuring a strong and interesting female protagonist, and a beautifully realized world, wrapped in a quality storyline that will pull you along to a satisfying end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												I can safely say that this one was one of the rare innovative games in the last couple of years. Unique art, interesting gameplay mechanics and a creative/fresh-blood story. I'm especially surprised by the female protagonist, I can count on my one hand how many games have that currently. What was kind of a bit disappointing is the tunnel-linnear route of each chapter, probably because most of the games nowadays is going towards sand-boxing theme even if sometimes its filled with nothing (yes I'm looking at you Maffia 2), so I cannot really complain, but to be honest I dont think many people will play this game more than once. The combat mechanics is pretty much Batman-Arkham style, with this combo-lab improvement, interesting although the fights were quite frustrating from the 1/3 of the game even on normal! Invisible enemies? Enemies who constantly reflect damage? Gang-rap? There is no real tactics here, but teeth-grinding. I must admit by the end of the game I was pretty much at the verge of chucking my controller at the wall, eh oh yes, its seriously a controller-game, I warned you. Closer to the end of the game I have found some tricks, and it got a bit easier, although I always hated games where the common/filler fights were 3x harder then the boss fights. And one more thing, directed at all game companies: DO ENABLE US SKIPPING CUTSCENES! Hordes of angry mob of videogamers will storm your castles, if you do not stop making games WITH achievements AND unskippable cutscenes! Goodnight.

												Set in a dystopian future Paris, the attention to detail to the level design is quite enjoyable. Unfortunately, I find myself wishing this was an open world along the lines of an Assassin's Creed game. However, it plays more like Mirror's Edge where each level involves following a predetermined route, solving simple puzzles interspersed with combat and ending with a boss fight. Rather like playing through a movie or novel with a set path. The thematic elements and storyline are what draw me to this game more than anything else and in that sense I enjoy it for all the same reasons I enjoyed Mirror's Edge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Eh, it's okay.What you have here is a neat cyberpunk setting where, as you might expect, new technologies that have great promise (in this case, the ability to alter one's memories) lead to the creation of a world that... isn't so good. There's this massive corporation that, through it's control of this new memory-altering technology, is able to use that to exert a great deal of influence upon society and undertake some really messed up experiments. You play as Nillin, who is a "memory hunter" who is also to not only steal memories from other people, but to actually dig into their minds and change what they remember about them. It only happens about 4 times, but the memory altering is pretty cool as you try to find what you need to screw with in order to make a past event change - at least in the eyes of the person whose memories you are altering. I'd say the gameplay part of it kinda reminds me of Life is Strange, but... that's no surprise because it's the same devs who made both that and this game.The rest of the gameplay consists of some simple platforming, punching people, and... boss fights. I'm no fan of platforming, but here it basically tells you where to go next so at least this time I didn't sit around scratching my head about what to do. The combat that you engage in regularly involves using combos (that you adjust yourself which is pretty cool) and some special abilities that you unlock throughout the game. And while the regular combat is pretty neat, the boss fights... basically are a dodge-fest as you wait for special ability cooldowns (though you can shorten those cooldowns via yer combos). It's easily the weakest part of the game for me. Oh yeah, and the fact that the cutscenes are unskippable is rather annoying and is keeping me from hunting down the rest of the achievements. >_>So, overall? Yeah... this game is okay. The setting and story are competent, though a bit forgettable. The memory altering and combo building parts of the gameplay are pretty cool, but those have to share the same space as lame platforming and smelly boss fights. In other words... this would be a "maybe" recommendation from me, but is going to end up with "yes" because there is no such option.If the setting sounds interesting, then I suppose you can pick this up and check it out. Have funs! :o

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Make no mistake, this game is a delight to look at.  The city of Neo-Paris has been rendered in a way that lends considerable creedence to their vision of the near future.  Lots of little details are included that make the environments believable.That task was probably made easier by the highly-linear nature of the game.  On the one hand, you can lament how incredible this would have been to have the same level of detail in an open-world, but the linear nature allows for a high degree of polish on the path you follow through the world and story.The story's competent, and told well enough, though I don't think I was invested as the story expected me to be.  Nilin comes across as introspective, yet more than a little cold.There's a neat memory-remix mechanic introduced early on and it felt like I was nearly halfway through the game before it came up again, though there are several instances before all's said and done.  I'll echo the sentiments of several other reviewers who wished there was "more of that, please."The combat itself is also competent, in the Arkham vein but with a dodge rather than a counter, with a few nice touches to spice things up.  Depending on your play style, it's easy for some fights to overstay their welcome, but once you become comfortable with the combo system and fight mechanics (or like me learn to stop hoarding your special attacks) you can dispatch with most battles relatively expeditiously.  It's got QTE's, and while the button you press corresponds to the action executed it still feels more like a match game than a act of skill, but they're used to cap off certain battles rather than as a routine mechanic.I played with a mouse and keyboard and occasionally felt like the game wanted me to be using a controller, but it was never a serious handicap.  (Here's a tip if you're using a mouse and kb like me - the "Rewind" motion is like drawing a counter-clockwise circle with your mouse.  Perhaps I missed a critical instruction, but that really threw me off during the first memory remix.)I think there was something else I wanted to say, but I just...can't remember.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Nilin in WonderlandDespite some technical limitations, Remember Me is simply gorgeous with an intriguing premise but ultimately the experience becomes flat and repetitive long before the games final episode.Players assume the role of Nilin, an errorist agent who has been captured and her mind erased. After being commanded to follow a drone to a chair to complete the final process, a voice guides her on how to escape. The voice is that of Edge and he'll remain with you throughout the entire game as he instructs Nilin from each objective while Nilin herself isn't too sure if she trusts him.Once Nilin has escaped, Edge aids her further by telling her to meet another agent by the name of Tommy who gives Nilin her trademark outfit and a device that will help her remix the memories of others. Nilin is a memory hunter and has the ability to go into the minds of others and change their memories and as she is attack by Olga, a bounty hunter, this is where one of the games more interesting gameplay mechanic comes into play.During these remix sections, a scene will play out as a typical cutscene but once over, players are then given an objective to complete. Control is then given to the player who then must rewind through what they’ve just seen by rotating the left analog stick and interacting with part of the scene when a glitch appears. These can play out in completely different ways as experimenting can lead to its own rewards. Unfortunately these parts are so few and far between, half of the game goes by before encountering another. While it would've been predictable to have these remix parts for every episode, I found the ones there extremely enjoyable and would've happily done a dozen more if not only to spice the core gameplay up.For the most part, Remember Me plays out like the combination of a bad Uncharted with a bad Batman. You’ll do a bit of dull platforming for a bit then reach an area that looks like a fight will happen then a fight happens. The fighting mechanics do offer a unique take as combinations can be changed to suit how someone plays the game. For example, you can have one combination that focuses on attacks while another focuses on health regen. However, it only remains interesting for the first few episodes as the game just dolls out wave after wave of enemies. Even on the easiest difficulty this becomes as chore.The same too can be said of the games characters. Characters such as Olga and Tommy seem interesting at first appearance but nothing is done with them, especially Olga who is seemingly written out after the second episode only to randomly appear for a few brief seconds at the end of the game. Episode two goes one step further as players are introduced to X-Mas Kid. He’s given quite the spotlight as you’re given an idea of who he is and how he behaves through TV ads all with himself boasting all which lead up to a very special boss encounter.While the core gameplay is bad impression of other much better playing games, it can at least stand proud of its art design and visuals. The game grips you with the slums you first find yourself in to the beautiful streets of Saint-Michel but I quickly found myself very bored of the locations by the latter half of the game after visiting similar locations and running around very familiar looking hallways.The game is a very mixed bag and really falls in the last half of the game as the story becomes a mess that’s weirdly hard to follow and is at odds with the intrigue and mystery of the beginning but in the end, I wish I could remix it into a better one as the ironically titled Remember Me is a forgettable brawler that fails to deliver on its own premise.I would still really recommend this game though but only to those who know that this isn’t a great game by any means but to see the potential of what’s on offer here. There’s a really great Remember Me somewhere but this isn’t it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												I went into this game not really knowing what I expected; I was slightly dissappointed by my early playtime in the game. However, the more of the game I played, the more I liked it.DONTNOT Entertainment made several design choices in this game that made it very unique. The result was a game that may not have been fine-tuned to satisfy the masses' desire for a cookie-cutter game, but instead a work of art. The world that you are immersed in while playing this game is stunningly beautiful; a cyberpunk universe that's not just gritty but also gleaming is rarely touched upon by world designers, and it really paid off. The characters are all well-thought-out as well. Though some of the diologue gets cheesy and some lines are fairly predictable, there's a lot of effort that was done to stay true to an artistic vision, and that's something I really like.Now, on to the gameplay! This game has a little bit of everything--you have uncharted platforming, some third-person shooting, the unique remixing mechanic, some puzzles, and the fantastic combat. While the combat can get repetitive, it's very polished. The ability to create and manage your own combo strings is really cool, and encourages you to explore the world to level up faster. The wide variety of abilities you can select really do a good job of making you feel powerful and in control. To call it 'immersive' would be a stretch, but you get more of an ability to 'choose' how combat will flow (similar to say...Prototype). Most of my issues with the game are it's pacing; the levels are pretty linear, and the long platforming sections are sort of distracting from the combat. Can I call it a perfect work of art? No. However, it is a game that I would recommend people to take a look at. The gaming industry should certainly take a look at this game, because we need more innovation and new ideas out there.
