content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I've bought this game when it was on sale, personally I wouldn't pay the full price, the full price it's a bit expensive for me, but I am very glad that I got the game. I love a good strong women lead character and Nilin is amazing, the voice acting is great, the figure the movements of her are great. I am just in love with her, and it's always good to play with a female character (feminist alert). The storyline is simple, you are a person who lost her memory, can't remember a thing, you're trying to remember and everything just completes itself really. The world is set in Neo-Paris, very futuristic, but it has a dystopic vibe to it. You're feeling like you're in a chaotic world, which I liked. There are some puzzle bits in the game, they are enjoyable, complicated enough but not too hard too. There is a hospital bit which is very enjoyable, I never played a part like that and I absolutely loved it. My computer isn't great so I played in low-medium graphics but they were good, so I believe that if you have a good computer you'll enjoy the graphics very much. I think the soundtrack is very good, especially the main theme is amazing. First of all, I am not an action gamer, This paragraph is about the action of it. I am more like a simulator, casual, indie game kinda person. Euro Truck Simulator, Cities Skyline, Don't Starve kinda... I am not good with FPS games, or any kinda action games really. But I could manage the mechanics easily, they were easy enough for me to be comfortable with, I could arrange MY OWN COMBOS. Which was amazing, I litereally made combos focusing on gaining health and used them like 100 times in every single fight. The boss fights were bit tricky for me, I played each fight like 6 times but I did it, eventually. And I played on easy mode so if you're good with them you can always play them in harder modes, make more complicated combos, make more fancy moves idk. You can configure them according your skills, it's up to you! So I think that's good. Some people may think that the mechanics are not good enough but they were good enough for me. I'd give a solid 7/10 to it. And btw I am a keyboard/mouse player so if you're using controllers, it has to be much more better.Overeall I'd give a solid 8.5/10 to the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												[4/5]{TL;DR:Pros- Excellent female protagonist, good story, and beautiful environmentsCons- Game wants to be a movie, my knowledge of physics keeping the combat from being more than a bad joke}Set in a perfectly realized cyberpunk future, Remember Me is deeply satisfying. The environments are beautifly detailed and complement the free running elements of this title, even if it can turn into a "look at the pretty skybox" stlye staright path a times. On the subject of free running, you might expect a free running brawler to include some moves that include jumping on your enemies from a higher point, but this is sadly not the case, despite some of your early enemies utilizing this exact tactic. Instead you, playing as asmall, skinny woman, must stand on the same level as larger, sometimes hulking, enemies. Of course the protagonist does this with great ease, you don't want to design a game to be too frustrating, after all. I'm not saying Nilin should be weak and helpless like so many other female characters in games, in fact, I think she maybe the best example of a female protagonist in a video game yet. That said, while I can imagine that anyone of her size who can run and jump all around the obstacles Nilin encounters just on her way to the local bar to have the endurance and speed to hold up in a fight, the boss fight against X-Mass Kid is a mahor breaking point of this logic. Regardless, the combat is simple, yet fun. Besides, the size difference isn't the biggest problem with the game, the problem is that Remember Me desperately wants to be a movie. I may have only just started episode 3 (something Valve can no longer use as an excuse), but a good chunk of the game, about 1/3 of my playtime, has been spent in cutseens, scripted sequences and "pretty skybox" segments. I know this might be the "no" moment for those considering playing this, but hold on just a second. It turns out that the story is really good, so the "want to be a movie" problem is very neglegable. Also, in my opinion, the exploration and combat parts (you know, the game part) of the game show up enough to keep the movie bits from overstaying their welcome. All in all, this is a nice story with some fun, anarchist-cyberpunk brawler action. There are some flaws, as there are with any game, but nothing that can't be ignored when put next to the better elements.

												Graphics are fantastic. The sounds and game environment are rich and immersive. Gameplay is good, especially with a controller. I used an XBox 360 controller. Was a bit difficult with keyboard/mouse, probably because I don't play many linear games like this one. In fact the one complaint I'd have about this game is how linear it is. You go from one fight sequence to the next. Your character Nillin spends most of the game on route to an objective. There are lots of corridors to navigate and every 3rd or so hallway opens out into an arena/courtyard of some type where something always falls down behind you to trap you until you defeat several foes, after which some forward obstruction miraculously falls away allowing you to continue.This formula gets a bit tiring and persists throughout the game but when it was done, I realized that I had enjoyed it far more than I thought I would. So given that this is not my favorite genre, I have to give it a thumbs up. In fact I didn't even come to the store page to write a review but to see if there was DLC so that I could continue.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Remember me is one of those games that you should play, but would annoy you at times during play.I recommand the game, but I have my issues with it.Pros:The game has an interesting plot, and the setting (the city of neo paris) is extremely well thought of. The fights are fun and fluid. The remembrance mechanisms are well thought of and enjoyful.The game also brings forth important questions, and (unlike some games) is not really afraid to try and answer.Cons:However - the linearity of the game is obscene. Doors lock down and open to lead you in a straight line through the city.Your character can jump from ledge to ledge (assasins creed style / farcor style), but can't go over a 2 inch cardboard box on the floor. The fights are a bit repetitive and there's not enough remembrance mini games (perhaps 5 throughout the game).I also have an issue with the fact that it's a future paris with robots and virtual reality, but there's only one gun in the entire city (and someone shoots himself with it). Only bots and gunships seem to have real guns.And lastly - at some point during the endgame, you get attacked by a horde which shouldn't really be there, isn't a real obstacle at that point (you finished a far harder horde 5 minutes before), and has no real point. That single fight scene really damaged the immersive experience that was a big part of the end game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												3rd person, action, fighting game with platforming. You play as Nilin, a memory hunter as they call her in 2084 Neo-Paris. Story is very good in my opinion, that unravels as you go on, with unexpected twists, wont spoil.Game has some great environments, but most of the levels are linear, small, closed off sections. Tutorial system that will help you learn the basics, that I found very useful. There is simple platforming element, in form of climbing walls, ledges, pipes, etc., most of them are highlighted and you can't climb any wall you want. Basically you run couple dozen meters, climb a bit, then get cutscene and begin fighting some enemies. There is no particular order, but it's not as bad as it sounds.Fighting involves punch and kick combos that you combine in "Combo maker", dodging is also vital, to avoid damage. You unlock more and more moves as you play the game, there are different kinds of combat moves, some add more damage, some restore your health, some reduce cooldowns on more powerful moves, etc.Movement animations are good, didn't notice anything troubling, voice acting is also on level and is enjoyable, cutscenes are nicely done and angled. You will notice some low resolution textures here and there, but generally it's good looking game.There are a lot of collectibles in form of Data packages in game, that award you health upgrades, as well as some art and 3D models in Extras. Personally I very much liked how game levels looked, as well as Nilin and her small little bosom. I recommend this, have fun!

Posted: August 27, 2013
												I'm on the fence about actually recommending this game. It has a gorgeous world and level design with a beautiful soundtrack and great character / enemy designs. It also has an intriguing lore with good voice acting. Gameplay and combat are decent, but the game as a whole is short and many of the ethics and issues that are brought up in conversations are never fully discussed. This game could have been much more engrossing and thought provoking, especially when the best aspect of the game, the memory remixing, is under used. In the end, I am going to recommend this game (flaws and all) because of the need to support new IPs and female protagonists in gaming. Not worth full price, but certainly worth a look.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This game is better played with a gamepad.     For any cyberpunk lover "Remember Me" is a must-play. A world it presents is vivid, full of life, believable. The game is linear, but many locations I've been to looked amazing. Every object and entity looked like it was carefully incorporated into this world. The futuristic Neo-Paris could serve as an excellent background for an RPG (ah, if only). Though the story goes really fast,  I coldn't help but stop for a minute or two and take a good look around at the commoners, the dutiful valets, the beautiful landscape.     The combat system is really simple once you get the hang of it. The customizeable combos you create are quite simple to remember but not that easy to do once you're in a crowd of enemies. I sometimes cursed the lack of lock-on but overall it's not needed. Some fights take much longer than they should because attacking multiple enemies at a time is quite difficult. Performing a healing combo correctly can be vital at times, due to Elite Enforcers' ability to constantly damage you when they're hit, for example.     As for protagonist, our little slim smartie Nilin, she really kicks♥♥♥♥♥ She mistakenly seems fragile, but she can climb walls like Lara Croft and fight like Neo. A really adorable girl that has the ability to remix and steal memories. That's what the story revolves around: the great invention of the 21st century which can help rebuilding the world ravaged by war, or destroy it.The design, the animations and the visuals of the game are really amazing, but it could be so much better. A few levels are utterly boring (almost the entire Bastille). There are only four "memory remixing" episodes. And last is the combat which is spectacular but a little flawed, sometimes repetitive and tedious (I, for instance, have died about 20 times when fighting two Leapers that stole Trace's memory).If you're still in doubt, get this game on sale. It is really worth playing once. If you cope with the few flaws it has, it presents a great movie-like experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												A unique action adventure game in the vein of your traditional hack 'n slash or brawler action adventures. If you're into games like God of War or Devil May Cry, you may take a liking to Remember Me. It combines a fluid brawling mechanic with the Combo Lab, which allows you to construct your own hit combos to your own liking. The combat controls themselves are simplistic, alternating only between punch, kick, dodge, special techniques that trigger unusual conditions in the environment against your enemies, and using a sort of blast gun. On top of this, you get to do some parkour-style navigation and platforming through the environments, which strongly resembles the Prince of Persia games but is fairly simplistic. It even throws in a handful of easy puzzles here and there to mix things up, most notably the ability to "remix" certain people's memories during the storyline to make them change their beliefs.The setting, story and characters are by far Remember Me's strongest point. It's a very good cyberpunk scenario, revolving around themes of questioning the nature of personal identity and what kind of value you can place on memories. The graphics, sound effects, music, and overall atmosphere are excellent. The story concludes on an interesting ending and the journey there is at times unsettling—in all the right ways, as is appropriate for the scenario's genre.The game's weakest point is its total length and replayability. I played the game on the highest difficulty from the start, and was finished with the story within 12 hours. Now, this is not to say that it's super-easy or I'm very good, because I felt adequately challenged considering the setting and some fights and bosses gave me quite a bit to chew on till I had figured out how to beat them. The game has an excellently smooth learning curve and maintained an entertaining difficulty throughout. The amount of hand-holding was kept to the minimum of what's expected of modern games and some of the fights and boss scenes surprised me in how the game designers wanted players to think outside of the box and inject some variety outside of the regular brawling with common enemies throughout the game. However, the issue still stands: the length and replayability is extremely limited. Outside of going back to hunt for all achievements and hidden items, because the level designs are very linear and there are no additional challenge modes or anything else to extend the play experience.Everything gels nicely in this game. Nothing feels contrived or redundant, which is often a problem with games in this genre, where you'll complete the game with abilities you never used or features that you ignored. If anything, I wish it were longer so I could get more use out of its many cool features, and I'm looking forward to any games that DONTNOD produces next. If anything about this game looks or sounds even remotely interesting to you, you should give it a try.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												I went into this game not really knowing what I expected; I was slightly dissappointed by my early playtime in the game. However, the more of the game I played, the more I liked it.DONTNOT Entertainment made several design choices in this game that made it very unique. The result was a game that may not have been fine-tuned to satisfy the masses' desire for a cookie-cutter game, but instead a work of art. The world that you are immersed in while playing this game is stunningly beautiful; a cyberpunk universe that's not just gritty but also gleaming is rarely touched upon by world designers, and it really paid off. The characters are all well-thought-out as well. Though some of the diologue gets cheesy and some lines are fairly predictable, there's a lot of effort that was done to stay true to an artistic vision, and that's something I really like.Now, on to the gameplay! This game has a little bit of everything--you have uncharted platforming, some third-person shooting, the unique remixing mechanic, some puzzles, and the fantastic combat. While the combat can get repetitive, it's very polished. The ability to create and manage your own combo strings is really cool, and encourages you to explore the world to level up faster. The wide variety of abilities you can select really do a good job of making you feel powerful and in control. To call it 'immersive' would be a stretch, but you get more of an ability to 'choose' how combat will flow (similar to say...Prototype). Most of my issues with the game are it's pacing; the levels are pretty linear, and the long platforming sections are sort of distracting from the combat. Can I call it a perfect work of art? No. However, it is a game that I would recommend people to take a look at. The gaming industry should certainly take a look at this game, because we need more innovation and new ideas out there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2013
												Paris, 2084. It felt like I was part of the future of humanity and although the game didn't have the best graphics, I felt it was good enough to pull me in and place me in this grim future where you play as Nilin, a Memory Hunter. The story was great and the atmosphere only added to it. Combat was kind of repetitive but they do continue to add new or stronger enemies throughout the entire playthrough of the game. Unlocking pressens, which are basically just extra moves in your combos, to combine with other pressens will allow you to customize the way you fight, but only to a degree. There are only 4 combos in the game but you are able to re-arrange or change how your combos work. One that will heal a great deal or do as most damage as possible. There are also 5 abilities you unlock throughout the game that can change the course of a battle entirely. Setting a bomb on the chest of an enemy or using an enemy mech to do damage for you. Exploring is limited as it's quite a linear game, however there are collectables hidden throughout the game that you will only find if you actually try to find them. Some are hidden off the main path and not easy to see. Others are right in front of you.Memory Remixes allow Nilin to change how someone might behave in their life. Changing someones memory in order to change the way they feel about someone, or something that happened in their life will change the path they choose to follow in the game entirely. Although there are many different outcomes in each memory remix, you can ultimately only choose one to complete the remix.I played on Hard Mode and finished the game 10 and a half hours with 30/50 achievements. The game also offers a New Game+ where earning PMP to do your skills is much harder to get. At $49.99 I would hold off, however, I paid $33 for it and was very pleased with my purchase and would recommend anyone into Action games to give it a try. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I liked it.The visuals are pretty amazing, the fake 3d on my monitor worked well with them too.The memory remix mechanic is cute though it's impossible to fail, just a matter of repeating a short segment until you've found all the glitches required.  You only do it about six times in the game so it's not a constant thing.The game has an interesting plot and they've put considerable thought into the ramifications of a single technology.  In some ways, the plot or at least the background, resembles Syndicate Wars a little.  I guess all Cyberpunk dystopias look a little bit alike.The gameplay mostly falls into parkour that is almost but not quite on rails and Over-The-Shoulder brawling which is quite a lot like Oni with punch/kick combos that you customise a little with various side abilities like regen/damage/cooldown as well as some special abilities that you build up focus for.  The fights aren't so frequent that you get bored and there's enough variety in enemies to keep it interesting.All in all, a very well executed cyberpunk game with a dash of philosophy to it.Time to complete: 14 hours at a casual pace.

												Remember Me takes and sets In a futuristic Neo-Paris In 2084. You are Nilin, the memory hunter. Everyone, the government Is afraid of you-- until you are wiped of everything you knew. As Nilin fights to remember and retrieve her memories, she relearns her combat, reminisces with her friends and makes It back to the top of the food chain, as the master memory hunter. You discover that Memorize, the game's tyrant Is running everyone's memories down, turning them Into creatures, mutants, monsters. Find a way to stop them In this action-packed, Immersive combat, and fast paced, heart racing Cyberpunk world.     I was quite Impressed when I first played the game. The first hour was very Immersive, with the world taking you Into it. I am a huge fan of Cyberpunk and this game captures It all. I knew this would be the game for me once I saw It. The combat Is fluid and varies depending on you. You can change up the combos with different types of effects, such like regenerating health, adding onto combos, amplifying damage, or even prolonging your combos! The story Is great, 'nuff said.     10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Remember me is a game that manages to still be fun and worth my time even when it has some critical flaws. I'll start with the biggest flaw: to many enimies. This would not be a problem if you were able to attack more than one foe at a time, but that is not the case. In a game that has such a strong focus on making your combos have useful effects it is really sad that it is rare to complete a combo. You will have to dodge an attack from some other dude before you can complete the combo you crafted that heals your character as well as lowers the cool down on other abilities. I ultimately just made all my combos three or four moves instead of the eight or so moves possible in some of the combos. The fact that there was no way to really do crowd control without your special abilities (which have a cool down timer after use) really just made the millions of crowds this game threw at you annoying. Fights were awesome when it was one on three or even one on four reasonable enemies, but once hoards of leapers came in or guys who when you hit them electicuted you, the fun left and was replaced by tedious dodging and little jabs here and there. I turned down the game difficulty towards the last hour just so I could use my combos without worry.But I did manage to have a good time with this game. Despite the flawed combat, it was sometimes still really fun, especially when using special powers or performing takedown moves. All your powers in this game look like cubist modern art and it's so awesome. Boss battles were fun as well, while not on the caliber of Metal Gear Rising, still nice multistaged fights in some really slick environments.Neo Paris is just such a well realized world. Orange lights just are glowing everywhere surrounded by urban decay except for in the richest part of town with the pure blue skies and pristine clean buildings. It helps that the graphics are just dazzling. The port is very solid without framerate hitch or stutter even once with everything cranked up all the way with to many enimies on the screen. I played this game to explore this city. To do genaric style "grab the ledges and poles" platforming over a destroyed factory with that orange glow under my feet. To fight to many enimies in a dream esc cubist world inside somebody's head.One more aspect of this game that kept me coming back was the plot. While the story wasn't perfect, the main character was well written and was forced to explore a lot of moral grey area. A lot of the really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ things you do end up helping you, and never bite your♥♥♥♥♥ The plot does not stick to karma in a boring way most videogame plots tend to do, but rather just tells a mostly realistic-ish story with realistic-ish results for the character's actions. Also, the plot is closely tied with these segments called "remixes" in which you change a person's memory. While they don't happen that often, when they do it is a real treat. They tell good little stories and just let you play around with variables to change the end. Of course there is a desired set of variables, but I had fun playing with the wrong ones and seeing what happened. It was a cool mechanic.So overall, the gameplay is the worst part of this game really, which should be criminal. But somehow, the super slick polish and the smart story won me over. Who-woulda-thunk?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Setting/VisualsThe game had me at cyberpunk. I am a huge fan of the genre and an even bigger fan of fully-realized world building (Fallout 3, Deus Ex etc.). So imagine my surprise when I hear of a new setting, a Neo-Paris, to explore. Each character feels unique no matter their screen time and Nilin has some cornball dialogue but overall feels like a solid character and is torn between being a rebellious memory hunter and the conflict in the story ("This red-riding-hood has a basket full of kickass!" per example of bad writing).The textures and visuals are beautiful and the neon is well-balanced with the trashy dim lighting for a cyberpunk vision. Seriously, when you first start each level take a minute to just swing the camera around and view everything. It's all designed with love and the little touches make everything truly come alive. Consider the mass produced Valet androids that are running around holding grocery bags, walking dogs, playing piano. It's amazing and I will definitely "remember" that ;)GameplayIt's an old school beat-em-up with some HD visual packaging. Your only incentive to unlock and experiment with new combos in the branching combo system is achievements and dispatching enemies quicker but once you find 2-3 combos that work you won't deviate from them; it's just too taxing to keep opening the menu to try new things. There are a decent amount of enemy types and some engagements are multiple types at a time which keeps things fresh. Platforming is light and engaging but tends to drag on. However, it only seems that way in hindsight perhaps because the environment and atmospheric splendor is so engaging.Gotta split this up to take an average because the visuals and world building left such an impact on meSetting/Visuals9/10Gameplay6/10Overall7.5/10  Would play again

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Remember Me is a uniqe attempt of a beginner studio at making a clever story about time travel. Since it's 2016 now, we have  Life Is Strange - so go play that first, and then play Remeber me as a "back to basics" vesrion. Many concepts and even gameplay elements have a similar feel to them, but this one also offers combo-based combat (which is very well-made for busy people who cannot remeber a combo since they play on a weekly basis).The story is comparable to a book, but the experience is a game-exclusive one: you could never just watch it on a screen or just read it from paper. You have to DO it yourself. Basically, 10/10 for effort and ideas, 8/10 for execution. Shouldn't be played as anything other than a storytelling experience, since that's what it is (although battle mechanics are quite nice).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Remember Me is an entertaining game with an interesting concept that was unfortunately not executed to it's fullest potential. Players take control of Nilin, a memory hunter with the ability to "remix" people's memories. She herself has had her memories erased, and is working with a mysterious man named Edge and the "Errorist" cause to take down Memorize, the company that has commercialized memories and is slowly corrupting the population.Playing as a character who's memories have been wiped puts the player in an interesting place where they know as much as the character knows. This concept is good for story development, however it also tends to be the game's own undoing. The game does a poor job of making the player ask questions about who and what Nilin is, so when the game makes reveals about the story they feel almost unimportant and unneccesary.The concept of remixing memories is interesting, however if felt almost tacked onto the game in most scenarios. I would have liked to see more applications for this concept, but unfortunately it only comes about four or five times in the game's rather short 8 to 9 hour campaign.The game's combat and other mechanics are fun, but they seem familiar save for the concept of building your own combos. However, I didn't find myself using that concept as much as I think the player was intended to use them; typically i only needed two or three of the five available combos to get through combat instances. These instances were very fast-paced, however, and were fun to play through, if they were just a tad on the easy side.Remember Me's soundtrack was probably one of my favorite parts of the game, and really served as one of the best atmospheric elements of this game.All in all, Remember Me is definitely a fun game that can be played in a weekend. It's not one that you'll be missing out on if you skip it, but it's definitely worth picking up if you see it on sale.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												This game was pretty amazing from the beginning. It takes an hour or two to figure out the system and basic layout of the game, but its a shame this game didnt take off and sell a million copies. The story is a big driving force in the game and the main heroine is likable and charismatic. The battle scenes are top notch and the overall gameplay is similar to Enslaved with a mix of combos.The combo system is unique and original, and its actually beneficial to learn each one (there are 4).Each combo can be tailored to your liking and play-style and they become a major necessity. There are very unique moments in the game where you have to alter people's memories to achieve a particular reaction from them, and this is one of the greatest aspects of the game. The combat remains interesting throughout the game and the story remains clear and there isnt a moment where it becomes boggled in confusion or side-tracking. Over all, I really enjoyed the game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys a medium length game with tons of action, some character development, and combo and quick time event sequences.

												I really recommend buying and playing the game till the end!So the game starts of horrible, the graphics and everything looks amazing don't get me wrong, but the gameplay in the first half of the game is super boring. So  just turn off your brain and keep on trucking untill you reach chapter 4-5. You need to parcour your way through a city, but it's all pointed out for you so you just follow a path. They don't even give you the illusion that you can figure your own way out. So that's really sad. The combat is fun for how long it lasts, which isn't long at all. When you reach chapter 4-5'ish the game really starts. The combat gets fun, rewarding and challanging. The story starts to blossom and the parts inbetween become shorter and less of a choar and more of a puzzle.Speaking off puzzles, there are some really cool and thought through puzzles in the game where you rearrange memories of people and solve riddles. The combat gets awesome because you learn different combo's and sick cooldown moves.You'll hopefully notice a lot of winks and references to all sorts of things in the game which is always fun.The environment is so well put together that it's a shame they didn't make it open world for the player to discover.It's hard to explain why you should buy and finish this game without spoiling anything. But I can say you will enjoy awesome boss fights, beautifull environments and graphics and the best part about the gameis the great storyline which is like a mix between Inception and Memento in the best way possible :) This game could've easily been a great movie.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game features some of the most underappreciated graphics I've seen in a while, and that's running the game on medium settings with a low-power graphics card. Altough combat gets less and less exciting the further you progress, the impressive detail gone into the design of Neo-Paris and the storyline accompanying draws your attention away from the more minor flaws.Pros:- Stunning visuals- Runs well on low spec CPUs- Interesting storylines- Memory remixing mechanic is well built- Customisable combos with different moves- Voice acting is not too badCons:- Fighting is easy and reptitive- Little variation between enemies- Camera angles can be ambiguous- Controls while scaling walls are awkward- You can backflip away from enemies any time you like?- Very linear storyline- Arrows are constantly telling you where to go: all difficulty of finding your way is lost.My favourite part of the game so far is being able to admire all the scenery and effort that has been put into the level desing - especially while climbing up pipes (you get some of the most amazing views while climbing up pipes on the sides of buildings). The tall, majestic buildings of the city and the deteriorating pits of the slums. I only wish fighting wasn't so easy. You can beat your way through several enemies very quickly by simply spamming the LMB and RMB keys. Even once you have defeated an enemy, if you keep clicking, Nilin will backflip straight to another enemy and continue fighting immediately. There is a very low level of difficulty between most enemies, the hardest being those that can disappear at will. On the other hand, I do enjoy the fact that you can customise your combos with different moves, or "pressens". However this also can make fighting simple as there are pressens that can regenerate your health. As soon as you equip these very close to the beginning of a combo, any damage you happen to take has virtually no impact as you can just brush it off by beating up more enemies.TL;DRIf you enjoy games with very appealing graphics and games which aren't CPU intensive, this is the game for you. It has a good storyline, but fighting is too easy and repetitive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
TL;DR: 11/10 needs remix edition But seriously, I actually enjoyed this game so much that I couldn't help giving it a full review.  (Please don't take this to mean that my typical brief reviews indicate any lack of enjoyment!)Summary:  An eccentric-but-enjoyable mashup of Tomb Raider, Inception, and Trace Memory, Remember Me features phenomenal storytelling, artwork, and voicing, marred only by some loose ends and slightly buggy controls.StoryThe story begins, as most do, with the introduction of the protagonist.  Nilin is preparing for induction at La Bastille, a maximum-security prison in Neo-Paris, A.D. 2084.  Inmates there are stripped of not only their belongings, but their memories as well, thanks to Sensen technology developed by the Memorize Corporation.  Sensen allows users to capture, remove, and share memories as easily as digital photos, but like any technology, it can be abused.  Memories are the new recreational pleasure drug, and an entire culture has built up around buying, selling, and stealing them.  Nilin, however, possesses the rare ability of changing them....Of course, there's a lot more to it than that, which I won't reveal in the interest of keeping spoilers to a minimum.  But, all told, it's attention-grabbing, thought-provoking, and has some curious twists that actually make sense in retrospect.  My major gripe is that there are a few loose ends left dangling:  for instance, what will happen if and when Olga discovers that her memory has been altered?  But I'd like to give the benefit of the doubt and say that maybe they're just leaving options open for a sequel.GameplayThe gameplay switches somewhat regularly between three modes (or, really, one mode split up into stretches of different types of actions), with an additional fourth mode that appears only at certain points in the game.The first is what I call "Exposition Mode," and consists mainly of walking through a relatively safe area while listening to someone (usually the mysterious "Edge") giving instructions and/or backstory.  This is the first mode introduced as you stumble through the prison hallways, and comes up several times per episode, usually as "breathing room" between high-tension scenes.The second is an "Adventure Mode," involving lots of climbing, jumping, and other dangerous acrobatics dozens of feet above the ground -- if there is any ground.  This is typically more a puzzle than a test of skill, as Nilin will automatically perform the maneuvers if you press the proper direction and action buttons, so you needn't worry much about your aim.Third is "Combat" mode, in which Nilin unlocks her "Pressens," a variety of combat skills.  You start with a limited set of Pressens, but collect more through the course of the game.   You can customize Nilin's attacks by chaining Pressens into Combos, with each strike having effects such as extra Power, Regenerating health, or accelerating the Cooldown of Special Pressens (S-Pressens).  Pressens have greater effect further down the chain, so modifying Combos can be a valuable strategy in certain situations, especially at Memhunter difficulty.  Mechanical enemies can't be attacked with regular Pressens, though:  you'll have to rely on a weapon or certain S-Pressens for them.  Combat is mostly about timing and strategy, as Combos only work properly if you attack a single enemy with them, but you'll need to keep an eye on the others so they don't blindside you.  N.B. Combat occasionally includes QTEs.  It's just a few button-presses usually, but they can catch you off guard, and missing them may force you to replay a segment.Fourth, the defining special mechanic of the game, and, sadly, appearing only rarely (four or five times altogether) is the "Remix Mode."  You don't play Nilin directly in this mode; instead, you watch a scene from a character's memory, then rewind it and alter details to "remix" the memory according to your objective.  (Keep in mind that this alteration occurs only in the subject's memory -- it doesn't change reality.  This is a minor plot point a couple of times, as well as the key to a few achievements.)  I really wish this had been used more, as it's really what makes this game stand out from others in the genre.As mentioned above, I had a couple of control problems.  The main one is navigating choices with the mouse:  when making a selection (such as menu items, or selecting a target with some S-Pressens), the game handles mouse motion like a gamepad rather than giving you a cursor, and moving the mouse continuously moves the selection continuously.  This gets very, very frustrating after a while.  As a workaround, I found that WASD also changes the menu selection, so I stuck to that.Another problem is that, at times, the camera would "stick" at a certain angle and be difficult to adjust, and sometimes at extreme vertical angles it would start to flip rapidly (i.e. possibly symptoms of no vertical angle limit).  These particular problems were only occasional, and for the most part I actually found the camera worked extremely well, keeping everything you needed to see in view.GraphicsI actuallly went and bought a new graphics card to play this game (and others) in its full high-definition, all-settings-maxed glory.  And I'm glad I did, because while my old card might have managed to play the game, it would only be at about half the resolution and the lowest quality settings, and even then would've been a bit slow.  The real-world graphics are amazing, hyper-realistic, artfully blending high-tech holography with backdrops of run-down slums and high-fashion districts alike, somewhere between cyberpunk and "cyberpreppy," if you will.  In contrast, the realms of memory realize the fuzzy, fragmented nature of human memory:  still detailed, but disconnected and unstable, dominated by empty space and shifting features.  In short, even if Remember Me had no story at all, it could probaby still sell as an art piece.SoundI'm no audiophile, here, but I will say that I had no issues with sound quality.  The voicing was beautifully done, and I noticed very few instances, if any, of awkward dialog.  Music was interesting, though I mostly remember (haha) the credits song, a classical-style piece with some rock/metal worked in and quite a bit of glitching that I think was intentional.OverallRemember Me includes a number of elements familiar from other titles, uniquely "remixed" into a pointed story about the importance of remembering the past; the settings and characters are well-crafted and believable, even whilie the story rides the bleeding edge of science fiction; the gameplay introduces a new, but underused, mechanic that provides a refreshing shift in perspective.  If you like hard sci-fi, cyberpunk, Inception, Blade Runner, Ghost in the Shell -- or just about any science fiction ever -- this is a game to pick up, for the story alone if nothing else.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Summery:Graphics: 10/10 (Never seen a game as detailed)Music: 10/10 (Contributes perfectly to atmosphere and great quality)Sound: 8/10 (Could do with some more bang)Gameplay: 5.5/10 (Very railed. Controls feels sticky and tricky if not used to it. Also a few GAME BREAKING BUGS)Story: 10/10 (Sci-fi/action/drama masterpiece movies only dream of... very deep)Detail:From the entry you are thrown into a world full of motion, intense detail and great effects. Capcom have gone above and beyong the call of duty to make this most likely the best looking game out there. Seriously, this is something special. The world constantly changes and every section feels unique. You sometimes stop to take a closer look. If you play for only graphics, you seriously can't miss this out.The music is epic and placed well throughout the game with varieties of the theme song popping up now and then.The sound is great, but could have done with some more bang in it. You don't always get that sense of doing damage or chaos happening. Well, you do, but it could have been so much better.Once you start playing the game, the first bit of issues pop up. Controls are not as slick and fast as for example Batman Arkhum. Yet it requires a way faster response time in combat. Climbing around also does not feel fluid. You get amazing views, but sometimes it is as if the camera wants you to see the view and not the character, making navigation a bit difficult. The real problem is all the bugs. Now, some bugs one can live with, but here we have a few that get you stuck. For instance, not killing all the enemies before terminating a boss when he is subjected to overload, will combat stuck the game and you will have to restart. Even if you follow those rules, you sometimes still get stuck and have to kill the boss from checkpoint restart. This is such a HUGE shame for this game, since...The story being told in Remember Me is of epic proportion. Many games try to have a great story. Only few succeed. This one goes beyond succeeding though. If you are willing to go through the bugs (which are not a lot, but they really break the game at times) you will be treated with an original and gripping story that you will not forget easily.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Confession time: I've really tried my best to like the Elder Scroll series. Seriously. I've purchased almost all of the recent games and given them each a few hours to win me over and none of them have done it. It's confusing to me because I really enjoy sprawling dramatic RPGs. I spent over 100 hours on the Fallout games and another 200 on the Mass Effect series. I think my problem is the fantasy setting; thees, thous, spells and swordplay never seem to resonate with me as much as the future (dystopian or otherwise). That's how I found Remember Me. I was reading some of the forums posts about the recent port of Deus Ex: The Fall and someone recommended it instead. Thankfully it was also part of the Steam Sale. Remember Me takes place in the Sci-Fi Dystopian Future of 2084. We've figured out how to backup, restore and replay human memories. These memories can also be bought, sold, shared or stolen. You play Nilin who is a memory hunter in New Paris who has the ability to manipulate and "remix" memories. Oh and she doesn't remember her past!1! So yeah - dramatic political intrigue, conspiracy, etc. Fun stuff. No swords. The city reminds me of Deus Ex except it is 3rd person and not gold tinted. It's really pretty beautiful. The gameplay is really reminiscent of the recent Batman Arkham games. There's a simple, but fun combo system interspersed with counter-attacks and some gadget weapons. I enjoyed the flow of fighting in the Batman games and this really scratched that itch. You can also customize your combos so that as they stack they'll do different things, such as do extra damage, refill your health or recharge your gadgets. For the most part it is really well done and has full controller support. I've played the game for about 6 hours and I've had two chances to "remix" memories and that mechanic is pretty fun to. Kind of reminds me of the crime-scene mechanic in Batman Arkham Origins. You can rewind and replay the memory to notice and interact with certain items. As you do so - that person's memory may change in ways that further the story. Fun stuff. Also worth mentioning that Nilin is a cool main character. She's in good company among Jade (Beyond Good and Evil), April/Zoe (Longest Journey) or Kate Wilson (Hydrophobia). So far the story is interesting and the voice acting is good. The two downsides for Remember Me are 1) it is only available for Windows and 2) the Steam Sale has ended so the game back up to $29.99.  Other than that I highly recommend this as an alternative to a game with swords or gold tint.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												It's not often I get choked up by a game, but this one nailed it.  Absolutely beautiful story, beautiful setting and some interesting mechanics.   As the game starts, Nillin is completely amnesiac, so you know just as much of what's going on as she does.  It's hard to write a really positive review about this game when its strongest point is the story, so I'll move on to some of the other aspects of it.Aside from the story, one of Remember Me's best points is the combat.  It's a free-flow, combo-based system reminiscent of the Arkham series, except that YOU choose the effect that the attacks have.  Extra damage, health regeneration, and a reduction in your special ability's recharge time (more on that in a minute) are the three choices you have, but in addition to that you can use a chain effect which mimics and magnifies the effect of your previous hit in the combo.  These can be changed mid-combat via a menu in the pause screen, to suit your needs in a particular fight. Nillin gets a TON of character development, but most of the other characters you meet don't really get explored.  Early on you meet someone who is supposedly one of your closest friends, but he never appears again after Episode 3.  This is, understandably, Nillin's story, but the game could have done with a bit more character development.  My only other big complaint is with the climbing.  When you're first introduced to the climbing mechanics, it feels like a tutorial, but the training wheels never really come off.  It has the look of Assassin's Creed-style parkour, but it feels very restrictive and not at all fluid, in several cases almost to the point of immersion-breaking.  I think that if DONTNOD had put some more time into the climbing mechanics, it could have been better than it is.All in all, weighing the bad with the good, I'd give this an 8.5/10.  The few issues I have with the gameplay aren't enough to really take away from the phenomenal story that this game has to offer, and I can honestly say that I was at the edge of my seat for a fair portion of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												I got this game in a sale and it was worth every penny.  Even at full price this game is worth it compared to many AAA titles that are $60 plus.It has an engaging story with likeable characters that you grow to care about and the voice acting is spot on.  The atmosphere in the game is really well done.  The game is set in a futuristic Paris where people's memories are a hot commodity and an evil company misuses their power to create a gap between rich and poor.  Overall I liked the story and it last about 7 hours (my gameplay time is higher because I alt+tabbed for a while). This game would have benefited from being more open as the futuristic paris looked great, I just wish I could have explored it more.I've seen a lot of people complain about the fighting mechanics, I suspect this is because they couldn't get to grips with them because I really liked them.  You can devise your own combos adding in different elements to change what your attacks do.  You also get a select few "special" attacks which do different kinds of damage.  At the end of the story with them all unlocked you can really pull off some cool combos and techniques.Unfortunately the game has little replayability value given its very linear story, save for going back to collect things you missed.  Unless you're an achievement hunter though, I doubt you will do this.  There's not much to be gained.Pros:- Strong female lead- Well written and voice acted- Interesting and at times philosophical story- Intriguing combat and cool combos- Great atmosphere and good graphicsCons:- Quite short (7hrs, max)- Not much replayability

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												I've been wanting to write this review for quite some time, so here goes (spoiler free):Remember Me is an action adventure / platformer hybrid with a length of roughly 12 hours by DONTNOD.This review focuses on its platforming, combat, visuals and story.The platforming is a bit simple, as the game always points you in the right direction using arrows. If you don't like platforming, you probably won't have much to complain. However if you actually like platforming, you will find it much too simple - it's not bad per se, but a bit sad.The game's combat has been compared to the Batman Arkham games. In this regard, it does not hold up, as it's not nearly as versatile and fluid. However, I think that the combat system of Remember Me shouldn't be compared to it, as it is fundamentally different. Instead of different combos, you learn "pressens", which are a certain sequence of button presses. These pressens must be unlocked and their effects can be customized to increase the combat's depth. If you can let go of the expectation that the combat is supposed to work like the Batman games, it's relatively easy to enjoy and find it satisfying.So far, the game is a mixed bag - the platforming is simple and the combat is a bit disappointing. Checkpoints are usually placed okay and rarely get you into unfair situations. The only real annoying thing about the combat is that the tutorial explanations pause the game until you do what they want and this happens on your second playthrough as well.As you probably know, the game is set in the world of Neo Paris. The developers have pictured their unique vision of the future where everyone stores their memories using the "sensen" program by "memorize". Overall, the world looks visually impressive and its developments seem believable. I especially love their way of doing buttons, switches, etc inplace by overlaying information without showing a HUD (and breaking immersion of the game). As there are techniques to store your memories, this way of augmented vision is believable.So far, we have a good looking attempt at a new game with a fresh world. But that's not all of it:Remember Me really shines when it comes to story. I found it to be greatas it takes you on a wild ride through the life of various personalities and tries to explain their past. This can be compared to Arkham Asylum, where the game is like riding a rollercoaster. As you drastically change peoples memories, you can see how your actions alter their character and actions. The plot is full of surprising twists and concludes with a very satisfying ending, unlike many other games lately. Unfortunately, I don't think I can find the right words to capture it, so I really think you should experience it for yourself.All in all, the game really is a mixed bag. If you can live with an emphasis on story and less focus on the mechanics, you will certainly be rewarded for your patience with a new, exciting game. I recommend you pick this up when it's on sale :) Oh yeah, and do yourself a favor: play it with a gamepad!

With games like Deus Ex and Shadowrun pioneering the Cyberpunk genre/setting Remember Me is a different interpretation of the very Cyberpunk ideal but it does it in such a way that it resonates with the core themes that Cyberpunk present.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Remember Me is an underrated rare gem within all the other AAA games out there. But of course it's not perfect. Really not perfect.+Unique ideas such as Remixing, which means reading someones mind, then altering a specific memory, creating very different outcomes, altering that persons personality and personal past which changes the present and future. With 2 words:  Butterfly Effect.+Customizable combat. You can create your own combos from Pressens. And there are 4 types of Pressens: Healing, Block Breaker/Stronger hit, reduces cooldown of your special abilities, and the final one which increases the effect of your latest Pressen in your combo+Variable enemies+Beautiful visuals+Comfortable controls (with Xbox 360 Controller, I never tried with KB+M)+Challenging bossfights, where you always have to have a unique tactic+Speaking of tactics, when the game senses you're struggling with a boss/puzzle, after a while it will help you, but at first it will only help you a little bit, and then you still have no idea what to do it will tell you the soulution. Saves you from searching it on YouTube+Many cool abilities. "Memory gun" to telekinetic powers, and lots of more.+Story is very good, not that mind blowing type, but still very good with many twists+Tickets to the feels train! I warned you+Music is very well composed. Slightly futuristic, but (thanks god) not exaggeratedly+/- Many bosses have QTE finishers. Personally I like QTEs but many people don't so yeah warned you again+/- I found kind of enough the memory remixes, but it wouldn't be a problem if there would be...let's say 5 more...or at least one in every episode.+/- Kinda average optimisation. Not that Ubisoft type slideshow, but not that impressive-The game uses Unreal Engine 3, which wouldn't be a problem, but it uses a very old version, which has it's own problems. Common in-game streaming, which causes FPS-drops like hell; sometimes textures are missing, invisible/stuck enemies etc. Certainly not a problem on a personal nuclear power plant, but still...-I found the included binkw32.dll pretty outdated, which caused some annoying echo during cutscenes. This could be easisly fixed by replacing it with a newer one.In overall: As I said before it's a gem, certainly a must have one. The bugs can be forgiven, because this is Dontnod's first game and later they gave us Life Is Strange, which is for me the one and only GOTY. But turning back to Remember Me it's one of the most refreshing big budget title for years, which will suck you in so much that you won't want to make the acts you have to do, because of some heavy pre-remorse. It really worth it's full price. Dontnod deserves it.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Setting/VisualsThe game had me at cyberpunk. I am a huge fan of the genre and an even bigger fan of fully-realized world building (Fallout 3, Deus Ex etc.). So imagine my surprise when I hear of a new setting, a Neo-Paris, to explore. Each character feels unique no matter their screen time and Nilin has some cornball dialogue but overall feels like a solid character and is torn between being a rebellious memory hunter and the conflict in the story ("This red-riding-hood has a basket full of kickass!" per example of bad writing).The textures and visuals are beautiful and the neon is well-balanced with the trashy dim lighting for a cyberpunk vision. Seriously, when you first start each level take a minute to just swing the camera around and view everything. It's all designed with love and the little touches make everything truly come alive. Consider the mass produced Valet androids that are running around holding grocery bags, walking dogs, playing piano. It's amazing and I will definitely "remember" that ;)GameplayIt's an old school beat-em-up with some HD visual packaging. Your only incentive to unlock and experiment with new combos in the branching combo system is achievements and dispatching enemies quicker but once you find 2-3 combos that work you won't deviate from them; it's just too taxing to keep opening the menu to try new things. There are a decent amount of enemy types and some engagements are multiple types at a time which keeps things fresh. Platforming is light and engaging but tends to drag on. However, it only seems that way in hindsight perhaps because the environment and atmospheric splendor is so engaging.Gotta split this up to take an average because the visuals and world building left such an impact on meSetting/Visuals9/10Gameplay6/10Overall7.5/10  Would play again

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Remember Me is a uniqe attempt of a beginner studio at making a clever story about time travel. Since it's 2016 now, we have  Life Is Strange - so go play that first, and then play Remeber me as a "back to basics" vesrion. Many concepts and even gameplay elements have a similar feel to them, but this one also offers combo-based combat (which is very well-made for busy people who cannot remeber a combo since they play on a weekly basis).The story is comparable to a book, but the experience is a game-exclusive one: you could never just watch it on a screen or just read it from paper. You have to DO it yourself. Basically, 10/10 for effort and ideas, 8/10 for execution. Shouldn't be played as anything other than a storytelling experience, since that's what it is (although battle mechanics are quite nice).

Here's why I'd recommend this game:I would start with a good story.There's a backstory on how it all started, how the city was created etc. Okay, it's pretty linear but still it could be a great movie or so and that's what I love with games (just forget CoD things...).Then, graphics and backgrounds. Because every "new" games after 2004 need to be good looking and SUPER realistic and stuff like that (I hate it but it must be said). Remember Me is one of those futuristic games that makes you dream about the real life because of the background, wich is Paris (Neo-Paris), a real place. There's a lot of thing happening when you play, a lot of little details like people talking behind a window, robot playing piano, someone shouting at you from a balcony... And the devs want you to discover those little things by making you looking for "bonuses", that's pretty cool, actually!Well, I will end the evaluation by saying Remember Me is a good game that you can't really describe or argue on. It depends what you want when you play and this game could possibly give you that. ^^End of transmission!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												9/10This game follows a story that is at times deeply angers you and at others, fills you with sorrow but at all times, is quite intense. The depiction of an Orwellian world in the future is terrific, as are the powers that be and every other person who is surviving in the regime of Memorize. Each chapter's story is very well crafted around the checkpoint based gameplay and even though the story is totally linear, it's a journey you don't want to miss and must finish. This is one those games in which you're living a part of the protagonist's life as in a novel or movie. The best parts of the game are when you get to remix memories. Although it would have been interesting if I could create armies or create total anarchy by remixing anyone's memories I chose, the developers chose not to trivialize memory remixing by limiting it to only some select people and moments in the story. Those parts draw parallels to Inception, to say the least. The action is the only part of the game that can get a little repetitive and monotonous, but not if you keep changing the combo moves to suit every battle sequence, which is something I learned. The very fact that the combos could be modified as and when the player chooses was a fantastic idea. A very beautiful game with an intense plot.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												It is a cyberpunk tale of a dystopia where people can trade, steal, implant and delete memories. The game feels very linear and there are some camera issues, but the gameplay is sound, the memory tampering mechanics are great (though there are only 4 of these "remixes" in the game) and the combat system requires the player to think a little which is not a bad thing. It plays like "Tomb raider" meets "Deus Ex: human revolution", but it's lacking in environmental interaction, which doesn't alleviate the feeling of being on rails.Who is this game for? Mainly for science-fiction fans. Some of the dialogues could have been better, and there are a few questions left unanswered at the end of the story, but the plot would make a better movie than 90% of the current holywood blockbusters.And if you're french or would like to see a vision of Paris in the future, it's the perfect game. The art is beautiful, even stunning, and the atmosphere at some moment is enthralling. The cutscenes blend seamlessly in the game, and make the cinematics all the more engaging.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Roughly 20+ hours, medium setting and 90% - finished.Really good about 8 out of 10 impo... A very strong story with some very original mechanics specifically woven with the concept of the game's story which is completely original to my knowledge. Musically charming, fantastic artwork and quality conceptualisation with a very believeable background running up and side offering of readables building it's universe. Unlike a lot of modernized futuristic games, it does bear it's own unique identity that is very appealing about it and makes you stop and look if you're into Sci Fi and games that offer something more than point click (bang) shoot em ups. But it only falls short of the open world side that obviously allows titles like Deus Ex to triumph due to it's designing, but you can still miss in game upgrades and artsy things by not going down dead end corridors or rushing through, which at no point are you really forced to, (I'll certainly be replaying sections).It incorporates fighting that is very similar to the Batman series and boss fights, with some exceptional fighting extras that are very fun and interesting to decipher including a design it yourself fight move User Interface. You have climbing that is very much similar to the Assassins creed series, puzzles reminiscent of both the previous titles mentioned but delivered wholly & uniquely enough to stand on it's own merit. You do have an environment with a set path and story to go through, you can't unless just for admiring purposes stand on one spot or go down every alley way or on every rooftop like Deus ex for example, it's a 3rd person view and if the second title is bold enough to be first person and then third person for fight sequences (or optional) it will save itself and make it with all the previous title's exceptionaly strong ingredients probably one of the best anticipated future titles due as a contender, it has so much of a world to offer it's designated format unfortunately cuts it short and limits it's immersive appreciability making it underrated and not fully able to deliver every nook and cranny of excellence it truly is, - thank you it was awesome!-Industrialism (Thiervery TuT) UK

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Remember Me is one of those titles I would never have gotten around to play if it wasn't for a grand sale.If I had to give it a score I would rate it 7/10Pros:+ Strong female lead with a great character development+ Great character development for other characters despite the short time you act around and with them+ Easy to master combat+ Great story+ Some nice plot twists here and there+ Beautiful enviroment+ Good voice acting+ A nice feeling of progression (new combos, unlocks and different "Mini games" that come along when you progress)+ Lots of different gameplay (Again, lots of "mini games")+ Tons of checkpoints+ Super useful collectables+ Combat craftingCons:- Super linear- Easy to master combat- No options to change outcome and story of the game- Only one ending- Not nearly enough time spent with other characters at all- Repititive combat- Took me 12 hours to finish (2.25 euros pr. hour if full price was paid)- A few easily forgetable characters (because they didn't get enough time to develop and be a part of the story)- A ton of checkpoints- Bad camera angles at times (Annoyed me at max 3-4 times)The list of cons might sound large, but the biggest and almost three only flaws for me would be how linear it is, no choises and the lack of "socialising" with other characters to devolop their storyI would recommend this for anyone who likes an excellent story, a beautiful enviroment and a great main character and can you live with no choises and just give in to a linear story and gameplay this is definetly something for you.If you do though want a massive amount of great combat, you should probably skip this one.If you still wanna try it while being a little sceptical, get it on a sale, but the game is definetly worth it for its story.NOTE: Play on the hardest diffculty, the normal and easy are both super easy, escpecially with the amount of checkpoints in the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												If you were entranced by Mirror's Edge's futuristic setting and enjoyed the chain attack mechanics of Batman, you're going to really get a kick out of Mirror's Edge.  Although other games have done each of its mechanics better, Remember Me's concept and setting are unique and enthralling enough to overcome what might have otherwise been a mediocre game. The game offers mouse control, but it's flawed; aggressive mouse acceleration and a small, artificial dead zone (re: controller centric design) make managing the camera awkward.  The worst technical sin, however, is that the gameplay and visuals are obstructed by the very narrow FOV.  Even on a 30" LCD panel, I constantly felt cramped.  This has the effect of magnifiying the control issues by demanding that they constantly move the camera around.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Very pretty but clunky brawler with some really interesting story ideas.--------+ Great setting.+ Interesting and smart story.+ Cool character designs.+ Good graphics.+ Memory remixes.+/- Hidden collectables.- Clunky, basic combat.- Annoying combat camera.- Linear, predetermined platforming.- Feels like it drags on a little bit.----Remember Me is a game full of interesting ideas, some of which work and some of which unfortunately do not.The story is both interesting, and does that thing all good science fiction does by feeling like a relevant reflection upon the difficulties in our lives. I feel like it would have benefitted more from really focusing on that aspect rather than proceeding as it did, however.The combat gameplay is akin to that seen in the Arkham Batman games, except without the countering or dynamism. It includes a system of designing your own combos that manages to feel very limiting as opposed to the freedom an idea like that should give. The combat camera is also less than helpful, often causing enemies to begin their attacks from off screen which obscures the visual warning. One aspect I did like however was the special "Pressen" attacks you could use. After charging a gauge in combat you can opt to unleash one of several special attacks for a variety of devastating effects.The environmental traversal gameplay is a case of follow the clearly marked climbing path with literal flashing arrows telling you where to go and being unable to deviate in any way. Cinematically this is okay - watching someone climb is more interesting than running down a long corridor I suppose - but it would be nice to be able to actually explore the world a bit more or for there to be some kind of a challenge involved. The gorgeous landscape absolutely begs for it.Overall, Remember Me is worth playing for it's excellent sci-fi memory dystopia world and for it's memorable "memory remix" segments. It has some good cinematic set pieces and graphically looks great but don't expect to be impressed by the combat or climbing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												PC Specs (If you care):~Alienware 15 R2 LaptopIntel Core i7 6700HQ CPU @ 2.6 ghz Turbo Boosted at 3.5 ghz, 4 Cores, 8 Logical Processors8gbs RAMNvidia Geforce GTX 970MWindows 10 Home~    Remember Me is a game that takes place in a 2080's, futuristic Paris. It is a story-driven game made by DONTNOD Entertainment (Life is Strange). It has beautiful graphics and a great storyline keeping you on the edge of your seat wanting to play more and more. It is split up into 8 episodes that take place in different areas around Paris and normally introduce new enemies changing the rules of the game.~Pros:    -Great Graphics    -Awesome Storyline    -Multiple Gameplay Mechanics    -Constant Changing of Mechanics    -No Bugs/GlitchesCons:    -Repetitive Combat    -Rage Inducing~Gameplay:     The gameplay in this game consists of making your own combos and using them to your advantage. Before or during a fight you can go into the combo lab and change your combos to appeal to the enemies your fighting. Combos are used with X and Y (Example: X, Y, Y, X, Y) and there are 4 different combo slots and combo moves to implement. You can outfit your combos with a Damage Multiplier, Health Regenerator, Cooldown Regenerator, or Loop.          Aside from the combat there is Parkour. The parkour in this game is very straightforward, you cannot pick your path. The game is set on one path the entire time that you have to follow, no branching out on another for a different outcome in the end. While doing parkour there is an orange arrow that follows you around and tells you where to go, making the game annoying because it's always telling you where to go.7.5/10 I would recommend this game to you and all of your friends.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												A visit to Neo-Paris 2084 itself is worth playing this game. It has good action and puzzles, great storytelling, and an absolutely amazing setting. The environment and the methods that require use of the remixer glove to navigate make me think that this is what Hydrophobia Prophecy, a different game from a defunct indie developer, should have been.'Remember Me' takes place in a beautiful futuristic city, with a little cyberpunk slum thrown into the mix. You play as Nilin, a wicked-awesome memory hunter that starts off with her memory being wiped, and goes on an adventure to get her memories back and take down a corrupt system. To help along theway, she has a glove that does everything from opening doors and moving objects (similar to Kate's keytool in Hydrophobia), to taking down enemies like a cannon, and ultimately steal/remix memories.The climbing and navigating challenges were fun, and there's also a very unique puzzle system, which exists in this game here; remixing memories at major points in the game were pieces of art themselves! However, these were used rarely (only on key characters), but I suppose the writers wanted to emphasize that this was a power not to be abused by the heroine. Still, I wouldn't have minded if they added one or two more events along the way.The story is interesting and tight, avoiding inconsequential side-quests that don't contribute to anything, and instead opt to let you see the amazing sights around you while pursuing your objectives.There are several QTEs, which I found a little annoying, but the combo system they have is entertaining and allows for interesting combat. I would really like to see whatever improvements DONTNOD might have planned if we're ever fortunate enough to see Neo-Paris again.Meanwhile, go and play this game!

												I think this is a cool game that’s maybe a little underrated. I enjoyed the gameplay quite a bit, I liked the combat I thought it was nice and flashy and flowed nicely and I also enjoyed the fun but simplistic and easy platforming. I think this game has an interesting concept and setting and a decent story overall. I also liked the soundtrack quite a bit too. I wasn’t a big fan of the actual storytelling, most of the objectives and missions in the game were not very interesting and they didn’t really add to the story or make the story anything more than a decent one when it could have been much better. The missions themselves just felt like small steps to achieve a larger goal and it didn’t really have any impact and sadly that’s what you end up doing for the majority of the game. I thought the characters were pretty average, I wasn’t really emotionally invested with the protagonist but I was mildly curious on how her story will pan out. The game is very linear in design which I didn’t mind at all because I think they use it to their advantage to make the gameplay focused. It could have been great but for what it is and for what it does well it is a very good game.  7/10 (Good)

Posted: November 25, 2014
												Graphics are fantastic. The sounds and game environment are rich and immersive. Gameplay is good, especially with a controller. I used an XBox 360 controller. Was a bit difficult with keyboard/mouse, probably because I don't play many linear games like this one. In fact the one complaint I'd have about this game is how linear it is. You go from one fight sequence to the next. Your character Nillin spends most of the game on route to an objective. There are lots of corridors to navigate and every 3rd or so hallway opens out into an arena/courtyard of some type where something always falls down behind you to trap you until you defeat several foes, after which some forward obstruction miraculously falls away allowing you to continue.This formula gets a bit tiring and persists throughout the game but when it was done, I realized that I had enjoyed it far more than I thought I would. So given that this is not my favorite genre, I have to give it a thumbs up. In fact I didn't even come to the store page to write a review but to see if there was DLC so that I could continue.
