content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Setting/VisualsThe game had me at cyberpunk. I am a huge fan of the genre and an even bigger fan of fully-realized world building (Fallout 3, Deus Ex etc.). So imagine my surprise when I hear of a new setting, a Neo-Paris, to explore. Each character feels unique no matter their screen time and Nilin has some cornball dialogue but overall feels like a solid character and is torn between being a rebellious memory hunter and the conflict in the story ("This red-riding-hood has a basket full of kickass!" per example of bad writing).The textures and visuals are beautiful and the neon is well-balanced with the trashy dim lighting for a cyberpunk vision. Seriously, when you first start each level take a minute to just swing the camera around and view everything. It's all designed with love and the little touches make everything truly come alive. Consider the mass produced Valet androids that are running around holding grocery bags, walking dogs, playing piano. It's amazing and I will definitely "remember" that ;)GameplayIt's an old school beat-em-up with some HD visual packaging. Your only incentive to unlock and experiment with new combos in the branching combo system is achievements and dispatching enemies quicker but once you find 2-3 combos that work you won't deviate from them; it's just too taxing to keep opening the menu to try new things. There are a decent amount of enemy types and some engagements are multiple types at a time which keeps things fresh. Platforming is light and engaging but tends to drag on. However, it only seems that way in hindsight perhaps because the environment and atmospheric splendor is so engaging.Gotta split this up to take an average because the visuals and world building left such an impact on meSetting/Visuals9/10Gameplay6/10Overall7.5/10  Would play again

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Remember Me is an action game set in a futuristic (and somewhat dystopian) Paris, with an interesting story centered around memories becoming the new form of social interaction. In the world of Remember Me, a company called Memorize has managed to digitize memories, allowing people to share them, which, theoretically, could lead to a more peaceful society. However, this is not the case, as society is still divided between the powerful and the poor.In the game, you play as Nilin, member of an activist group known as "Errorists", who seek to stop Memorize, as they consider the digitalization of memories has led to a worse society. At the start of the game, you've been captured and have no memory of who you are, and it's only through the help of a mysterious ally, known as Edge, that you manage to escape. From there, you start searching for clues of your past, while helping the Errorist cause. The story is pretty good, with some interesting twists here and there, which is why I won't write more about it, as there's risks of spoilers. There's also lots of collectibles scattered around that add a bit of background information regarding the story of the game.As far as gameplay goes, well, it's somewhat simple. The game is combat oriented, which means you'll be fighting plenty of enemies; it offers a certain degree of customization through the "Combo Lab", which allows you to modify four different combos with different skills that increase their power, or grant you things like regeneration; not to mention the different special abilities you'll unlock as you progress. There'll also be sections of the game in which you'll be exploring around (although this is a bit of an overstatement, as the game is pretty linear), climbing buildings and solving puzzles. I'd say both gameplay aspects are well balanced in their execution.The environments are gorgeous, with a great level of detail; it is unfortunate, however, that there isn't much exploration, since, as I mentioned above, the game is pretty linear. Even then, I've got to appreciate the amount of detail they gave to Neo-Paris, you can even find some recognizable Paris landmarks, like the Eiffel Tower, although you'll never access them. The soundtrack is excellent; I really loved the music, and it really set the tone of Neo-Paris being a sort of futuristic re-imagining of a classical Paris, if that sentence makes any amount of sense.Still, I must say this game had flaws, and, even though it's a good game, it could have been much, much more. The linearity isn't the biggest of its problems, as the game is somewhat buggy, which can cause you some trouble. Another problem I found is that the combo system isn't really effective against large groups, since the combo only works on a single enemy at a time; there's no freeflow between enemies (besides a special ability), meaning that your combo will be broken when switching enemies, not to mention that if an enemy hits you, the combo breaks as well. The camera can be a bit problematic as well, especially since there's no "lock-on" when fighting; sometimes you'll end up in a corner unable to see some enemies. Another big problem (at least for me) was the unskippable cutscenes. Now, I understand making them unskippable for the first time; but when I keep dying to the same enemy and being forced to watch the same (lenghty) cutscene over and over again, it gets annoying; however, I must say that I'm glad that, at least, they made it possible to pause the cutscenes, as that's another thing that annoys me, "unpausable" cutscenes.Well, despite its problems, I think Remember Me is a pretty solid and fun game, so I can recommend it.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Remember Me is a uniqe attempt of a beginner studio at making a clever story about time travel. Since it's 2016 now, we have  Life Is Strange - so go play that first, and then play Remeber me as a "back to basics" vesrion. Many concepts and even gameplay elements have a similar feel to them, but this one also offers combo-based combat (which is very well-made for busy people who cannot remeber a combo since they play on a weekly basis).The story is comparable to a book, but the experience is a game-exclusive one: you could never just watch it on a screen or just read it from paper. You have to DO it yourself. Basically, 10/10 for effort and ideas, 8/10 for execution. Shouldn't be played as anything other than a storytelling experience, since that's what it is (although battle mechanics are quite nice).

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Remember me is a pretty great game:If you like art involving futurisic urban areas. This game has some great built environments from the flooded paris slums to the misture of "classical" and futuristic architecture in the city centre. The soundtrack is also very good and plays well with the art style. If you like casual arcade-style gameplay. This game isn't a super-hardcore one. The main controls involve chaining combos in order to attack enemies in different ways. I think the way that the game uses this is pretty well executed, especially in that you can customize how the combos are built [each combo 'hit' can be an attack, a heal, a power regen, etc.].If you like trans-humanism. The story revolves around implants that let people share their memories, and the inevitable moral complexities that arise in this. The technologies involved allow overlays on the screen, a la "augmented reality", which is how most of the UI is played, but it brings up an interesting point: The technologies involved are what lets characters fight each other. If you didn't have one of these implants, would you still be affected? If you like to think about these kinds of things, I'm sure the game will give you lots to work on.Overall, just a very good action game.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												This game, along with the Batman: Arkham series has re-invigorated my interest in action games. Firstly, let's talk about the game quality of Remember Me. Aside from Nilin when she's talking (lips don't always match her speech), and another when one of the enemy bosses temporarily left the area I could fight in, I noticed no errors. There wasn't any empty map areas, there wasn't any low quality texturing anywhere, and everything I interacted in worked flawlessly.However, there are a few problems. First is the fighting 'combo' system. While it's good and innovative, the lack of time between enemies (especially when they're rather aggressive and you're trying to fight back 5 of them) means anything other than the first combo of 3 punches is likely to get unused, especially late game. The powers available are a mix of good and meh. Sensen Fury is a good power but unfortunately useless for the majority of late-game due, normally due to the ammount of enemies you're facing meaning one is always ready to strike you and break the combo, and the fact there's more useful powers available. Some of the enemies are hard to defeat too. The large robot, for example, unleashes a shockwave power you have trouble escaping from, and then has a vulnerability which, if you get caught in the shockwave, cannot get to in-time to attack the robot. Some boss battles are hard to do due to lack of guidance (e.g. you need to do power X and then Y). The upgrading system is good - it's not as you level up, it's as you find parts of the upgrades... which is a good ploy for you to search the maps for upgrades. However, you occasionally have a hard time finding said upgrades. While I'm talking about collecting, might I add how hard it is to find all the Scarabmechs. The story, however, is the crown jewel of Remember Me. Thoughtful, logical, and if you have a good mind, you can link up so much of the story elements as you play you can link things together, often before the story reveals them to you.Lastly, the soundtrack. From stirring pieces to real gritty, electronically re-cut "you're about to poop yourself" moments, I have never heard such a good soundtrack. There's parts where it sounds normal, and others where it's been remixed in such a way it blends in with the whole experience.Remember Me is - without a doubt - one of the best games I've ever played. It joins my pedestals of other excellent games, like No One Lives Forever 2, Railroad Tycoon 2 and Sid Meier's Civ series from 4 onwards.

												I've bought this game when it was on sale, personally I wouldn't pay the full price, the full price it's a bit expensive for me, but I am very glad that I got the game. I love a good strong women lead character and Nilin is amazing, the voice acting is great, the figure the movements of her are great. I am just in love with her, and it's always good to play with a female character (feminist alert). The storyline is simple, you are a person who lost her memory, can't remember a thing, you're trying to remember and everything just completes itself really. The world is set in Neo-Paris, very futuristic, but it has a dystopic vibe to it. You're feeling like you're in a chaotic world, which I liked. There are some puzzle bits in the game, they are enjoyable, complicated enough but not too hard too. There is a hospital bit which is very enjoyable, I never played a part like that and I absolutely loved it. My computer isn't great so I played in low-medium graphics but they were good, so I believe that if you have a good computer you'll enjoy the graphics very much. I think the soundtrack is very good, especially the main theme is amazing. First of all, I am not an action gamer, This paragraph is about the action of it. I am more like a simulator, casual, indie game kinda person. Euro Truck Simulator, Cities Skyline, Don't Starve kinda... I am not good with FPS games, or any kinda action games really. But I could manage the mechanics easily, they were easy enough for me to be comfortable with, I could arrange MY OWN COMBOS. Which was amazing, I litereally made combos focusing on gaining health and used them like 100 times in every single fight. The boss fights were bit tricky for me, I played each fight like 6 times but I did it, eventually. And I played on easy mode so if you're good with them you can always play them in harder modes, make more complicated combos, make more fancy moves idk. You can configure them according your skills, it's up to you! So I think that's good. Some people may think that the mechanics are not good enough but they were good enough for me. I'd give a solid 7/10 to it. And btw I am a keyboard/mouse player so if you're using controllers, it has to be much more better.Overeall I'd give a solid 8.5/10 to the game.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Remember me is one of those games that you should play, but would annoy you at times during play.I recommand the game, but I have my issues with it.Pros:The game has an interesting plot, and the setting (the city of neo paris) is extremely well thought of. The fights are fun and fluid. The remembrance mechanisms are well thought of and enjoyful.The game also brings forth important questions, and (unlike some games) is not really afraid to try and answer.Cons:However - the linearity of the game is obscene. Doors lock down and open to lead you in a straight line through the city.Your character can jump from ledge to ledge (assasins creed style / farcor style), but can't go over a 2 inch cardboard box on the floor. The fights are a bit repetitive and there's not enough remembrance mini games (perhaps 5 throughout the game).I also have an issue with the fact that it's a future paris with robots and virtual reality, but there's only one gun in the entire city (and someone shoots himself with it). Only bots and gunships seem to have real guns.And lastly - at some point during the endgame, you get attacked by a horde which shouldn't really be there, isn't a real obstacle at that point (you finished a far harder horde 5 minutes before), and has no real point. That single fight scene really damaged the immersive experience that was a big part of the end game.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												A fantastic, and incredibly underrated game. I remember looking forward to this before it released, but then being discouraged by all of the negative and mixed reviews. So unfortunately, it took me a while before I finally bought and played the game. Moral of the story: don't listen to the critics! The developers have created a beautifully imaginative future, complete with stunning graphics and a captivating soundtrack. Gameplay mostly consists of platforming through the streets of Neo Paris, battling enemies with an innovative combat system, solving puzzles and generally interacting the environment with augmented reality tools. All together, it's an incredible concept, and a joy to play. It feels a bit like the mechanics of a Prince of Persia game, with graphics reminiscent of Mirror's Edge and a setting and story not unlike Tomb Raider: Angel of Darkness. This reviewer finds that to be an excellent combination.As much as I enjoyed the game, I now have a better understanding of why some players may have become easily frustrated with the combat system. I did not understand it for the first hour or two of gameplay, and I very nearly quit the game for good. But after the first memory remix - easily the best concept in this game and sadly underused - I was determined to keep playing to continue unraveling the story. With a bit more patience, I came to love the combat system and realize just how fun it could be (and, mind you, I'm not usually a melee/combat sort of gamer). By the end of the game, I had pretty much mastered the combat system, and found myself customizing combos on the fly depending on the battle at hand. So if you're struggling with the combat, be patient with it and don't let it ruin the whole game for you.I do however have one major gripe with the game, which is how excessively linear it is. You're in this incredibly vibrant world, and 9 out of 10 of doors are closed off to you, steering you down a narrow path to your objectives. And it's a one way street - almost every single time you go through a door, it closes behind you, sealing off any secrets or powerups you may have missed. The game uses a unique premise for offering powerups - you catch a glimpse of where they are and have to remember the location before you pass it by, which is trickier than it seems. And as far as the platforming goes, you're limited to climbing on very specific objects the whole way through, indicated in orange. With how vast the world is, I suppose this makes sense or otherwise you could be climbing in every direction. As much as I want another massive open world game, (what can I say, I've been spoiled by Assassin's Creed) I understand that that may have been beyond the scope of the debut of this IP. At the same time, considering the immense amount of time that must have gone into this meticulously designed city, it's a shame to breeze through it all in a matter of hours. Me personally, I finished the game in about 10 hours. I look forward to replaying it again at some point- it's definitely worth it. Remember Me does allow you to reload chapters so you can find powerups and secrets that you missed the first time through - and I may end up doing just that.One thing that I must applaud this game for, in stark contrast to many other games out there, is how it continues to innovate and evolve over the course of its 8 chapters. New enemies appear and old ones grow stronger, you gain new abilities and unlock more powerful combos, and the tools and puzzles grow ever more complex, right up to the end. Boss battles and memory remix scenes add an extra challenge that serves to end each chapter with a satisfying resolution. The memory remix dynamic is very original, I really don't think I've ever seen anything like it. It's just a shame it only appears four times in the game. The soundtrack is also fantastic, built from notes of somewhat familiar classical Parisian orchestra, remixed with what I can only describe as futuristic and chaotic glitches - in a way that feels natural. The music also is well-weaved into the combat. I was reading that the composer wanted the soundtrack to feel as chaotic as the world of Remember Me itself - a world where memories can change or be erased at a whim. I think they did an excellent job in that endeavour.I was also very impressed with the story, which kept me hooked, surprised, and emotionally engaged all the way to the end. This is a story that does not feel too far off from our own world, and closes with a powerful and appropriate ending. I found the final boss battle to be a bit strange, and perhaps a bit too easy, and at the same time I enjoyed it thoroughly.Personally, I think this game is worthy of a strong 9/10, however if I end up posting this review online anywhere I'd bump that to 10/10 to even the scales a bit. I honestly believe that the game is short on flaws, and the only ones that do exist are most likely a reflection of what particular gamers like and don't like in their games. I see many bad reviews from those who tried an hour or two of the combat and gave up, just like I almost did, and missed out on the rest of a great game. And I acknowledge that not every game has to be open world, and that I'm a bit spoiled to expect that. So even my biggest complaint does not really stick. So now that I've completed the game, perhaps this review finds me doing a bit of my own memory editing, to put some of my own minor gripes into perspective. This is a fantastic game, one of my top favorites of the year and one I won't soon forget. Highly recommended. 9/10

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Remember Me takes and sets In a futuristic Neo-Paris In 2084. You are Nilin, the memory hunter. Everyone, the government Is afraid of you-- until you are wiped of everything you knew. As Nilin fights to remember and retrieve her memories, she relearns her combat, reminisces with her friends and makes It back to the top of the food chain, as the master memory hunter. You discover that Memorize, the game's tyrant Is running everyone's memories down, turning them Into creatures, mutants, monsters. Find a way to stop them In this action-packed, Immersive combat, and fast paced, heart racing Cyberpunk world.     I was quite Impressed when I first played the game. The first hour was very Immersive, with the world taking you Into it. I am a huge fan of Cyberpunk and this game captures It all. I knew this would be the game for me once I saw It. The combat Is fluid and varies depending on you. You can change up the combos with different types of effects, such like regenerating health, adding onto combos, amplifying damage, or even prolonging your combos! The story Is great, 'nuff said.     10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Overall Score: 7/10My advice: If you enjoy a game for its story and can overlook repetitive fighting, pick it up on sale.Genre: Action Adventure, PlatformerAlright, let me get all of the puns out of the way first. While Remember Me does have some memorable moments, a sound track that won't get out of your head, and an environment that sticks out in your memory, the combat was utterly forgettable and left me nostalgic for other fighting games. *Ahem*With that out of the way, you play as Nilan, a girl who's forcably lost memory of who she is, but is saved from having her mind completely wiped thanks to a mysterious figure named Edge. He belongs to a group called the Errorists, people determined to cleanse a society that uses memories as a form of tradable commodity, and experiments with memory itself to produce a stable, segregated city. As you venture through the game, you come across the nightmares of such experimentation and ultimately begin to take part in the most fun aspect of the game --remixing memories of certain people you come across and changing elements of what they recall to get them to join your cause.It's really hard for me to figure out the kind of game Remember Me is trying to be. It gives this rich and interesting world but confines you to a linear path. It develops a wealth of interesting characters, but such flat development that at times feels forced. It tries to put together a unique combat system, but with such simple mechanics, most matches devolve into acrobatic button mashing. The coolest element of the game, memory remixing, doesn't happen nearly enough for it to hold the game up on its own. The worst part about it is a certain amount of pretentiousness with how it knows it's an artsy, smart game. Still, the music and atmosphere are astounding, and I have to give credit where it's due --it's a damn good story. Just wish the other elements had more thought put into them.

												Pros:+Deeply moving storyline with excellent character development, rare for a game to have a female protaganist that I actually care for.+The best level design I have seen since Half Life 2. Around every corner is something that makes me say "wow".+Beatiful visuals (after an essential tweak) and a vivid, colourful world.+Dynamic and fluid combat mechanics with a number of strategies available.+Parkour is smooth and simple to master.+Memory Remixing is a stroke of genius, and can be an emotional rollercoaster.+Fabulous music that adds well to the immersion.Cons:-Levels can sometimes feel a little too linear, despite the game being non open-world by design.-Memory Remixing, probably the game's strongest point, is simply not explored enough.-Very little replayability aside from completing all collectibles.-Rather duff final boss, despite the superb and moving build-up.-Combat and some other elements are poorly explained with no tutorial leaving the player to figure out what to do.-Default game has a stupid film-grain effect which ruins the visuals, but this is easily removed (PM me).-Camera difficult to control, FOV can be restrictive and is not editable.-Although it functions well, parkour remains fairly simplistic and could have been expanded.Overall I really enjoyed the game experience, despite the cons. This game recieves 9/10 bacons.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												3rd person, action, fighting game with platforming. You play as Nilin, a memory hunter as they call her in 2084 Neo-Paris. Story is very good in my opinion, that unravels as you go on, with unexpected twists, wont spoil.Game has some great environments, but most of the levels are linear, small, closed off sections. Tutorial system that will help you learn the basics, that I found very useful. There is simple platforming element, in form of climbing walls, ledges, pipes, etc., most of them are highlighted and you can't climb any wall you want. Basically you run couple dozen meters, climb a bit, then get cutscene and begin fighting some enemies. There is no particular order, but it's not as bad as it sounds.Fighting involves punch and kick combos that you combine in "Combo maker", dodging is also vital, to avoid damage. You unlock more and more moves as you play the game, there are different kinds of combat moves, some add more damage, some restore your health, some reduce cooldowns on more powerful moves, etc.Movement animations are good, didn't notice anything troubling, voice acting is also on level and is enjoyable, cutscenes are nicely done and angled. You will notice some low resolution textures here and there, but generally it's good looking game.There are a lot of collectibles in form of Data packages in game, that award you health upgrades, as well as some art and 3D models in Extras. Personally I very much liked how game levels looked, as well as Nilin and her small little bosom. I recommend this, have fun!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2013
												If you like thought-provoking science-fiction this game is for you. With a great story and breathtaking world design – Neo-Paris looks spectacular! – Remember Me is a very memorable experience. Especially because of the four memory remix sequences scattered throughout the game, where you must change the memories of certain people in the story. While four does not sound much, the sequences gives one very much food for thought – I think even more so because of this low number. This memorable experience is coupled with an interesting combat mechanic, somewhat reminiscent of Arkham Asylum/City, where you can and in some situations must mix the effects of your combos in mid-combat. Furthermore, Remember Me has an atypical and very striking musical score, which supports the game’s themes very well. The only thing somewhat lacking in this game is its very limited platform sections, due to its level design, which almost entirely does not give any room for any exploration deviating from the main path. However, this problem with the weak platforming sections is somewhat alleviated by the beautiful and atmospheric world design, and the combat sections throughout the game. If you want to support an original IP, with a great and thought provoking sci-fi story, excellent world design, outstanding musical score and superb gameplay (thanks to its combat and memory remix sequences) only marred by a weak platforming mechanic, then Remember Me is for you.Info: I played Remember Me with a controller, with French audio/English subtitles language settings, and on the highest difficulty.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Remember Me is an action game set in a futuristic (and somewhat dystopian) Paris, with an interesting story centered around memories becoming the new form of social interaction. In the world of Remember Me, a company called Memorize has managed to digitize memories, allowing people to share them, which, theoretically, could lead to a more peaceful society. However, this is not the case, as society is still divided between the powerful and the poor.In the game, you play as Nilin, member of an activist group known as "Errorists", who seek to stop Memorize, as they consider the digitalization of memories has led to a worse society. At the start of the game, you've been captured and have no memory of who you are, and it's only through the help of a mysterious ally, known as Edge, that you manage to escape. From there, you start searching for clues of your past, while helping the Errorist cause. The story is pretty good, with some interesting twists here and there, which is why I won't write more about it, as there's risks of spoilers. There's also lots of collectibles scattered around that add a bit of background information regarding the story of the game.As far as gameplay goes, well, it's somewhat simple. The game is combat oriented, which means you'll be fighting plenty of enemies; it offers a certain degree of customization through the "Combo Lab", which allows you to modify four different combos with different skills that increase their power, or grant you things like regeneration; not to mention the different special abilities you'll unlock as you progress. There'll also be sections of the game in which you'll be exploring around (although this is a bit of an overstatement, as the game is pretty linear), climbing buildings and solving puzzles. I'd say both gameplay aspects are well balanced in their execution.The environments are gorgeous, with a great level of detail; it is unfortunate, however, that there isn't much exploration, since, as I mentioned above, the game is pretty linear. Even then, I've got to appreciate the amount of detail they gave to Neo-Paris, you can even find some recognizable Paris landmarks, like the Eiffel Tower, although you'll never access them. The soundtrack is excellent; I really loved the music, and it really set the tone of Neo-Paris being a sort of futuristic re-imagining of a classical Paris, if that sentence makes any amount of sense.Still, I must say this game had flaws, and, even though it's a good game, it could have been much, much more. The linearity isn't the biggest of its problems, as the game is somewhat buggy, which can cause you some trouble. Another problem I found is that the combo system isn't really effective against large groups, since the combo only works on a single enemy at a time; there's no freeflow between enemies (besides a special ability), meaning that your combo will be broken when switching enemies, not to mention that if an enemy hits you, the combo breaks as well. The camera can be a bit problematic as well, especially since there's no "lock-on" when fighting; sometimes you'll end up in a corner unable to see some enemies. Another big problem (at least for me) was the unskippable cutscenes. Now, I understand making them unskippable for the first time; but when I keep dying to the same enemy and being forced to watch the same (lenghty) cutscene over and over again, it gets annoying; however, I must say that I'm glad that, at least, they made it possible to pause the cutscenes, as that's another thing that annoys me, "unpausable" cutscenes.Well, despite its problems, I think Remember Me is a pretty solid and fun game, so I can recommend it.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Remember me is a pretty great game:If you like art involving futurisic urban areas. This game has some great built environments from the flooded paris slums to the misture of "classical" and futuristic architecture in the city centre. The soundtrack is also very good and plays well with the art style. If you like casual arcade-style gameplay. This game isn't a super-hardcore one. The main controls involve chaining combos in order to attack enemies in different ways. I think the way that the game uses this is pretty well executed, especially in that you can customize how the combos are built [each combo 'hit' can be an attack, a heal, a power regen, etc.].If you like trans-humanism. The story revolves around implants that let people share their memories, and the inevitable moral complexities that arise in this. The technologies involved allow overlays on the screen, a la "augmented reality", which is how most of the UI is played, but it brings up an interesting point: The technologies involved are what lets characters fight each other. If you didn't have one of these implants, would you still be affected? If you like to think about these kinds of things, I'm sure the game will give you lots to work on.Overall, just a very good action game.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												This game was pretty amazing from the beginning. It takes an hour or two to figure out the system and basic layout of the game, but its a shame this game didnt take off and sell a million copies. The story is a big driving force in the game and the main heroine is likable and charismatic. The battle scenes are top notch and the overall gameplay is similar to Enslaved with a mix of combos.The combo system is unique and original, and its actually beneficial to learn each one (there are 4).Each combo can be tailored to your liking and play-style and they become a major necessity. There are very unique moments in the game where you have to alter people's memories to achieve a particular reaction from them, and this is one of the greatest aspects of the game. The combat remains interesting throughout the game and the story remains clear and there isnt a moment where it becomes boggled in confusion or side-tracking. Over all, I really enjoyed the game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys a medium length game with tons of action, some character development, and combo and quick time event sequences.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												Remember Me has been given a raw deal. True the combat gets repetitive at times, the memory remixing is perhaps under utilised and the game is very much "on rails" (to be fair they never said that it was going to be anything but and I'm a strong believer that sometimes it's nice to just be led through a story - Last of Us is pretty much linear for example). However the world the game inhabits is extremely rich, the sounds and graphics add to that. The story is fascinating and gets pretty far out towards the end. It's what I lazily deem "high concept" with some of the ideas - something that rarely goes down well with the mainstream reviewers. It's a real shame though. Unlike some of the other "better" games out there, I sat down and played Remember Me over the course of a week or so and finished it. It drew me in, told a great story and offered some extremely memorable moments....and a fantastic sound track.Sometimes we really should just celebrate art.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												It's not often I get choked up by a game, but this one nailed it.  Absolutely beautiful story, beautiful setting and some interesting mechanics.   As the game starts, Nillin is completely amnesiac, so you know just as much of what's going on as she does.  It's hard to write a really positive review about this game when its strongest point is the story, so I'll move on to some of the other aspects of it.Aside from the story, one of Remember Me's best points is the combat.  It's a free-flow, combo-based system reminiscent of the Arkham series, except that YOU choose the effect that the attacks have.  Extra damage, health regeneration, and a reduction in your special ability's recharge time (more on that in a minute) are the three choices you have, but in addition to that you can use a chain effect which mimics and magnifies the effect of your previous hit in the combo.  These can be changed mid-combat via a menu in the pause screen, to suit your needs in a particular fight. Nillin gets a TON of character development, but most of the other characters you meet don't really get explored.  Early on you meet someone who is supposedly one of your closest friends, but he never appears again after Episode 3.  This is, understandably, Nillin's story, but the game could have done with a bit more character development.  My only other big complaint is with the climbing.  When you're first introduced to the climbing mechanics, it feels like a tutorial, but the training wheels never really come off.  It has the look of Assassin's Creed-style parkour, but it feels very restrictive and not at all fluid, in several cases almost to the point of immersion-breaking.  I think that if DONTNOD had put some more time into the climbing mechanics, it could have been better than it is.All in all, weighing the bad with the good, I'd give this an 8.5/10.  The few issues I have with the gameplay aren't enough to really take away from the phenomenal story that this game has to offer, and I can honestly say that I was at the edge of my seat for a fair portion of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												I got this game in a sale and it was worth every penny.  Even at full price this game is worth it compared to many AAA titles that are $60 plus.It has an engaging story with likeable characters that you grow to care about and the voice acting is spot on.  The atmosphere in the game is really well done.  The game is set in a futuristic Paris where people's memories are a hot commodity and an evil company misuses their power to create a gap between rich and poor.  Overall I liked the story and it last about 7 hours (my gameplay time is higher because I alt+tabbed for a while). This game would have benefited from being more open as the futuristic paris looked great, I just wish I could have explored it more.I've seen a lot of people complain about the fighting mechanics, I suspect this is because they couldn't get to grips with them because I really liked them.  You can devise your own combos adding in different elements to change what your attacks do.  You also get a select few "special" attacks which do different kinds of damage.  At the end of the story with them all unlocked you can really pull off some cool combos and techniques.Unfortunately the game has little replayability value given its very linear story, save for going back to collect things you missed.  Unless you're an achievement hunter though, I doubt you will do this.  There's not much to be gained.Pros:- Strong female lead- Well written and voice acted- Interesting and at times philosophical story- Intriguing combat and cool combos- Great atmosphere and good graphicsCons:- Quite short (7hrs, max)- Not much replayability

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												9/10This game follows a story that is at times deeply angers you and at others, fills you with sorrow but at all times, is quite intense. The depiction of an Orwellian world in the future is terrific, as are the powers that be and every other person who is surviving in the regime of Memorize. Each chapter's story is very well crafted around the checkpoint based gameplay and even though the story is totally linear, it's a journey you don't want to miss and must finish. This is one those games in which you're living a part of the protagonist's life as in a novel or movie. The best parts of the game are when you get to remix memories. Although it would have been interesting if I could create armies or create total anarchy by remixing anyone's memories I chose, the developers chose not to trivialize memory remixing by limiting it to only some select people and moments in the story. Those parts draw parallels to Inception, to say the least. The action is the only part of the game that can get a little repetitive and monotonous, but not if you keep changing the combo moves to suit every battle sequence, which is something I learned. The very fact that the combos could be modified as and when the player chooses was a fantastic idea. A very beautiful game with an intense plot.

												Pros: Impressive graphics, adheres to all stereotypical Cyberpunk tropes, runs wild with the post-armageddon corporate dictatorship theme, criticisms of human nature, intriguing storyline, snarky dialogue at times, vague contemporary references, semi-customizable combo sequences, entertaining boss fights, hidden objects to find, (overall) user-friendly tutorial, and especially MEMORY REMIXING. what's more godlike than being able to tamper with others' history to your own advantage?Cons: Extremely linear gameplay, NO exploration or environmental interaction at all, everything is guided, fights are very repetitive, unskippable cutscenes, almost no replayability, hard-to-control UI, selectively displayed HUD, repetitive dialogue in bossfights, no death penalties, occasional lag spikes, short gameplay (only 8 hours and you're done), lots of keyboard smashing, poor PC porting/optimizations, only 4 memory remixing scenes, and way too much parkour.Graphics: 9/10Story: 6/10Gameplay: 5/10Quality: 4/10Overall: 6/10Get it while it's on 80% discount!

												Graphics are fantastic. The sounds and game environment are rich and immersive. Gameplay is good, especially with a controller. I used an XBox 360 controller. Was a bit difficult with keyboard/mouse, probably because I don't play many linear games like this one. In fact the one complaint I'd have about this game is how linear it is. You go from one fight sequence to the next. Your character Nillin spends most of the game on route to an objective. There are lots of corridors to navigate and every 3rd or so hallway opens out into an arena/courtyard of some type where something always falls down behind you to trap you until you defeat several foes, after which some forward obstruction miraculously falls away allowing you to continue.This formula gets a bit tiring and persists throughout the game but when it was done, I realized that I had enjoyed it far more than I thought I would. So given that this is not my favorite genre, I have to give it a thumbs up. In fact I didn't even come to the store page to write a review but to see if there was DLC so that I could continue.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												This game, along with the Batman: Arkham series has re-invigorated my interest in action games. Firstly, let's talk about the game quality of Remember Me. Aside from Nilin when she's talking (lips don't always match her speech), and another when one of the enemy bosses temporarily left the area I could fight in, I noticed no errors. There wasn't any empty map areas, there wasn't any low quality texturing anywhere, and everything I interacted in worked flawlessly.However, there are a few problems. First is the fighting 'combo' system. While it's good and innovative, the lack of time between enemies (especially when they're rather aggressive and you're trying to fight back 5 of them) means anything other than the first combo of 3 punches is likely to get unused, especially late game. The powers available are a mix of good and meh. Sensen Fury is a good power but unfortunately useless for the majority of late-game due, normally due to the ammount of enemies you're facing meaning one is always ready to strike you and break the combo, and the fact there's more useful powers available. Some of the enemies are hard to defeat too. The large robot, for example, unleashes a shockwave power you have trouble escaping from, and then has a vulnerability which, if you get caught in the shockwave, cannot get to in-time to attack the robot. Some boss battles are hard to do due to lack of guidance (e.g. you need to do power X and then Y). The upgrading system is good - it's not as you level up, it's as you find parts of the upgrades... which is a good ploy for you to search the maps for upgrades. However, you occasionally have a hard time finding said upgrades. While I'm talking about collecting, might I add how hard it is to find all the Scarabmechs. The story, however, is the crown jewel of Remember Me. Thoughtful, logical, and if you have a good mind, you can link up so much of the story elements as you play you can link things together, often before the story reveals them to you.Lastly, the soundtrack. From stirring pieces to real gritty, electronically re-cut "you're about to poop yourself" moments, I have never heard such a good soundtrack. There's parts where it sounds normal, and others where it's been remixed in such a way it blends in with the whole experience.Remember Me is - without a doubt - one of the best games I've ever played. It joins my pedestals of other excellent games, like No One Lives Forever 2, Railroad Tycoon 2 and Sid Meier's Civ series from 4 onwards.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I've bought this game when it was on sale, personally I wouldn't pay the full price, the full price it's a bit expensive for me, but I am very glad that I got the game. I love a good strong women lead character and Nilin is amazing, the voice acting is great, the figure the movements of her are great. I am just in love with her, and it's always good to play with a female character (feminist alert). The storyline is simple, you are a person who lost her memory, can't remember a thing, you're trying to remember and everything just completes itself really. The world is set in Neo-Paris, very futuristic, but it has a dystopic vibe to it. You're feeling like you're in a chaotic world, which I liked. There are some puzzle bits in the game, they are enjoyable, complicated enough but not too hard too. There is a hospital bit which is very enjoyable, I never played a part like that and I absolutely loved it. My computer isn't great so I played in low-medium graphics but they were good, so I believe that if you have a good computer you'll enjoy the graphics very much. I think the soundtrack is very good, especially the main theme is amazing. First of all, I am not an action gamer, This paragraph is about the action of it. I am more like a simulator, casual, indie game kinda person. Euro Truck Simulator, Cities Skyline, Don't Starve kinda... I am not good with FPS games, or any kinda action games really. But I could manage the mechanics easily, they were easy enough for me to be comfortable with, I could arrange MY OWN COMBOS. Which was amazing, I litereally made combos focusing on gaining health and used them like 100 times in every single fight. The boss fights were bit tricky for me, I played each fight like 6 times but I did it, eventually. And I played on easy mode so if you're good with them you can always play them in harder modes, make more complicated combos, make more fancy moves idk. You can configure them according your skills, it's up to you! So I think that's good. Some people may think that the mechanics are not good enough but they were good enough for me. I'd give a solid 7/10 to it. And btw I am a keyboard/mouse player so if you're using controllers, it has to be much more better.Overeall I'd give a solid 8.5/10 to the game.

It takes awhile to get adjusted to the combat system because they don't explain it clear enough(I had to look up a guide to figure it out, but once you understand it, it's semi-smooth sailing from there). The levels are very linear, but they're very detailed and they look great. Some of the fights are very difficult no matter the difficulty level,  and the boss fights are a little longer than they need to be.Long story short, it's decent at best. If you're patient and look past the repetitive combat and super linear levels, it's decent. I'd suggest buying it on sale, though. The original retail price is not worth the headache. Buy it on sale, it's worth the sale price. I do recommend it, though, there's little plot twists that make the story worth your while.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Make no mistake, this game is a delight to look at.  The city of Neo-Paris has been rendered in a way that lends considerable creedence to their vision of the near future.  Lots of little details are included that make the environments believable.That task was probably made easier by the highly-linear nature of the game.  On the one hand, you can lament how incredible this would have been to have the same level of detail in an open-world, but the linear nature allows for a high degree of polish on the path you follow through the world and story.The story's competent, and told well enough, though I don't think I was invested as the story expected me to be.  Nilin comes across as introspective, yet more than a little cold.There's a neat memory-remix mechanic introduced early on and it felt like I was nearly halfway through the game before it came up again, though there are several instances before all's said and done.  I'll echo the sentiments of several other reviewers who wished there was "more of that, please."The combat itself is also competent, in the Arkham vein but with a dodge rather than a counter, with a few nice touches to spice things up.  Depending on your play style, it's easy for some fights to overstay their welcome, but once you become comfortable with the combo system and fight mechanics (or like me learn to stop hoarding your special attacks) you can dispatch with most battles relatively expeditiously.  It's got QTE's, and while the button you press corresponds to the action executed it still feels more like a match game than a act of skill, but they're used to cap off certain battles rather than as a routine mechanic.I played with a mouse and keyboard and occasionally felt like the game wanted me to be using a controller, but it was never a serious handicap.  (Here's a tip if you're using a mouse and kb like me - the "Rewind" motion is like drawing a counter-clockwise circle with your mouse.  Perhaps I missed a critical instruction, but that really threw me off during the first memory remix.)I think there was something else I wanted to say, but I just...can't remember.

Posted: August 14, 2014
												Remember Me takes and sets In a futuristic Neo-Paris In 2084. You are Nilin, the memory hunter. Everyone, the government Is afraid of you-- until you are wiped of everything you knew. As Nilin fights to remember and retrieve her memories, she relearns her combat, reminisces with her friends and makes It back to the top of the food chain, as the master memory hunter. You discover that Memorize, the game's tyrant Is running everyone's memories down, turning them Into creatures, mutants, monsters. Find a way to stop them In this action-packed, Immersive combat, and fast paced, heart racing Cyberpunk world.     I was quite Impressed when I first played the game. The first hour was very Immersive, with the world taking you Into it. I am a huge fan of Cyberpunk and this game captures It all. I knew this would be the game for me once I saw It. The combat Is fluid and varies depending on you. You can change up the combos with different types of effects, such like regenerating health, adding onto combos, amplifying damage, or even prolonging your combos! The story Is great, 'nuff said.     10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												A fantastic, and incredibly underrated game. I remember looking forward to this before it released, but then being discouraged by all of the negative and mixed reviews. So unfortunately, it took me a while before I finally bought and played the game. Moral of the story: don't listen to the critics! The developers have created a beautifully imaginative future, complete with stunning graphics and a captivating soundtrack. Gameplay mostly consists of platforming through the streets of Neo Paris, battling enemies with an innovative combat system, solving puzzles and generally interacting the environment with augmented reality tools. All together, it's an incredible concept, and a joy to play. It feels a bit like the mechanics of a Prince of Persia game, with graphics reminiscent of Mirror's Edge and a setting and story not unlike Tomb Raider: Angel of Darkness. This reviewer finds that to be an excellent combination.As much as I enjoyed the game, I now have a better understanding of why some players may have become easily frustrated with the combat system. I did not understand it for the first hour or two of gameplay, and I very nearly quit the game for good. But after the first memory remix - easily the best concept in this game and sadly underused - I was determined to keep playing to continue unraveling the story. With a bit more patience, I came to love the combat system and realize just how fun it could be (and, mind you, I'm not usually a melee/combat sort of gamer). By the end of the game, I had pretty much mastered the combat system, and found myself customizing combos on the fly depending on the battle at hand. So if you're struggling with the combat, be patient with it and don't let it ruin the whole game for you.I do however have one major gripe with the game, which is how excessively linear it is. You're in this incredibly vibrant world, and 9 out of 10 of doors are closed off to you, steering you down a narrow path to your objectives. And it's a one way street - almost every single time you go through a door, it closes behind you, sealing off any secrets or powerups you may have missed. The game uses a unique premise for offering powerups - you catch a glimpse of where they are and have to remember the location before you pass it by, which is trickier than it seems. And as far as the platforming goes, you're limited to climbing on very specific objects the whole way through, indicated in orange. With how vast the world is, I suppose this makes sense or otherwise you could be climbing in every direction. As much as I want another massive open world game, (what can I say, I've been spoiled by Assassin's Creed) I understand that that may have been beyond the scope of the debut of this IP. At the same time, considering the immense amount of time that must have gone into this meticulously designed city, it's a shame to breeze through it all in a matter of hours. Me personally, I finished the game in about 10 hours. I look forward to replaying it again at some point- it's definitely worth it. Remember Me does allow you to reload chapters so you can find powerups and secrets that you missed the first time through - and I may end up doing just that.One thing that I must applaud this game for, in stark contrast to many other games out there, is how it continues to innovate and evolve over the course of its 8 chapters. New enemies appear and old ones grow stronger, you gain new abilities and unlock more powerful combos, and the tools and puzzles grow ever more complex, right up to the end. Boss battles and memory remix scenes add an extra challenge that serves to end each chapter with a satisfying resolution. The memory remix dynamic is very original, I really don't think I've ever seen anything like it. It's just a shame it only appears four times in the game. The soundtrack is also fantastic, built from notes of somewhat familiar classical Parisian orchestra, remixed with what I can only describe as futuristic and chaotic glitches - in a way that feels natural. The music also is well-weaved into the combat. I was reading that the composer wanted the soundtrack to feel as chaotic as the world of Remember Me itself - a world where memories can change or be erased at a whim. I think they did an excellent job in that endeavour.I was also very impressed with the story, which kept me hooked, surprised, and emotionally engaged all the way to the end. This is a story that does not feel too far off from our own world, and closes with a powerful and appropriate ending. I found the final boss battle to be a bit strange, and perhaps a bit too easy, and at the same time I enjoyed it thoroughly.Personally, I think this game is worthy of a strong 9/10, however if I end up posting this review online anywhere I'd bump that to 10/10 to even the scales a bit. I honestly believe that the game is short on flaws, and the only ones that do exist are most likely a reflection of what particular gamers like and don't like in their games. I see many bad reviews from those who tried an hour or two of the combat and gave up, just like I almost did, and missed out on the rest of a great game. And I acknowledge that not every game has to be open world, and that I'm a bit spoiled to expect that. So even my biggest complaint does not really stick. So now that I've completed the game, perhaps this review finds me doing a bit of my own memory editing, to put some of my own minor gripes into perspective. This is a fantastic game, one of my top favorites of the year and one I won't soon forget. Highly recommended. 9/10

Posted: December 4, 2015
												The game is well made. I did not have probelms with the combat system. It felt very Arkham-ish, but less forgiving. The FoV is really small (even for 3rd-preson), but the FoV can be increase via Flawless Widescreen (flawless widescreen . org) with ease. The audio is very good all around. The soundtrack is well done and works wonderful in creating a believeable atmosphere as and combat sounds bring home the hand2hand combat. The english voice actors are nice and especially the protagonist has a good VA.* I think it is equal to FemShep. It is easy to change to multiple spoken language. Ital, engl. franc. and germany as well as other are choosable via ingame menu. The menu language is always your install-language, which you can change from the steam library.The game and story is linear, but this is no problem. It is a good, well designed journey with some interessting ethnical question for the player. You can't change the outcome, but you can ask yourself how you feel. The story and actions aren't as black&white as in many other videogame storys.Performance: Mostly very well, but some frame rate dips, when the game was loading. I only had one camera bug, where i had to restart from a checkpoint ~3 minutes away.As a resume: well designed world and charakters, animation are good and voice actiong excellent*. The combat system is okay, but the default camera makes it more awful, than it is. The game could have a bit more enemies. Performance is good and i had only one bug in 10hrs gameplay.Nilin/10*english is not my native language

												Awesome game! Just finished it and really enjoyed the whole experience. It's been a long time since I've actually played through a single player game, often times I get bored of the combat and stop playing. Remember Me really had a interesting story line that grabbed my attention and engaged me from the very start. Aside from the the story the different characters and enemies grab you based on their uniqueness. I really enjoyed the combat system, and I reccommend playing the game on the hardest difficulty. It was fairly straightforward but kept me entertained the whole time. You don't waste time fighting through hordes of endless enemies, to win you must strategize how to beat the current battle. If you find yourself breezing through every battle then you should make sure you are on the hardest difficulty. When I lost a battle it's because my strategy was off, not my mechanics. The settings and the music really led to a great environment to play in. I really recommend playing this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Remember me can be best described as an hybrid between a fighting  and a platformer game. Developed by Dontnod Entertainment, it takes place in a futuristic version of Paris (known in the setting as Neo-Paris) from year 2084, where a new technology, the Sensen, has allowed men and women to influence their own memories and store or even cancel them as they please. The protagonist, Nilin, is a memory hunter, a woman capable of interfering with the others' minds easily. The beginning of the game shows Nilin suffering a severe case of amnesia and finding herself into a terrorist group seeking to destroy the Sensen and free Neo-Paris. The story of Remember Me therefore revolves around Nilin trying to recover her memories back.The main beef of the game is about navigating the various levels and survive the fistfights you are thrown in at times. Nilin is very agile and can get a good grip on many edges and jump between them easily: that's where the platform elements come from. There are always little visual clues on screen to tell you exactly where you should jump or hang on next. As the game progresses you'll be asked to overcome some small stealth sequences (there are sometimes patrolling droids that will instantly kill you if you get in their range) and puzzles: as Nilin acquires more skills you'll have to use them all to carve your path. Remember Me also features a really large collection of collectables items, which unlock concept art and 3D models in the main menu: some of them are hinted at during gameplay with some sort of maps, but the majority of them are incredibly well hidden and my require more walkthroughs to find.The combat in Remember Me is your usual fighting game fare: you must achieve combos on enemies for massive damage while being careful to dodge the attacks thrown at you. The game features an unique combo system: the in-game menu allows you to actually build your own combos, deciding how many hits each must contain and what each hit may actually do (while some hits just damage the enemies, others may heal you, for instance). Nilin can also use special attacks and temporary boost called Sensens: they are available after achieving enough focus and have different results (using some of them become mandatory to overcome some bosses). Many enemies in Remember Me can't be really taken on using sheer force and require special attacks or strategies first. While this element always keeps on your toes, on later level such enemies become more and more common and therefore more and more frustrating (they are also always escorted by lesser mooks who will disrupt your combos, making your job even harder). The game also features four boss battles, each with its unique flavor and rather challenging too.An unique gameplay element from Remember me are the Memory Remix sequences, which are more akin to an adventure game: you are presented with someone's else memory and have to change some particular details in order to change the ultimate outcome and proceed. Such sequences aren't that hard to overcome and are mostly trial and error in nature.It's also worth mentioning that the presentation in this game is absolutely gorgeous: the landscapes are very faithful to Paris itself and well crafted; the enemies design is original and extremely detailed; the soundtracks makes a great job at enhancing the overall mood.It can be argued that Remember Me tries to throw in many elements from different genres and doesn't manage to produce something truly unique for itself and the story could had been made far better for the truly incredible setting, but I still find this game to be severely underrated and I'd advise pretty much everyone to try it out regardless

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												This is a truly beautiful game. The city is as majestic as the top sci-fi cities of Deus Ex and Dreamfall, but on top of that you also get some truly gorgeous menus and cyberspace-y cut scenes. Unfortunately the interactive part of the game is not so great. The biggest problem for me is that it is a linear console shooter, except instead of shooting you are punching and kicking. Most of the game you just walk through a corridor till you get to an open space where you need to kill some baddies, then repeat. That said, just like Mass Effect 2 and 3, which had equally mindless button-spamming combat, the game is saved by its mythology. Remember Me is set in a fabulous cyberpunk world and features one of the best female protagonists since Faith from Mirror's Edge. The story is a bit chaotic, but there is plenty of melodrama to keep you entertained. The graphics and music are exceptional. I wish they had ditched the combat in favor of stealth and parkour, but hey, you can't have it all. It's not Deus Ex, it's not Mirror's Edge, but if you liked either of those you will probably like this. It's a great ride.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Remember Me is interesting, because it has a lot of things in it that should make a game bad, but it's crafted so well together, that it makes it great.As a game it's not the best at what it does, it doesn't have anything new that I haven't seen before, and some parts of it feels more like an interactive movie, rather than a game. But as a whole it's an extremely well assembled fun game, with a great story.THE COMBAT is quite simple, therefore it's really repetitive, but not easy, and it's spectacular. The fighting parts are sectioned out very well, they short enough that won't become a grind, but challenging enough to be satisfying to beat them.THE BACKGROUND WORLD is very well built, it's multifarious, it's interesting, it's important to the story but not forced upon the player. It's introduced over the right amount of time that you feel that you saw everything, but it's not overwhelming.THE STORY is very well written, and in my opinion is without clichés. The story telling is executed flawlessly. This is a very strong aspect of the game, so the replay value on this one is low.OVERALL there are games where you feel you should have had more fun playing them, but this is the exact opposite. If you break down the game to its different parts, like combat, exploring, the remix levels or boss fights, not one of them could stand up on their own, but as they tied together with the story it creates a quite unique and really fun game. It's simple but challenging, it's short enough to be interesting all the way, but long enough to be satisfying when you finish it.

It's not as great as other games, but it's like a slightly more combo based version of Arkham, I suppose. - The art is great. Not the graphics, the actual art style and world created. The game feels linear, but still feels as if it's massiveCons - Feels a bit empty - besides coming across some people early on, the only people you get to see are either those relevant to the plot, random robots continuously doing tasks or those whose faces you'll be punching in.- The camera can bug out sometimes, and hoooly♥♥♥♥♥♥is it annoying. Doesn't matter what it is, if you're in battle and you just took damage because the camera ♥♥♥♥ed up, or if there's a view and you can't see it because the camera is fixed for some reason. It's all pretty much annoying. This is the major gripe I had with this game, if this got fixed, then I genuinely think most of my frustration with this game would be fixed with it.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												It is a cyberpunk tale of a dystopia where people can trade, steal, implant and delete memories. The game feels very linear and there are some camera issues, but the gameplay is sound, the memory tampering mechanics are great (though there are only 4 of these "remixes" in the game) and the combat system requires the player to think a little which is not a bad thing. It plays like "Tomb raider" meets "Deus Ex: human revolution", but it's lacking in environmental interaction, which doesn't alleviate the feeling of being on rails.Who is this game for? Mainly for science-fiction fans. Some of the dialogues could have been better, and there are a few questions left unanswered at the end of the story, but the plot would make a better movie than 90% of the current holywood blockbusters.And if you're french or would like to see a vision of Paris in the future, it's the perfect game. The art is beautiful, even stunning, and the atmosphere at some moment is enthralling. The cutscenes blend seamlessly in the game, and make the cinematics all the more engaging.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Tl;DR - beautiful game with medicore gameplay, very good setting and a pretty good story. Overall 7/10.Those are the 4 elements I'll be writing about. Let's start with what this game surprised me the most - the visuals. Art direction in this game is astounding. The colors, light, graffities, models, all tell the story of the Neo-Paris. Despite the fact that the assets themselves are not really good quality (not bad either though, especially considering it was a previous gen game) the game still has a lot of wow moments and it's all thanks to a very smart and beautiful usage of the listed elements.That, alongside multiple dialogues, fluff announcments audible in the background and notes found as collectibles creates a very detailed, believable and scary vision of the late 21st century. However, the world was not used correctly, in my opinion. Personally I wish we'd spend more time on the streets of the city, watching how the people live, what problems they have etc. We've only heared or read about the world (which again, was done very well), but almost never saw it, spending most of the time in some labs/prisons etc. That was one of my big issues with the game, lots of wasted potential there.Learning about the world and seeing the beautiful environment was what kept me playing most of the time, as the rest was rather obvious from the start.Story set in this world is not as good as it could be. It's full of cliche solutions, lacks any choice and sometimes it's hard to emphasise with main character's actions. The story itself lacked something more inventive, unusual.Finaly - gameplay. Most of the game is split into 2 sections - Batman-esque fights and exploration. Both aspects are done poorly. There's very few enemies and most of them are more or less the same. Instead of introducing new, more complicated opponents, at later stages the game becomes more difficult just by throwing in more enemies. It clearly tried to go full Batman, but failed (also, it gets boring at this point too). Combo system associated with the combat also felt lackluster. By the time I've finished the game I had 3 full combos and 1 unfinished one. Instead of building a database of my combos that I could use as I see fit, depending on the situation, in the end I just built 2 universal ones that I used all the time, depending if I needed utility (most of the time) or damage (rather rarely). Exploration left some to be desired as well - you can only climb the very specific objects that the game allows you to, so pretty much if you can climb something - you should. It was done similarly to Enslaved: Odyssey to the west, where you just moved the stick, pressed the jump button and watch your character perform animations. No room to fail, no challange, no threat. Just a filler.The unique gameplay element, that also has to be mentioned, was the memory rewriting. Sounds very cool and about half of the time it was, but the other half, at least to me, felt rather unlogical. The solution to the problem felt random, which led to continous rewinding just to try another, sensless combination. Additionaly it lacked a functionality that would improve the system in general (not the unlogical sections, though) - ability to quickly jump to identified memory glitches and changing them much faster that way.In the end I still recommend this game, a bit. It's not great, but it's good. It has increadibly well done elements, some pretty good ones and if you don't bounce off the medicore ones, you might still have fun.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Remember Me is one of those titles I would never have gotten around to play if it wasn't for a grand sale.If I had to give it a score I would rate it 7/10Pros:+ Strong female lead with a great character development+ Great character development for other characters despite the short time you act around and with them+ Easy to master combat+ Great story+ Some nice plot twists here and there+ Beautiful enviroment+ Good voice acting+ A nice feeling of progression (new combos, unlocks and different "Mini games" that come along when you progress)+ Lots of different gameplay (Again, lots of "mini games")+ Tons of checkpoints+ Super useful collectables+ Combat craftingCons:- Super linear- Easy to master combat- No options to change outcome and story of the game- Only one ending- Not nearly enough time spent with other characters at all- Repititive combat- Took me 12 hours to finish (2.25 euros pr. hour if full price was paid)- A few easily forgetable characters (because they didn't get enough time to develop and be a part of the story)- A ton of checkpoints- Bad camera angles at times (Annoyed me at max 3-4 times)The list of cons might sound large, but the biggest and almost three only flaws for me would be how linear it is, no choises and the lack of "socialising" with other characters to devolop their storyI would recommend this for anyone who likes an excellent story, a beautiful enviroment and a great main character and can you live with no choises and just give in to a linear story and gameplay this is definetly something for you.If you do though want a massive amount of great combat, you should probably skip this one.If you still wanna try it while being a little sceptical, get it on a sale, but the game is definetly worth it for its story.NOTE: Play on the hardest diffculty, the normal and easy are both super easy, escpecially with the amount of checkpoints in the game.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This game is better played with a gamepad.     For any cyberpunk lover "Remember Me" is a must-play. A world it presents is vivid, full of life, believable. The game is linear, but many locations I've been to looked amazing. Every object and entity looked like it was carefully incorporated into this world. The futuristic Neo-Paris could serve as an excellent background for an RPG (ah, if only). Though the story goes really fast,  I coldn't help but stop for a minute or two and take a good look around at the commoners, the dutiful valets, the beautiful landscape.     The combat system is really simple once you get the hang of it. The customizeable combos you create are quite simple to remember but not that easy to do once you're in a crowd of enemies. I sometimes cursed the lack of lock-on but overall it's not needed. Some fights take much longer than they should because attacking multiple enemies at a time is quite difficult. Performing a healing combo correctly can be vital at times, due to Elite Enforcers' ability to constantly damage you when they're hit, for example.     As for protagonist, our little slim smartie Nilin, she really kicks♥♥♥♥♥ She mistakenly seems fragile, but she can climb walls like Lara Croft and fight like Neo. A really adorable girl that has the ability to remix and steal memories. That's what the story revolves around: the great invention of the 21st century which can help rebuilding the world ravaged by war, or destroy it.The design, the animations and the visuals of the game are really amazing, but it could be so much better. A few levels are utterly boring (almost the entire Bastille). There are only four "memory remixing" episodes. And last is the combat which is spectacular but a little flawed, sometimes repetitive and tedious (I, for instance, have died about 20 times when fighting two Leapers that stole Trace's memory).If you're still in doubt, get this game on sale. It is really worth playing once. If you cope with the few flaws it has, it presents a great movie-like experience.
