number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												This is a great game, one of my favourites. From slums to the heights of society, every level is exquisite and well designed. In the nicer parts of Neo-Paris the enviroment has this polished clean look that adds to juxtaposition of the ramshackled slums and sewers. Overall graphically it is a very stunning game.Now gameplay. There are few things to talk about here. One is combat mechanics. This game takes an interesting approach to melee Arkham like combat. It has customizable combos, which can be accessed and altered at any time through the Combos Lab. This is a really cool idea and I love the game even more for it. The second thing to talk about is the memory remix sections. This is where you remix a person's memory so that their perception of reality is shifted in one case turning enemy into ally. This is a part of the story and part of the more morally questionable aspect of the protagonist Nilin.Lastly the story. I have to say I loved it. But then again I'm a huge fan of the Cyberpunk genre. If you don't like cyberpunk stories than you probably wont like this one. I thought is was a brilliant depication of a dystopian society masquerading as a utopia. Last advise: If you plan to get this game use a gamepad. With these melee combo centred games I prefer to use a gamepad. It just feels better.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Remember Me is pretty good. Not great, but definitely not bad. Decent characters, interesting premise, okay story, reasonably fun gameplay. The combat is not as good as say Batman: Arkham Asylum or City, but it's still pretty decent. I'd say it's a game worth getting, especially on sale.You'll want to play this with a game-pad, though. Keyboard/mouse control is rather weak and not fun. Beware: it may be very unstable on less than optimal systems. I could not play the game beyond the intro without a crash-to-desktop on my old machine (a 2011 2.4GHz i7 MacBookPro 8GB RAM w/ 1GB Radeon 6770M and Win7 64), even with all of the settings set to their lowest. The game runs like a dream on my current machine (a current MSi Dominator Pro 24GB RAM with GeForce GTX 880M). Basically, you're definitely going to want to have power to run the game smoothly and stably.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												*Small spoilers alert*, you will see some things I say right in the start of the game so it won't ruin anything really.This game was really fun for me. Putting it on memory hunter difficulty (hard) will make the game actually a challenge, you die in a few hit from even the standard mobs. The mobs in the game have interesting abilitys that make them unique and can make you have to rethink how you must take them down and who you must take down first. I love how you can change your combos and what each hit does at any point in the game. The fact that your character has no memories and you are just asked to believe the past other people say you have makes the game interesting it leaves you open for some plot twists and leaves you trying to find your characters backstory to fill the gaps that even your character is trying to fill.9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												So I just be the game today and here's my take on it. Hope it helps for those considering to purchase this game!Story, Art, and Characters - Simply amazing. Everything in the game has great textures and you can see the developers really focused on making sure the graphics in every scene were done carefully to ensure a complete masterpiece. The story is very interesting, as you watch the main character struggle to find her identity, struggle with morality, and the broken society. If you like philosophy, you may enjoy this game as it quotes some historic guruus.  The cutscenes are unskippable which makes replaying some levels a pain. Also this is a straightforward, single-result (meaning no different endings) type of game with no side-missions or quests.Gameplay - Standard fights are repetitive, relying on the same button combos and limited variety of enemies. Often, I had to put the game down because the gameplay was too repetitive and not fun. However, the "remixing of memories" a feature used 4-5 times in the entire game was a blast and I wish the developers made that more prominent in this game. In addition, it took me about 8 hours of gameplay to beat it once through without searching for hidden items or achievement hunt.If you like a game that has beautiful art that takes "Inception" to a completely different level and that you don't mind putting down due to repetitive fighting and moving around the areas, then this should definately be a consideration to add to your library:

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I found Remember Me to be a pretty epic game, although I thought it a bit flawed.The world the game takes place is amazing, graphics are great (apart from some plastic lookig skin textures on the main character) and the developers seem to have spent much care in making a detailed world. The lore and backstory to the world is a different take on usual dystopian scenarios. On the downstide for the most part the game couldnt' get much more linear if it was a simple straight line. And I'm sure "invisible walls" went out many years ago. Or are at least better disguised. But those are minor points.Soundtrack is also awesome and fits in well with the game.Story was great. (I'm sensing a theme here :) )The combo system was an interesting mechanic I haven't really come across in other games. It worked well, albeit somewhat frustrating. In fact, my main peeve with this game was the damn combat as it's mostly nothing but mashing the left or right mouse button (with a few special actions thown in as you progress). Another letdown was the combat scenarious as time and time again they would trigger some foes to fight, then as soon as you dusted them off, they doubled the number of foes and had you go at it again. I didn't enjoy that, although the difficulty wasn't that hard really.Gameplay wise was nothing special - lots of platforming and with some akward camera angles at times. It worked though.As I said, the story was interesting, thought provoking, and easily capabably of producing a range of emotions. Without going into specifics for spoilers, I found one aspect of the remix sequences to be somewhat disurbing, doubly so when it was revisted towards the end of the game. However, as with so many things, it's down to personal experiances - and if you've never experianced this thing in RL, then you probably won't be fazed by this sequence in game either.So I found the combat flawed and the story disturbing at times but everything else top notch and well worth the play time.Hopefully some other games in this world will be released in the future.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
 -So empty , But yet so true , The past is a foreign country- Well , when we talk about a game developed by a french studio then 2 things will blow your mind: the Story & the artwork.this game isn't mirror's edge or another hack N slash game , its way different.Its basically a new mix of martial art game , where you can mix combos of your own , light puzzle in an extraordinary style and light platforming.basically:-Graphics in this game is very decent and fair enough , artwork , textures , colors choice is really really awesome.-Gameplay is way too smooth , no glitches or bugs , yet you can also create your own combos , gives you more freedom in combat.-Soundtrack in this game is pretty much awesome , vocal choices are neat ( wish i know who was it ) , the timeing of soundtracks are well set aswell.-Story , is mind blowing , not only full of plot twists but you will get to make the plot twists yourself !!.-Artwork in this game is really going to catch your eyes , basically each scene of this game is full of artwork that you will have to pause and enjoy it for a few secs.-Puzzle in this game was sort of too easy and weak , but its pretty much a whole new style of puzzle , no need to spolier you will know as soon as you play it.generally its a must to play game , it was so enjoyable and it leaves you wishing for a Remember Me 2. <-episode 2. i recommend this game in full price or sale price , tottaly worth it either ways. 9.5/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												It is rare when I am stunned by a game.  Often games can be entertaining, visually stunning or encompase complex story arcs, but rarely do they acheive all three.Remember Me is a beautiful game.  I lost count how many times I just sat back and looked at the environment, often getting attacked in the process.  The combat is not complex (once you get used to it) and by the end you flow around your enermy, dancing between blows like a ballet of violance.The story is imaginative, thoughtful and well written, with strong voice acting and presence.  In the end you drift past the combat, knowing that your enermy will meet their poetic demise, because all you desire is to understand the next glimpse of your fractured memory.This game is a cross between Deus Ex, Mirrors Edge and a film I used to love called Renaissance (2006 staring Daniel Craig).If I were to critic this game, and I am loathed to do so, it is a little short and I completed it in about 10 hours.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												I've just finished Remember Me and, truth be told, I have mixed feelings. Did I enjoy it? Well... yes. And no. I really can't bring myself to rate the game as a whole, so I'm just going to give it two ratings:Gameplay: 4/10Story: 8/10Let's start with pros: the story is really nice. I don't suppose it'll make you cry manly tears like Life is Strange did, but, eh, whatever - it's pretty damn solid nonetheless. At times it's touching, at times it's disturbing... and above all, it makes you think. the idea behind the game is interesting, though not really science-y. artstyle is really cool. I'm not sure why exactly, but I love the real-life overlay/HUD that Sensen provides. Voice Acting is not terrible. animations are well done. Maggie Said it First I liked the two riddles that appear in the game.And now, cons: controls are just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AWFUL at times (K+M, not sure about pad). Climbing is alright, but that telekinesis-thingy absolutely drove me nuts. Memory-mixing sequences can get under your skin, too. Remember Me's combat system heavily relies upon combos - it just seems logical that the game would allow you to continue your combo on a different opponent, no? And yet the game doesn't let you to do that, unless you jump over (not just dodge to the side) another enemy and THEN smack him/it (the same one you just jumped over, which might not be that easy, because controls can be quite wonky and you usually fight multiple opponents). It truly does amaze me. Elite Enforcers. You'll understand once you've played it. sadly, thanks to the three points above, combat felt like a chore to me. music... it is there, but it's like it wasn't. do you know that feeling when you just finished that few-minutes-long bossfight and the game crashed right before your progress saved, and thus you had to beat the boss once again? Yeah, that. I had to feel that TWICE while playing Remember Me - game just bugged and all I could do was to load the last checkpoint, beat the boss again and pray this time will be different. Happened to me on two separate occasions. a game couldn't get any more linear. gameplay gets really repetitive after a while.Do I recommend it? If you like story-driven games - yeah, sure! Remember Me is a game that is worth playing, even if only for its plot. But be warned - if it is a good gameplay you seek, you most likely will be disappointed.Remember you soon!

content:

												I heard about this game after I played Mirror's Edge. Also I read that this game has elements known from Assassin's Creed series. Screenshots and videos looked very encouragingly therefore I gave a try and bought this game when Capcom gave discount for their games. Fighting system is pretty simple but good thing is that you can mix effects for your moves and create your own combinations depending on your needs. Like in Enslaved: Odyssey to the West I like also that you earn experience for defeated enemies and you can improve your character fighting style. Unique element of this game is that Nilin can change other person's memories which totally change their point of view and personality. Story is not very original but anyway is pretty interesting and addictive. Atmosphere of this game reminds me a little Half-Life 2 (anti-utopian world based on slaving people) but Remember Me is much more colorful and polished. Overall in my opinion it is very good game and if you like action-adventure games like Batman Arkham City, Tomb Raider 2013 or Enslaved: Odyssey to the West, I highly recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												I've only played this game because it was made by Dontnod and had to try it after finishing Life is Strange. Ofc I didn't expect anything closer to that in quality but thought it worth a try. And well, yes it did. It's a good game. Not great but not bad either. It's just a good game.I recommend it but only if you like TPS hack and slash games (DMC, God of War, Darksiders etc.) and platformers (like Tomb Raider for example). Because the game is the combination of these two genres. You either playing a platformer going through Neo-Paris and its buildings or fighting the enemy. There isn't too much "downtime" in the game.The art and music are gorgeous but not everything is the outside... And here lies the problems. Mostly two big things. 1. The main "selling point" of the game, the memory remix, is limited. You will only use it _FOUR_ times in the whole game and only in scripted scenes. And it's a sequence puzzle nothing more. That's a big letdown, I was expecting something like Watch Dogs where you can interact with everyone...2. The game is incredibly linear and the combat is even more repetitive. You basically do the same thing through the whole game from the first minutes until the very last. To make it worse the combat system is broken in the sense that you can chain your abilities together in a way that you will never die... Not that it's bad but makes the whole game really really really easy (final boss fight was like 3 mins long max).The story is pretty good and that's why I kept playing. Once again it's not Life is Strange level but you can see and feel it was made by Dontnod. Can't tell anymore about it because otherwise I'd spoil it...Give it a shot, but only buy it on sale (5€ max)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												This combat system has a different approach to others with similar setup like Devil May Cry. In Remember me you don't go for the highest combat combo for an S-Rank score. The combo's are too short to make that even work. Once you complete a combo string then the counter starts anew. How combo's work in this game is too simply combine damage, cool down or health regen to it. And that shows right away how they're supposed to function in combination with the Sensen skills. You don't use the combo's to actually kill hordes of trash mobs like you would in similar games. Sure you can kill some and then overload their brain, but the majority of damage output comes from using the Sensen. So the combo's are there mainly for health regen so you can survive hordes of opponents with ease... combined with coold down reduction till your next Sensen attack is possible. This reduces battles often to tedious tests of patience where I want too attack, but have too wait for the right Sensen to come off cool down to deal with the specific opponent. On top of that the protaganist is nice and mobile as well as reactionairy in controls when dealing with many opponents at once. You can easily jump over them while maintaining the continuation of the combo. All opponents, even those invisible or off screen, have a noticable "gotham arkham"-ish indicator to show their incoming attack.This change in mindset isn't what people expect from games with this style of combat. Thus they have trouble grasping it and finding it frustrating. That is not too say there aren't frustrating moments in the game. In some boss fights the QTE's aren't always visible enough. This can result in a repeated sequence until it is noticed by the player. I had such a moment that took me almost a dozen times too repeat and had no idea why. Which brings me to the point of communication information to the player. There are moments where the game keeps repeating the fact you need to use a certain attack, but other times no information is given on what to do. Personally I didn't find this bothersome since I enjoy solving situations. On top of that I look at which mechanics are introduced and then can come to the right conclusion on how to proceed.The other part of the game relates to what you see in many action-adventure style games such as the new Tombraider reboots and Uncharted...namely the platforming and scaling walls. This works really smooth. So smooth even that I hardly feel involved most of the time. Only issue I have is that graphically the ledges aren't always clearly visible to indicate what path too take. Therefore the yellow indicators come into play in order to guide the player forward. Personally I find this at times helpfull when stuck, but other times insulting. I'd rather have seen a bit more contrast in which ledges could be used as part of figuring out the route to go.I quite enjoyed many design choices in this game, but some don't really get fleshed out fully it seems.Still it is a very enjoyable game with a cool story and some amazingly beautiful vista's. The story uses elements you'd normally see in time travel related stories. Since it now takes part in the minds of people this same element feels more at home and properly utilized. There are puzzles and lots of different things to do during a lineair progression.Definately a game worth grabbing. It isn't a top of the line game in my opinion, but for a sub-maximal game it is still a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Now, here is my problem with Remember Me, and don't expect me to say story or graphics or anything else that I can just let slide by.The gameplay is terrible. You will expect something easy to pick up like DmC's combat where you can join combos together and create new combos. Except you can't. You're stuck with using X-X-X as a combo, and quite litterally the only attack. Then you unlock X-Y-X. This type of system would work. That is if all options to throw into the combo were available at the start. They aren't, instead you're stuck with hitting the same button three times to kill someone. Or hitting X-Y-X to kill someone. Which sucks because the rest of the game I liked, except for that one combat system.

												(PC, no game controler): unless gifted, don't touch. Game for consolepros: nice enviroment, interesting sci-fi story, soundtrackcons: terrible floating camera, one button action, auto aim, low textures, "don't think, go to orange marker"The graphics in this game seem to consume a lot of resources despite low textures and overall "medium" visual quality.The camera work feels pretty vague and sometimes it gets switched to another corner in the area which is very confusing. Menu control is without any cursor and feels odd, too. Combat mainly consists of pressing one or two buttons, sometimes you have to evade. "Objectives" are no thinkers, just follow the orange marker we give you.Final conclusion: This game is not fun to play. It's more a game to be watched than a game to be played.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Let me start the review by saying something, I love this games concept. The idea of having memories be more than they are in the world we know around us is a very unique concept. I have always liked the story of the underdog fighting against corrupt corperations. But there is alot of flaws with this game. First off, it's in third person. Why? What is the point? You make a game about living through someone elses perspective and you make it so you feel distanced from the character. Not only that fact of the third person but the camera angles are very wierd. Why add ♥♥♥♥♥♥ parkour elements into this game? This is not the mirrors edge parkour its the godawful uncharted parkour. It feels out of place even in an adventure game, so why put it in a game not even related at all to parkour? It feels out of place and just breaks up the "action". The fighting in this game is so dumb you right click and left click to do unsatisfying combos that are bland at most.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												The long and short of it is that this game plays like a more linear, less interesting, less fluid Assassin's Creed. Despite picking it up on sale for 6 bucks, I still regret the purchase and the time I invested in the game.Pros:-Potentially interesting world and concept-Soundtrack is good but fairly repetitiveCons:-Every aspect of the game is ridiculously easy. Combat is a piece of cake even on the highest difficulty, and the game completely holds your hand through the parkouring elements (seriously, the whole game feels like a tutorial level).-English voice acting is pretty bad, and if you decide to use French instead with English subs, you miss out on all the side conversations/chatter that for some reason aren't subtitled.-Annoyingly buggy. Hitboxes sometimes feel way off, and on multiple occasions I had to reload the game due to falling through the world or part of the area getting stuck when I should have been able to move it with my Spammer.-Related to above: the game doesn't seem to play nice with controllers. Button prompts would show up with controller buttons half the time and keyboard buttons the other half when I was playing with a controller. Certain moves (targeted S-pressens) I found literally impossible to use with a controller during their tutorial phases and had to switch to keyboard for a short period.-The story just isn't that appealing, and the characters are very one-dimensional and not terribly believable. -The game feels riddled with terrible plot holes. For example, in the first chapter of the game you alter someone's memory to believe that their fiance was killed by the people who are targeting you, in an attempt to keep her from killing you. It works, and then... we never hear from her again. Seriously. She somehow never figures out that her fiance is actually still alive.-Very very linear. It's impossible to even backtrack through levels, with doors immediately and permanently closing behind you as you make your way through corridors. Went the right way but wanted to look for collectibles/powerups? Too bad!-The game raises interesting moral questions and the protagonist herself seemingly struggles with things she's done... and then it's all ignored as she brazenly continues on the same path without any seeming hesitation or regret aside from the interludes between chapters. It feels very unsatisfying and disconnected.-Ugly. For a fairly recent game, the look of the game is honestly abysmal save for the character models and interface. This would be forgiveable if gameplay was good, but... yeah.-The camera is pretty terrible in some parts of the game - strangely, more often in the open than in tight corridors. Not sure what's going on there.In the end I couldn't even bother to finish the game, stopping about 75% of the way through and watching the rest on youtube while I was cooking. And yeah, the ending is pretty unsatisfying too.TL;DR?Buy some of the earlier Assassin's Creed games (the most similar to this title without being bad, imo) or really any other action game out there. Unless you're scraping the bottom of the barrel, I wouldn't bother picking this up even on sale. And, not to disparage anyone's taste, but whoever is saying stuff like "great story" or "this game is like a good book" must be pulling from a pretty small sample.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Not entirely a negative review. Amazing world, beautifully designed, and lovely soundtrack. I was hyped up about this game for several reasons (female protagonist for one! As a  gamer who happens to be a girl I can't have never enough of female-centered games) and I really, really wanted to like this one, but I just...can't. -The game design is not ideal (ie some camera angles while interesting and "artsy" could hide visual clues about the path you have to follow, not to mention they may cause motion sickness esp during fights, there is almost no interaction with the environments and ZERO with NPCs, etc)-The combat system isn't that good eitherThese are just two examples of why the whole experience isn't particularly pleasurable, nor satisfying. And besides, I found it buggy. NGL, I lost count of the number of times I kept kicking or punching and the controls weren't responding for long seconds (funnily enough, dodging worked fine all the time). That said,  I HAAAAATE how the bossfights have been set up. Actually, this is the main reason why i'm rage-quitting Remember me even though it pains me to do so: the bossfights. UGHHHHH. I'm really not interested in playing the same thing over and over just because random glitches were freezing some of my controls or because at the last second I messed up the QTE sequence. And speaking of, QTE sequences. Seriously?!? On the plus side, the memory remixes? Niiice! The combo lab was a good idea, but I wish TPTB had made it more flexible (more combos with no restrictions on the assign-able slots).  I can't tell much about the story or characters' backstory cos I got stuck before I could form a solid opinion. They seemed promising though.  I would have LOVED RM had it been Open World. Seriously, Neo Paris looks so good and interesting. TL;DR. It could have been an amazing game. It's not. Don't get me wrong, it's not bad, but it's certainly lacking in some regards. My heart says give it a positive review for the effort (and it does look GOOD) but my brain says nope, solely for the less-than-stellar fight system. Why oh why the combat was so repetitive and vital to move the plot forward?

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Remember me has amazing graphics and a beatiful world you would want to explore but you cant because the game is too linear to allow it. You will find yourself climbing more than Nathan Drake and Lara Croft ever had to in their entire life till you face a battle scene with henchmen who call you ''lil lady'' even tough Nilin (main protagonist) is like 30 year's old, you try to fight them but you realise that you can only do 3 thing's punch, kick and dodge. There are 2 things that try to fix the boring combat first a menu called combo lab wich lets you augment your punches and kicks with different properties like healing or cooldown decrease for powers. Then Powers wich will buff you with more strength or stun all enemies around you but these are not enough to save the combat from feeling boring and repetitive. All in all remember me has a fun unique story wich has segments where you alter memories and impressive graphics but because of the boring and repetitive gameplay i cant recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												I had great expectations on this one, but left it unfinished. The game doesn't know what it wants to be. You could mistake it for Assassin's Creed in a Deus Ex or Mirror's Edge world, but it's more like Mortal Combat with long hauls between the fights and an unnecessarily elaborated combat system. The fine graphic design and cool futuristic environments makes you want to explore, but you can't, except for one pre-determined route from A to B (B for boss fight). This is one of those games where you will encounter invisible walls or having trouble finding a way forward (because there's only one). Thumbs up for much of the design work, but otherwise it's wasted effort.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												While the game is pretty and visually enjoyable at times with an interesting back-story the gameplay is greatly lacking. The progress is along a set path that cannot be deviated from and the fight mechanic timing requirement is another disappointment.The interesting backdrop of Neo-Paris begs to be explored as an open world experience and to allow the player to jump, climb and crawl almost anywhere should have been a requirement. The path between objectives is a set path with no deviation except for small side paths to gather items to aid the charater or reveal more history of the events leading to the core plot.I wish they had built the abilty to explore Neo-Paris for this game to expand on the play time and experience. Instead we are forced into a boring linear progress that I find frustrating.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												It's unfortunate, but I can't recommend this game UNLESS IT'S ON SALE. The Story is GREAT. You play a woman unsure of her past while battling through the future. Altering memories in her wake. The idea of the game is good, but the world, while beautifully done, is very linear. There is no exploration at all. You will go where the you are supposed to go. No where else. Which brings down the replay value.  The fighting system is fun, in that you pick the values of each part of a combo. HOWEVER, the combo doesn't reach beyond one enemy. So getting a max combo is very hard to accomplish unless there is only one enemy to face. If you get hit or move out of the away to avoid a hit, the combo starts over. Had it carried on in a sort of "free flow" then it would have been much better. OVERALL: 5/10

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												One of the best games I've ever played.The environment although linear was amazing to look at and the world felt alive and was full of motion.The story was great and Nilin is a great character,although the story could use some more depth it's good enough to enjoy it.The combat was an interesting part of the game but not very well implemented,it gets quite repetitive near the end even with the addition of new combos.Here's a list of things that sum up the game:An interesting world with a lot of potential and a unique artistic style.A great soundtrack wich I personaly admire,one of the best I've ever heard.Intersting characters with undeveloped backstories.Challengeing battles and new enemy types wich require different strategies as the game goes on.A bunch of visually stunning boss battles.A great story wich could use some more depth but is good nonetheless.A kind of uncomfortable build-your-own combo system.Great voice acting.If you're a fan of cyberpunk games but don't want to pay full price for the game wait for a sale and buy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												This is one of the most rage inducing games I have played in so long. It commits nearly every cardinal sin of gaming. It's repetitive, annoying, spammy and every single bossfight is done via quicktime events. There isn't any point in the combat system that i'd say "Yep, it's fun". It's just a series of endlessly respawning dudes while you mash the LMB. I say mashing the LMB because at a certain point in the game, it just becomes too much work to actually get a combo out without being interrupted or having the system spazz out and switch your combo halfway through.Anyone who was thinking of buying the game for the story, like I did, think again. The premise is interesting but the game has plenty of plotholes, along with the long despised "Get the story narrated in the load screen then never speak of it for the rest of the level" style that so many people seem to go with. Not to mention, Nilin isn't incredibly interesting. For all the hype the game got about "demanding a female character" I can't think of a single reason why, other than to make their game completely parallel with Tomb Raider. Nilin has little to no personality. Not once does she stop and ask herself WHY she's doing the things she is. She escapes the people who stole her memories and then just automatically listens to the first guy she meets. For all she knows he's actually the evil one, but not once in my entire playthrough did she even consider it. Mind you, I only got in halfway to the game cos I was so infuriated by the first half. It was not fun, and I have no intention of dragging my way through the muck for an ending that may or may not ever redeem the rest. Buyer, you have been warned.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												Played the game from start to finish in just over 14 hours. The graphics are beautiful, the storyline is excellent and the overall atmosphere was great. A few things that lack in this game like a parry system, there is no way to block incoming attacks. The chevrons that tell you where to go next take all the fun out of trying to get to the next area and the lack of exploring (none of the shops, etc) you only have a set path to follow. Also, the mobs are the same and are a little annoying and repetative. This game also has a function where you can rewrite the past and tap into peoples memories. This happens 4 times and is challenging but makes the game feel as if it lacks content as it is limited. Overall, the lack of open world explorability combined with the repetaive mobs and the lack of game content made me sad. Unfortunately, I wish I had known about this before purchasing it (on sale for approx $9.99) as I probably would have passed.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I bought this because I loved Dontnod's second game, "Life is Strange." I also bought it because of Steam sale. I just spent 9 hours playing this and beat it. I reget both decisions.I can see how the studio grew from Remember Me's beginnings, including seeds that would blossom into Life is Strange's time travel mechanic. It wasn't worth the time I spent frustratingly playing this game, though. Just watch a Let's Play and support Dontnod by buying your friends copies of Life is Strange. That game is genuinly my 2015 GOTY, and that comes from a Metal Gear Solid fanatic who adored MGSV.To get into more specifics: the gameplay is really plain/frustrating/stupid/immersion-breaking, only punctuated by its most unique aspect of "remixing memories" around 3 times total out of my 9 hours of gameplay. The rest is spent holding up and jumping around a lot, along with the most annoying and frustrating combat system and enemy AI routines you can imagine. Its not worth your frustration.Oh, and the writing is god-awful. The voice acting for the guy who talks to you throughout the game couldn't be flatter if it tried. Its very obvious they went and got a French native to try to act in English. Or if they didn't it sure feels like it, much like most flat acting that you might find in some of Quantic Dream's very obvious characters with French actors speaking with an American accent. Thank god they got some great actors for Life is Strange.But really, just go play Life is Strange instead of this.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												Played the game from start to finish in just over 14 hours. The graphics are beautiful, the storyline is excellent and the overall atmosphere was great. A few things that lack in this game like a parry system, there is no way to block incoming attacks. The chevrons that tell you where to go next take all the fun out of trying to get to the next area and the lack of exploring (none of the shops, etc) you only have a set path to follow. Also, the mobs are the same and are a little annoying and repetative. This game also has a function where you can rewrite the past and tap into peoples memories. This happens 4 times and is challenging but makes the game feel as if it lacks content as it is limited. Overall, the lack of open world explorability combined with the repetaive mobs and the lack of game content made me sad. Unfortunately, I wish I had known about this before purchasing it (on sale for approx $9.99) as I probably would have passed.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31
												Where do I go with this review. You have one of the most interesting topics to deal with; manipulation of memory. This screams stealth game with rpg elements. The ability to manipulate the characters around you would be invaluable as a spy, or a thief, maybe not an assassin, but still. The developers could also have added rpg elements, even if they are light elements to deal with. The ability to effect those around you for whatever purpose would be amazing. Yet they wasted such a great opportunity in this nice looking world on a beat em up action game with scripted boss battles, linear environments, and the concept of memory manipulation not only is never explained on how it works, but it is so rarely used, it might as well not even be in the game at all. Your run of a mill beat em up with so much wasted potential down the drain. With it's already bland gameplay come with fairly bland characters, and fairly bland mechanics.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Remember Me has had a very mixed reception, but it's one of my favorite games of the last generation. Beautiful set pieces, a nice soundtrack, interesting original story, well realized setting, and a main character who is both powerful and vulnerable, and defies a lot of game character norms, really make it something special. The only things that the game is let down by is being extremely linear and not having the best combat system ever devised. Neither of which bothered me tremendously, especially since the combat isn't broken, it just gets repetitive. Oh, and the dialogue outside of cutscenes is a little... awful to the point of being unintentionally funny in places. But these are minor complaints with what is overall a top notch game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												So, this game has a solid dystopian Science Fiction premise, a likeable protagonist, reasonably varied enemies and a solid fighting system. Puzzles and platforming exist but are not extremely arduous.The story is tol from the point of view of Nillin, who has a lot of interesting qualities. I really like that she reacts to situations in a reasonable manner. When she jumps down a flight of stairs she stumbles and cries out, because she just jumped down a flight of 10 stairs.Graphics are beautiful, the game runs great on my machine and is bug free. Controls are gernerally intuitive.The most interesting idea in this game is the memory remixing. Altering people's memories to change the way they feel currently feels exactly like cheating. One of the first times you do it, an enemy becomes a friend. It is awesome.Sometimes the fighting feels clunky, which I think is part of the design. Everytime you mess up her combos the music stops to let you know that you have messed up. This is great but it feels like her combos are more often messed up than not. I just came from playing Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor and the combat there is much smoother.Overall I would reccomend this game to anyone that enjoys Dystopian Science Fiction, or action games in general.7/10

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Could have been great, exploring the possibilities of memory alteration and its ramifications, but ended up as one long massively glorified quicktime event.I kept wanting to like this game. I kept going back to it in the hopes it would get better or grow on me.  I really did want to like it.  The graphics, music, story and characters truly are all great and I loved the artistic world that has been created.  The game truly does *look* great.  What lets it down is everything else.The trailer gives you the impression that the game centers around being able to modify peoples memories.  From that I had gotten the feeling that you could "stealth around" enemies or convert them rather than rely on direct confrontation every time. Sadly though the memory remix moments are few and far between and they are (like the game in general) far too linear, there being only one "right" way to remix the memory.  This seems like a bit of a missed opportunuty in my opinion, there could have been so much more focus on the memory scrambling and altering abilities in the game.What little story there is between chases, telegraphed bosses and too-long quicktime chain cutscenes made me want to carry on to see how it went. The story is actually compelling and interesting and I wanted to see if/how the character could grow.  But time and again the QTE based fighting and QTE based running away along with the stiffling train-track limited "open" world the game was just ruined.I liked the main character, her self questioning, her reassessment of what she had become forcing us to question our own motives and morals.But with a combat system that is more an exercise in futile button mashing and enemy avoidance than actual combat I really cant recommend this to any but the most die-hard of QTE fans.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												this is a very poorly designed game which has almost nothing interesting going for it from the start.the game knows only one way to be played and that way is executed in the most uninspired way possible. i purchased this because i was intrigued by the distopian setting. however, right away, i was quickly turned of by the poor gaming mechanics. the story didn't present anything new but stereotypes. "remember me" is basically unplayable.i had hoped the game gets better but at episode 3, i have lost all hope.what is the problem? well, first of all it is a long corridor of a game, there is no exploration, the world is dead and cannot be delved into. occasionally, the game throws two choices of directions at you, one will lead to a bonus pick-up, the other continuous the corridor. it is not obvious which is which but if you are unlucky to choose the continuous path first, the game will put a wall behind you which prevents you from getting the bouns from the othe path.some of the vista look interesting with people and shops, but these cannot be interacted with, so there is practically a detachment between what you do and what is going on in the world.This is re-inforced by the way of traversing the environment. climbable areas are marked by flashy graphics or distance indicators. this could be a horizontal ridge in 2 meter height. this you could jump to. but don't expect to travers a small barricade of 1m cardboard boxes. these are insurmountable barriers in the game.occasionally you will reach the end of a corridor, surrounded by high walls. from the konowledge of the world you would know because of lack of indicators that you couldn't possibly "escape" that area. yet, the game will bring up a cut scene which makes it somehow possible. this becomes predictable soon. the point is, the game is completele unintuitive, things that should be logically possible are not, impossible things are somehow possible. eventually, you feel mucked by this, because the game forces you onto a path that you couldn't possibly comprehend as a person in the world in advance. you are stumbling through corridors...than, there are fighting scenes. the system is kind of intruiging, but umplayable because of the out-of controll camera. it basically surmounts to panic clicking of buttons while the camera gives no view of what is going on.finally, there are scenes of "memory manipulation" while the control mechanism is a joke, this was the only part that was interesting in the game, because you get intrigued about what effect each manipulation had.perhaps the game would have been more interesting if they had cut the traversing in corridors between memory manipulation mini games.i cannot recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												I would have given a positive review but there are a few elements of the game that really bother me. I would however like to see a sequel made where they improve the flaws in this game's design.Don't get me wrong, there are many good things about the game: such as the setting, the graphics, the story and the main character (it is nice to have a brown coloured main character for once and the main character's design is really well done).But the good things aside, it is the flaws of the game that really hold it back for me and ruined the overall experience, for me.The first issue is the combat; it uses preset combos that you can customise, from the moment the game introduced the combat in this way I knew immediately - oh boy this game's combat is going to get very repetitive very fast! The issue when you have combos that are completely fixed with the same identical animation and same identical button combo each time is that it means you just have to keep pressing the same button combinations over, and over, and over the entire game long. Yes, you can change the combos but all it changes is the effects and the animations of the combo; the button presses remain the same. E.g. left click, right click, left click, right click. Sorry but I can only stand repeating this so often.There is a power for Batman style freeflow combat, but it is only temporary and feels a lot less satisfying than doing a combo which actually seems to do more damage than the freeflow power. It would have been cool if the freeflow power allowed unlimited combo as long as you could keep the combo going without a break in the combo (yes, I know, like Batman). This would have helped quite a bit. There are other powers you can use and if you damage some opponents enough you can use finishers, which are cool. But these only go a short way in helping the overall issue that is the combat in this game. It may have been interesting if you simply could customise the combo effects at different stages of the combo and the animations simply cycle through the ones they have made for that effect - this way at least you have more animation variety and this would allow them to give greater customisation to the combos. E.g. you could pick speed over damage and such too, which currently is not the case. Picking the same type of combo attack with a different animation does only that - same damage, same speed, just different animation.In addition, they could have allowed constant freeflow attacks but that do not give you a bonus effect and also reduced damage. These are just a few ideas and I'm not even a game developer.Then there is the platforming, in general it works but it has many issues with the controls and doesn't always work or do what you want. There are times I've made the same identical jump two times, one time she just randomly decides to fall right through the ledge she was supposed to grab, the other time she grabs it no problem. Then often while going around corners or trying to jump across a gap she just refuses to go the direction you want no matter what key press you push. I don't know if this is due to the port or if this was also an issue on the console versions but definitely is something they should have fixed. If not at launch, at least with an update!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												A highly underrated and underappreciated game, Remember Me delves into a cleverly written cyber-punk universe, where memories are everything. Traded, sold, erased, reconstructed, memories are no longer private, and as protagonist Nilin, you have the power to not only take memories... but remix them. Thrown into a prison with no recollection of who or what you once were, you are thrust into a dangerous world that teters on the brink of collapse. With only the mysterious Edge to guide you, you will have to fight your way through both humans, and their memory lost muntant Leaper counterparts. Story - Amazingly well written, I was completely immersed in this new cyber punk scenario the developers had bulit up. Gameplay - Combat is okay, but the combo lab is where it shines. Able to create your own combos, you can mix up how you approach battles to your liking. Platforming could've been executed a bit better though.Graphics - The Neo-Paris area is gorgeous to look at, though its too bad most of the time is spent in doors. Even then, the world of Remember Me is a stunning and visually astounding.Sound - The music has scratched up remixed like sounds thrown into a powerful electronic baseline, able to go from tension, to tender caring moments.Overall - An awesome game, and I highly recommend it to anyone and everyone. Fantastic story, music, and art style makes Remember Me shine. While the gameplay isn't perfect, it still offers a good experience overall.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												It's ironic that the title of this game is Remember Me, because the developers and writers seem to forget the theme of the game within an hour of booting it up. Between an unfocused story line, weak dialogue, a hamfisted approach to making the game cinematic, a repetitive combat system, a poorly thought out exploration system (exploration is downplayed because the game is completely linear but there are little pick ups for those willing to take a few steps off the path, some of them flesh out the lore of the game, which could just be available to the player from the start) and a basically non-existent attempt to blend the story and the game aspects, the only real thing going for Remember Me is the distinct visual style. The game is gorgeous but bland, the only gameplay aspect that really mixes things up is the memory remix mechanic, which is utilized in game 4 times throughout the entire thing, for a total of less than an hour of any kind of unique experience.Just don't bother.

content:
Posted: March 6
												This is an incredibly beautiful game/story ruined by an absolutely horrific combat system.  Imagine playing Arkham Asylum only without the ability to counter when a bad guy interrupts your combo chain. Instead, you can only dodge about and constantly reset said combo chain.  Which wouldn't be so bad if combos weren't a requirement for a) reloading your actually useful skills b) healing c) dealing specific damage to mini bosses.  It's awful.  I can't understand how anyone got past the demo version of this and said "Yup, this feels organically frustrating, let's go with it."  The fact that you can customize the combos doesn't help other than you can change the simple three button one - aka the only  one you'll consistently be able to do -  to whatever you really need at the moment.  Because there's no way you'll ever be able to pull off the five or seven combos with enough regularity to get through the game.  I've had this for months now, and still haven't bothered to beat it because I can't stand the fighting system after only thirty minutes or so of playing.  If you can just watch the story bits on Youtube that's probably better than buying this game, even on sale.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												+++ Breathtaking art direction, in-universe setting and concept.+++ Free-flowing, easy-to-learn brawl play.--- Tedious and meaningless platforming sections.--- Everyone but the protagonist is a throwaway character.--- Story pacing issues.--- Completely linear level design, with pseudo-secrets strewn about.--- Pace-breaking QTEs.While initially presenting a very promising concept, Remember Me never quite manages to capitalize on its strengths.  It has a wonderful world to offer, but the player is never really given the opportunity to explore it, and so the levels feel much like walking through a static museum.  For those who don't want to look around too much, this means levels boil down to satisfying although samey battle sequences, in-between platforming/acrobatic sections that are but a formality of button-pushing to get through, with the occasional fork in the road where one path leads to an upgrade some ten meters down - and so, what little exploration can be done ends up feeling shallow.Similarly, characters are introduced only to never be seen again, with the only constants being the protagonist and what best qualifies as her commanding officer.  The player is not given any time to relate to any secondary characters, and the 'major' enemies of the game are little more than items to check off a list.  It is difficult at best to want to beat a foe when the only exposure about them is given in occasional blurbs spread out in the ten minutes before encountering them.Perhaps the strongest point is the fighting, with the way the music changes with the intensity of the battle, and the impact noises are quite satisfying to hear.  The boss fights take it a step further, often serving as a test of the skills the player has learned so far - unfortunately many of those encounters must be finished with a QTE.  Failing those only results in a minor setback, but fact remains that the thrill of victory is heavily diminished once the player's seen the same finisher sequences 3-4 times.Overall, it feels like the 90s way of game design was applied to a 2010s title.  A whole lot could've been accomplished with the idea to create a rich game and mayhaps even a franchise, but the end result is ultimately little more than concept art in 3D.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												So... the best parts about this game are often understated: 1.) The storyline is imaginative, compelling and well told through cinematics and voice over - actually decent voice over!2.) The graphics are gorgeous, the music and sound effects are well done and the controls (for the most part) are smooth.3.) The UI is pretty informative. As a bonus, it's even tied into the storyline, which is something a lot of games don't do. 4.) Combat can feel pretty satisfying when you've statted up your customizable fighting combos appropriately. 5.) Speaking of combat, the game does a fair job of trying to spice things up by adding a lot of new abilities, mini games and puzzles to try to keep things interesting. Notice I said "fair," more on this later...6.) The 'leveling' system feels appropriate. You often face monsters you've encountered before and when you meet them again in later levels, wrecking the monsters that wrecked you earlier feels, oh, so cathartic.  Are we done gushing? Ok, onto the terribad:1.) Game is repetative, Repetative, REPETITIVE. Did I mention, redundant? Oh, it's that too. Every episode, EVERY EPISODE follows the same sort of segmented sections: fight, "explore"/puzzle, story time. Sometimes they come in different combinations, but you can always tell which segment you're about to encounter next. 2.) Despite the variety of activites the game presents, it tend to want to overwhelm you with combat, which normally isn't a bad thing. The combat in this game is primarily a brawler style combat system, so be prepared to mash X and Y. A LOT. This by itself isn't bad. However, the key to fighting is pulling off combos, which would be awesome if you weren't always fighting ABOUT 10 people who ALWAYS interrupt your combos. This greatly limits one's ability to pull off, say, a 6 or 9 string combo, making approximatley half of the features in the Combo Lab practically pointless. This also means a lot of time is devoted to flipping around the battle aimlessly whilst trying to avoid getting slaughtered by a huge mob of minions. And while I think the designers and artists deserve kudos for making the protagonist a lithe and fiesty brunette, I just don't think watching her flip around with her legs in the air is enough to excuse such tedious battles. Call me a feminist, I guess. Or a "hardcore gamer." But I digress..."What about bosses?" you ask. "Aren't you fighting them one on one?"Yes, but typically there's a lot of dodging and special activities that are required to make them vulnerable first- then when that happens, they typically call for reinforcements. Wash. Rinse. Repeat. 3.) CAMERA. ANGLES. FROM. HELL! Luckily the game never freezes in one of these angles, but it can be frustrating when you're trying to keep an eye on 6 monsters, navigate obstacles in the environment AND fight a boss that's shooting bombs at you from across the screen. 4.) So the "About this game" section kinda of lies. A LOT. --- It mentions "A balanced mix of combat and exploration." Firstly, I think if I had to log all the time I spent doing either activity it would be something more like 70/30 respectively. Plus, I'm not sure following a discrete path through the environment really counts as "exploration."--- It also mentions the "Memory ReMix" feature, which I will openly admit is one of the best parts of the game. However, I think you use it a total of 3 times in the whole game. So, returning to that previous note about "balanced mix" I think the break down becomes something like 70/27/3. So here I am, about 10 hours into the game, only about 75% of the way through and I'm asking myself, "is it worth it to keep going?" As it is, I have to drag myself to play this game over the 50 other games I've stockpiled during flash sale events. And a game that makes you ask yourself, "Is it worth finishing?" has problems with its fun factor.--EDIT 12/13/2015--So, less than a week later it seems my decision has been made for me. During a particular boss fight in Episode 7 th e game started to glitch out. "Combat time" continued to play even when I'd defeated all the enemies in the area and accomplished my mission goals. I had to burn a focus power to trigger the end of combat (luckily). Not ten seconds later I was unable to interact with a focus powerup. I thought it might be because I had to clear another conditional trigger because the Aug-Eye icon was flashing, indicating that there was something I needed to look at by pushing the down button on the D-Pad. Unfortunately, that wasn't working either. I managed to clear it by completing the next section of the area and unlocking a ladder. I ran back to the focus upgrade and still couldn't interact with it. Defeated I returned to the ladder, only to find that I COULDN'T INTERACT WITH IT EITHER! Effectively trapping me in the level. After having spent at least 5-7 minutes wading through a half dozen minions at a time to defeat the previous boss (not to mention the prior 3 bosses) I did not relish the idea of starting the episode over. So this game experience ends now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Remember me is a game that i probably will not remember in about a year or two. The game had a very good setting going for them but fell flat when it came to the protagonist story and certain aspects of the gameplay. It is not necessarily a bad game, it just isn't an enjoyable one. The Good part - The setting is amazing, it is 2084 Neo-Paris and they aced in every part of that. From the buildings to the people to the music. They made it very believable. The soundtrack is very unique and all the buildings that you enter does look like something you would see in 2084. They did it better than deus ex human revolution and binary domain in that regard. The memory remixes are extremely fun to play with and does not feel boring. You could mess around with it for 30 minutes each and it is a shame that there are only 4 in the entire campaign. S-Pressens (or Super combos) are a joy to use and each of them are unique. It's always fun to do different combinations of them.The bad part - for most of the story it is basically "follow to leader". Some random guy who came out of nowhere named "Edge" tells you how to escape a facility and you follow his orders for the entire story. The story gets a little interesting at some parts but never amazed me. The Pressens/ combos (not to be confused with S-Pressens) are really dull. They only give you 3 or 4 different combos and you do that for the entire 9 hours. They are not enjoyable to use at all and the only thing that saved it was S-Pressens. The game is extremely linear, there is no alternate path.. Not even in the Parkour/ climbing sections. The game would have been so much better if it was open world or even semi open world. Recommended if below $10Not recommended if above $10

content:
Posted: February 19
												An entertaining 10 hour Cyberpunk adventure story that is worth playing through once.  The story itself involves a bleak futuristic Paris where a corporation called Memorize has taken control of the majority of the populace through their memories and allowed them to create a surveillance state.  You play as Nilin, a rebel soldier of the group called "Errorists", who is intially captured but escapes and trys to regain the lost memories taken from her.  All the while trying to bring the downfall of Memorize.  The graphics and art style of the game make future Paris a beautiful yet bleak place to explore through.  The orchestrated music score with it's mixture of techno is quite good, it's just ashame they didn't release an OST for it.  The combat gameplay itself is decent yet the Remix segments are by far the best parts of the game.  If you've ever played DONTNOD's other game, Life is Strange, then you can instantly tell that the Remix portions of the game helped influence the Rewind mechanic in that game.  I also found it interesting that the main protaganist, Nilin, seemed to inspire the appearance of the main character, Max, in LIS.  Overall, if you're like me and I decided to give this game a try because you enjoyed LIS then you may be disappointed if you were expecting a similar experience.  It's still a fun game and I give it a 7.5/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												After playing Life is Strange I thought I would try the studios first game, sadly Remember Me has little redeeming features. The story is very by the numbersl with an ending you can see coming from a few hours before the reveal and the dialogue is terrible throughout which after playing LiS is a real dissapointment. The gameplay fairs no better, from terrible easy platforming and constant fighting with enamies you will see again and again, only with added features like, this one has a shield or (frustratingly) an electric field which damages you with every hit. The one really reedeming features is the memory remixing, where you edit the memories of charcaters by affect objects in the enviroment to change their memories. Sadly there are not many of these throughout the game and some of them are overly long. The games soundtrack is possibly the worst soundtrack I have heard in quite some time, its a mix of violin strings and electronic glitches scattered randomly throughout, which is just an assult on your eardrums everything you hear it. The graphics are pleasent enough with some really terrific looking areas when walking around Paris, sadly a lot of areas seem like carbon copies of other areas. Steer claer of this one, even though some parts of the game are midly interessting, it is not worth the time you will put in to beat it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Remember me had a lot of novel ideas, but unfortunately is too timid to fully realise any of them.The most egrecious though is that of the "custom combos". See, it SOUNDS like you're going to be able to pull off long awesome combos on the fly, maybe choose them in the menu, but the reality is that all you change is the animation and the effect of the moves.What this translates into is the player pressing the exact same sequence of buttons throughout the whole game. Occassionally pausing to swap the effect.And don't get me started on the memory remixes... It could have been something truly interesting, but it just falls flat, partly because there's only 3 or 4 memory remixes in the whole game, one of which is a "memory of a memory".Really, Remember me could have been a lot more than it was, and was entirely missable.

												Remember Me is a great game with a rare used setting! The female main character was also a good choice. Story: ( 8 / 10 )- The Game is set in the year 2084 in Neo-Paris ( a futuristic version of Paris )You have to Stop the Memorize corporation. They invented a brain implan called " Sensen". It allows the population to upload and share their memories. You can also delete unhappy or unpleasent memories. A small group of people are addicted to absorb as many memories as possible. Their Sensen has degraded and they have mutated into a sub-human form called "Leapers". Characters: ( 9 / 10 )- many characters with their own special personality.Sound ( 9 / 10 )- Well mixed and composed music and sounds that fits to the Setting of Neo-ParisThey did a great JobExample:

Graphics: ( 7 / 10 )- Unreal Engine 3- The City looks beautiful- nice reflexions- nice lighting- cool effects ( like "Warning" when you fight against a robot )- face animations and face textures could be better Gameplay ( 7 / 10 )- Great Combo System ( pretty hard at the beginning )- cool special moves like "Fury" , "D.O.S " , Camo " . " Logic Bomb " and "Rest in Pieces "- The Main Menu has a good overview - Great Boss Fights !- You can remix the memories ( pretty rare :( ) but it´s a awesome featureAt the end it´s a fantastic game with a rare used setting ! You should nominate this game for the " Sleeper " award in Steam Autumn Sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												+++ Breathtaking art direction, in-universe setting and concept.+++ Free-flowing, easy-to-learn brawl play.--- Tedious and meaningless platforming sections.--- Everyone but the protagonist is a throwaway character.--- Story pacing issues.--- Completely linear level design, with pseudo-secrets strewn about.--- Pace-breaking QTEs.While initially presenting a very promising concept, Remember Me never quite manages to capitalize on its strengths.  It has a wonderful world to offer, but the player is never really given the opportunity to explore it, and so the levels feel much like walking through a static museum.  For those who don't want to look around too much, this means levels boil down to satisfying although samey battle sequences, in-between platforming/acrobatic sections that are but a formality of button-pushing to get through, with the occasional fork in the road where one path leads to an upgrade some ten meters down - and so, what little exploration can be done ends up feeling shallow.Similarly, characters are introduced only to never be seen again, with the only constants being the protagonist and what best qualifies as her commanding officer.  The player is not given any time to relate to any secondary characters, and the 'major' enemies of the game are little more than items to check off a list.  It is difficult at best to want to beat a foe when the only exposure about them is given in occasional blurbs spread out in the ten minutes before encountering them.Perhaps the strongest point is the fighting, with the way the music changes with the intensity of the battle, and the impact noises are quite satisfying to hear.  The boss fights take it a step further, often serving as a test of the skills the player has learned so far - unfortunately many of those encounters must be finished with a QTE.  Failing those only results in a minor setback, but fact remains that the thrill of victory is heavily diminished once the player's seen the same finisher sequences 3-4 times.Overall, it feels like the 90s way of game design was applied to a 2010s title.  A whole lot could've been accomplished with the idea to create a rich game and mayhaps even a franchise, but the end result is ultimately little more than concept art in 3D.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												Tentative Recommendation:Overall, a decent cyberpunky game with one excellent game mechanic. First off, most of the gameplay is an incredibly easy version of what you would find in one of the Batman Arkham games. None of the fights are particularly challenging. The one interesting mechanic presented in the game is called "remixing," wherein you watch a memory of a character and then attempt to alter certain aspects of it in order to manipulate their memory. It's a neat idea and pretty fun, but only happens maybe four times total throughout the entire game.The story itself takes place in a cyber-punky version of Paris wherein memories have become the most valuable form of currency. Again, it's a neat sort of idea but is basically left unexplored and as a result does not make a great deal of sense if you stop to think about the world a bit. The story starts off fairly interesting, but begins to peter out and finishes with a total letdown of an ending.If you decide to try it, get it on sale for 5-10 dollars or so.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												Imagine all the things that make the Batman series fun and interesting and trow them out, then you'll have Remember me. Its very similar (the fighting system is almost identical) but much more repetitive, uninspired, and boring. Boss fights are borderline depressing and just require you to find the pattern and break it at the apropriate point repeatedly until you reach the next cut scene. and the story line doesn't really grab you or keep you interested. The memory augmentation is an interesting mechanic, but they are too few and far between and border on tedium. You have to constantly rewind and play out the same thing over and over, looking for the perfect combination of very minor changes to make everything work right. I got it on sale for $10 and I wish I had just skipped it. While its not a bad game overall, its no where near a great game. I believe it sits comfortably in the midst of mediocrity.

												I was excited for the launch of this game, but didn't get it and I'm so glad that I waited.  I was hoping for another deus ex.  This isn't it.  The best description of this game is tedious.  While visually very pretty, the combat is ridiculous and depends on putting the right combinations in order, which of course you build as the game progresses.  Lackluster mechanics aside, where this game fails miserable is in connecting with the player.  Several hours into the game I find myself not caring about the story, characters, or the missions.  When the protagonist falls off of a building to her death...I don't care.  When she gets beaten in a fight...don't care (other than the inconvenience of having to re do the fight scene which unfortunately drags out the miserable gaming experience).  I really wanted to like this game and because of that gave it way more chance than it deserved.  Pros:  Graphics are good, voice acting is good, it's been completely glitch freeCons:  Everything else

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												It's cyber-punk the way it was meant to be. ( Bladerunner, Neruomancer, The Matrix, Deus EX ). A nice clash between Dystopia and Utopia and an engaging story that makes Nillin a memorable character. Plus she's hot as *&%$ !     But not only the story and my fixation with cyber punk made this game a win for me. The visuals and graphic style of this game kept me coming back for more.       The combo creation feature makes the combat so much more interesting than just button mashing. Boss fights are creative and fun.       But most of all, Neo Paris is alive with ambience and the vistas through out most of the game are stunning and right on par with other great cyber -punk worlds. Overall, a very under rated game but very much worth at least one playthrough.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I wish there was an option for a mixed opinion, because I know others might enjoy the game, I just didn't.The game is essentially just a virtual tour, of an admittedly nice looking world, but with a very on rails experience. There's really not much strategy or decision making to it at all, you simply follow the markers everywhere, or engage in very bland fist fights, that quickly become reptitive, with memory zombies. Also, apparently all it takes to heal yourself is punching or kicking in a combo..In the about an hour I played the game, hardly anything was explained about the world, it stated what things were but, they never actually explained why things were. How does a memory keeping company produce and throw away such a large volume of corpses? And why are some half alive, acting and speaking like Smeagol/Gollum? Why is there an underworld in 'Neo-Paris' with all these beings running freely? Perhaps later on things are better explained, but something about it tells me probably not.To be honest, I really wanted to enjoy the game, I had never heard of it before, saw it on the steam sale and thought it looked pretty awesome. But all these things I've stated just hold me back from enjoying it, I was just forcing myself to play more and more, but just getting more and more bored with it. It's a great looking game, but just doesn't have much for gameplay.. So, for now I'm refunding it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												I originally started to play Remember Me on PS3 as a PSN freebie. It was okay but nothing I ever went back to. During one of many Steam sales, I decided to give it another go since I felt I didn't give it a real chance on PS3. The first thing I noticed, do NOT play this with a Steam controller. No matter how I tried to configure the touch pad to simulate a right analog stick for camera control, it absolutely would not work correctly. Use a Xbox 1 controller or forget about it. Initially I thought the main character, Nilin was a bit unusual. Mainly because she looked Black and Black women are almost never featured in games not to mention featured as a main character. But I like her design and the motion capture for her walk is sexy so there's that. Later I found out she's biracial and although it felt like a bit of a cop-out (the design world still doesn't have the stones to actual design a Black lead family for a story such as this), I still thought Nilin's design was overall well done if a bit of a let down in a way, considering how the story progresses and the scene in the car. The graphics in general are really good with some great lighting and details. The art direction for Neo Paris is very impressive even by today's standards (3 years later in a GTX 10.x world). Combat is a bit clunky but functional allowing for players to build custom combos through unlockables. These combos can also restore health, deal more damage or reduce cool down times for specials. It works, but does take some getting used to. Anyone familar with games like Devil May Cry or God of War will definitely see the not-so-subtle rip off of the combat style and mechanics. But as I mentioned, combat is functional if not adding anything interesting or new. For my tastes, it simply doesn't flow as well as Devil May Cry or Bayonetta and it doesn't have the impact of God of War.Speaking of borrowing from other games, there is a lot borrowed from the Uncharted series in terms of stage navigation. Constant climbing, shimmying across and scampering through various locales. It's heavy handed to the point that it became a bit annoying 50% through the game because it's such a blantant rip from Uncharted. Even the cut scenes where the environments break apart as Nilin tries to progress are face palm worthy. I was embarrassed for the developers. Liked Uncharted so much that you just had to swing from Naughty Dog's nipple? Ooooookay. This brings one of the biggest problems with the game and I have three. 1) As beautiful as the game is most of the time, it's far too linear with some glaring annoyances as a result. Here we have a heroine that can scale vast landscapes almost like Spiderman but can't jump over a 3 foot crate. She can jump across a 30 foot span 20 stories high but she can't jump over a counter. The game is linear to the extent that it makes the environments less impressive because we can't actually explore anything and the character is hamstrung many times to keep us on the predetermined path. This is made worse because there are times when you will have to travel through an apartment that's lived in but you can't actually explore buildings, streets or other rooms. Only the path the developer dictates. 2) Total lack of bosses. There was a cool boss fight with Kid XMas because he was like a zonked out Vin Diesel broadcasting the battle for TV audiences. But there aren't too many afterward. Madame's boss battle was cool but there simply wasn't enough of it. Johnny Greenteeth's battle sucked and that brings me to my final major grip with the game...3) It's too long. After the first 4 or 5 hours, I was really into the game and the story being told. The concepts about memories are really interesting. The game felt like it could be similar to Heavenly Sword in a way. Heavenly Sword is only 6 hours long but it's a really wild and action packed 6 six hours. But Remember Me drags on after Chapter 5. The way the plot reveals itself I expected to see end credits and a final cut scene after chapter 5 or 6. Going into chapter 7, I got really annoyed with the game because it feels like the developers padded the game instead of keeping it tight and concise letting it reach its conclusion. I think the memory remixing IS excellent though but again...fantastic concept that isn't utilized enough in the game. The same could be said for the supporting cast of characters. You simply don't see them enough. Althought the events of the game are supposed to affect all of Neo Paris, it's suprising how little of an impact the events really seemed to make. I never really felt like my actions made any real difference. One reveal during the car scene is followed by "oh, yeah...that's important to know but now run off and go do something or other. As important as that info is to solve the riddle of your identity, don't focus on that...just go over here and do something else instead."I still recommend Remember Me, because it's dirt cheap these days and runs great even on not-so cutting edge rigs. There is some good stuff in it. I just feel the game had the potential to be stellar instead of just "good" overall...in a bargin bin kinda way.
