content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Okay, overall, I thought this game had a good concept, okay execution, and pretty good voice acting.  Possible mini-spoilers so please read at your discretion. If you're looking for a game with a beautiful word, you'll find it in the city of Neo-Paris. But what disappointed me upon first play was that the world was not as interactive as I thought it would be, considering how much detail went into interesting rooms and objects that you merely passed by during gameplay. Like the robots that scatter around the city of Neo-Paris. I wish they served more of a purpose within the game because they're everywhere, but they're not mentioned at all in the storyline.To be honest, everything about this game felt like a half-full & half-empty glass of milk. After the first major secret of Nilin's past was revealed, most of the rest of the game became predictable. I liked Nilin as the main protagonist, but I believe that a lot of the side characters just lacked reason for their actions, or they just... weren't very convincing as villains or stricken heroes. The reasons didn't convince me and felt forced. And also, I felt like the game was trying to do TOO much. There were too many things that the game wanted to include in the story and that's where all the stuff fell flat because it got boring after awhile, and the story seemed overstretched. Instead of episodes and quantity in information, they should've gone with quality and precise information. The explanation of some back characters also weren't very clear, and a lot of characters who were important in one episode were forgotten for the rest of the game or came back at awkward or weird parts of the story. The messy use of the side characters kinda made me confused and bored as well because frankly, after that character was gone so long, I had stopped caring about them and any character deaths weren't very sad for me. And the emotions and relationships felt fake since we only saw that character once or twice before so there was not really much of a connection that had me emotionally invested in the game.Anyway, that's just some of the bad things that I had to get off my chest. Regarding the good things, like I said, the world is very beautiful. The first major plot twist was very interesting (though the rest proved predictable afterwards). Nilin was excellent as a main protagonist suffering from amnesia, and I thought that was very clever because we, as the players, could learn along in the game as she did. The mechanics of the memory remixes were very fun because I made♥♥♥♥♥♥go wrong just for the heck of it, and I wish they included more options for the memory remixes to create more outcomes. Either way, I really liked the whole "memory hunter/remixer" thing going on. Another thing I really liked was the parkour stuff, climbing walls and scaling odd structures. Wish they could've also incorporated more of that actually...Anyway, I'm really in-between in the game. I think it's a good game to play once, but even then, I don't think it's a very memorable game other than its interesting concept and pretty art. I'd recommend getting it on a sale if possible.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												TL,DR: While Remember Me is definitely a bit rough around the edges, it delivers on an interesting story, and generally enjoyable gameplay.First, the rough patches: the controls are sluggish and unreliable (though usually not to a game breaking extent), every five minutes you'll have to drop everything you're doing to listen to someone force feed you another chunk of exposition, there are times when the audio just cuts out for no reason (on my machine Alt-Tabbing out and then back in fixed this), the camera occasionally points in entirely the wrong direction for you to see what you're doing, and parts of the level/game design can be fairly unintuitive.Next, the redeeming qualities: level design as far as the general atmosphere is fantastic at communicating the feel of the city of Neo-Paris and the fictional times in which the game is set, memory remixing is a blast (it's like a choose your own adventure version of a cutscene), the overall plot is compelling and definitely takes a few exciting turns.Last, what this game is not: if you're really into TPS combat games like Devil May Cry (or even just Legend of Kora) Remember Me's combat system will leave you sorely disappointed at it's repetitive and surprisingly inflexible nature, if you really enjoyed free climbing as found in Assassin's Creed (or even Splinter Cell) you should remember that no matter how it looks Remember Me only doesn't have a free climbing system, it has one that only let's you travel on very specific routes that aren't necessarily obvious to the casual observer.So, do I recommend this game? It's definitely worth a look for the story and the developers deserve to be supported for the thought and innovation they put into the remixing mechanic. Is this a particularly good game? If you aren't bothered by it's flaws and limitations, it's a pretty enjoyable experience, otherwise I recommend waiting to pick it up when it's on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												I really enjoyed this game.  It was very stable -- something you cannot take for granted in today's gaming environment.  A great inventive story.  Game mechanics/controls worked well.  Graphics looked great to me -- although I'm not super picky about that anyway.  It was like you were participating in a big budget movie.  I'd definitely recommend this game.Some minor criticisms (mainly for the developers) about a couple of common annoyances in games:a) non-skippable really long cutscenes (several minutes).  If I'm having trouble a with a particular sequence right after a long cutscene and I have stop -  I don't really want to be forced to watch the cutscene again (and again ...).b) When you die, the game does not remember your combo configs.  They go back to what they were at the last checkpoint.  It was a bit annoying on a difficult sequence to have to reconfigure the combos after every time I died.  In frustration to get around this, I reduced the game difficulty temporarily just so I could get through the sequence because I was tired of repetitively having to reconfigure the combos.  This was only a factor for me in two spots in the game.But this game was a great deal of fun and the pros far outweighed the cons for me.

Posted: November 20, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game... I really did. But no go.Where should I start? First off I got it on sale along with the DLC pack, and I'm sorry I even bought it.I have not completed it yet, but given its mishaps it's unlikely I will.Let me explain in it in PRO / CON:PROs:The game itself is graphically pleasing, it has a certain style to it (even the graphic glitches add to the flavor of the story telling)Sound and soundtrack are fit for the whole theme of the gameCinematics are well madeWorks properly with SteamCONs:The game has VERY FLAWED controls with a mouse and keyboardMovement and interactions are awkwardThe combat system is downright machinatedMemory mixing UI/controls are uninspiringStory is meh... It could be that my expectations were too high from the trailers (even with 80% off the purchase price)Reading the Mnesist Memories doesn't really add any depth to the story or any information of value in helping with gameplayMost of the time in the game is spent either in stupid (and unwieldly) combat or moving from one place to the next as you try to piece together story elementsIt feels like a french movie, almost looks interesting but in the end everything is left hanging because they don't know how to make a proper ending.Like I said, I really wanted to like the game but in the end because of its poor design/execution I'm going to see if I can get a refund.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												No idea why this game has such a bad rating. Game has a rich, imersive story set within a sci-fi lover's fantasy that combines the futuristic elements we all love from well known stories such as aeon flux with the current archetecture of France as if fantasy and reality simply melded. On top of all this the voice acting is pretty decent and the gameplay fluid and very responsive. Fighting elements of the game remind me of batman arkam asylum with  a twist as Remember Me allows combos to be customised to give different affects. Climbing aspects of the game are used very well and show the depth and detail of the world Killin is making her way through. This is one of the most well rounded and balanced games in terms of playability, story and concept I have played in a while, worth picking up full price if not during a steam sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												If you are a fan of third person hack n slash/beat em up's then you have played this before and you won't be playing this game for anything unique in the gaming department. The combat is mediocre, where you are prompted when to jump out of enemies attacks and as the game progresses they get bigger, have new skills and you fight more and more. The platforming was easy, constantly being told where to go, having my hand held all along the way and I think I died maybe once from a platforming sequence. What makes Remember Me a good game was the science fiction and the world you play in. Whils the world is very linear and you are confined to tight paths, just go along the ride and experience the world as the set designers and artists made it. The concept in the game is also pretty badass and kept me playing till the end. Whilst the gameplay and story was rather mediocre, the concept and the world kept me playing. I give it 6/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I got this game as a bonus for a Humble Bundle so from my perspective it was essentially free.  That being said I feel like I overpayed.Do you like button mashing?  Do like linear gameplay? Do you like absurdly frustrating boss fights that result in you uninstalling the game (I can't be the only one).  If so this game may be for you.Aesthetically speaking I like it. The visuals are gritty and twisted, the style is mostly contigous. The story leading up to the first boss was definitely intriguing, the concept has potential. This however is the unrealized version of these things.The combat is in fact dreadful. Yes you can technically "craft your own combos" but what that really entails is struggling through an undescribed, unintuitive interface to select between different versions of the same thing, the only thing that really matters is that you can consistently hit the dodge button. This part was somewhat expected and so I was starting to overlook how tedious and unfulfilling the combat was, I mean hell I was on a role.  Then it happened...So I alluded to it previously but when you are building your combos in the interface different buttons map to different moves.  You don't get a legend or explanation for which button is which move however and in fact they are represented by these little symbols.  Meh, after getting your face eaten a few times you can manage to pull off one of the two combos you've created and then repeat until the battle is over.  Then you get to the boss, suddenly the tone changes from futuristic memory thieves to what might as well be wrestling, it's that over the top.  At first you even get to follow the same lack luster combat techniques used for previous encounters and then suddenly ... horribly ... in order to proceed ... you must respond to quick time events (okay you're saying, that's not the end of the world) but instead of the events being dictated with something you could recognize they are instead flashed on the screen as the cryptic symbols from the combo configuration screen.  So basically you have a fraction of a second to attempt to correlate that little symbol with one of the buttons on whatever device you may be controlling the game with, good luck.♥♥♥♥ this, ♥♥♥♥ them, ♥♥♥♥ quick time in general, but especially ♥♥♥♥ this cryptic♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t quick time that demands you memorize their little crappy symbols and how they map out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												The stylish Remember Me will take you on a heavily guided tour of the striking cyberpunk city of Neo-Paris.Remember Me is not an open world game in spite of how tempted you will be to explore the highly detailed world of Neo-Paris.  Your journey from the slums and sewers to the corporate megaplexes of Neo-Paris will be strongly guided by little yellow chevrons that highlight what path to take and to which ledges to navigate.  Deviating from the recommended path will yield rewards of health and Focus (mana) increases, but the immediate dead ends will soon guide you back to the prescribed path.  While this seems like more of a deliberate design decision than a shortcoming of the game, I think it is important to know what to expect from Neo-Paris.  What you see will be beautifully detailed, but it will be exactly what the designers want you to see.The combat is based on a combo system and while you cannot alter the sequence of punches or kicks, you can choose with which boons to imbue them.  As your character progresses you will be able to unlock punches and kicks that replenish health, deal extra damage, shorten cooldowns of your special abilities, or amplify the effect of the previous attack.  Although you will frequently be outnumbered by foes that interrupt your combos, their attacks are broadcasted in such a way that you can dodge them to hopefully continue your combo on the baddie you have singled out.  Successfully completing a long combo will yield extra PMP (XP used to unlock Pressens, the perks you use to enhance your punches and kicks) and finish off enemies faster.  Bosses will often be surrounded by these lesser mobs and defeating them helps build the Focus you will need to execute your S-Pressens (special attacks) to overcome the bosses' immunities and ultimately defeat them.  After depleting a boss's health, you'll enter a sequence in which you stylishly deal the finishing blows to your enemy, but you'll have to satisfy QTE prompts to dispatch him.  Failing any prompt will kick you back to the regular combat where you will have to whittle down the last fraction of the boss's health again before attempting the QTEs.  While people may not appreciate QTEs, I enjoyed the cinematic flare with which they allowed me to finish off a boss.The S-Pressens mentioned earlier are unlocked at specific points in the story and it is up to you to figure out which ones are best used against specific enemies to exploit their weaknesses or overcome their immunities.Also at specific to points in the plot are the memory remixes wherein the player is tasked with reviewing an NPC's memory and changing details of it to alter how an event is remembered.  Rotating the thumbstick of the controller to rewind or fast-forward through memories was a satisfyingly tactile experience (microfilm, anyone?) and although reaching the desired outcome of any memory remix is mostly an exercise in trial and error, the solutions are not as random or obscure as many puzzles of the point-and-click genre.  There are only four of these remixes throughout the game, but they are a welcome improvement on the passive cut scenes they might have otherwise been.Neo-Paris is a fitting backdrop for uncovering a plot whose theme centers around memories.  In a world where the technology allows for the storage, transfer, and manipulation of memories you will be tasked with recovering your wiped memories and thwarting a plot to use this technology to topple the utpoian Neo-Paris.  If doing so in a richly detailed cyberpunk world with some stylish fight sequences and light puzzle and platforming sequences sounds good to you, consider picking up Remember Me.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												I've wanted Remember Me for a while and got it at one of the last sales at a discounted price.So far, it appears to be a straightforward 3rd Person adventure.It feels like a rails game since its not an open world. That is, you're guided rigorously to the next goal. The only deviation is the occasional hunt for collectibles/boosts.The memory remixing is pretty cool since its not as straightforward as you'd think. You can't just change everything, it needs to be a specific combination of items. It's a different take on the rewind/fast forward time manipulation mechanics. Outside of that, the combat feels like typical button mashing, combo building, dodge mechanics. From there, the art direction is cool. Futuristic Neo-Paris. Nothing you really haven't seen before.I recommend this game if you can get it on discount. It's not going to break any ground and probably only has 6-7 hours worth of content.

												Fews games have a distinct sense of style, Remember Me is one of them.  The environments and charater design both serve to strengthen the story rather than distract from it.  The story itself is incredibly enganging, a sci-fy or tech noir tale that leads to a satisfying conclussion.The game play works well, even though if it is not my prefered style of games.  It feels and performs like a console game and I was glad that I had a controller to enjoy it.  I would guess that keyboard and mouse would be less enjoyable.  At times the battles in the game tended toward lasting too long and I would say that, at times, they felt a bit tedious.  Boss battles also suffered from the same problem.  It took work to figure what was the correct strategy for some of the big fights.  Then it took practice to be able to execute the strategy successfully.These negative points however, were not enough to detract from what was a memorable gaming experience.  Take the time to discover this game and emerse yourself in this dark future Paris.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Highly recommended for those who like cinematic games. The graphics are pretty unique and the combat is relatively similar to your typical beat 'em ups. The game's main feature is the story though, and because of this, everything is practically linear. It's practically impossible to get lost, since many branching paths just lead to a dead end, and the only things you can interact with are the things that progress you through the story. This might make some people lose interest, but because the story is quite immersive, it makes up for the linearity. Combat is pretty straightforward since you only have 3 options: punch, kick, or dodge. You'll then be able to equip special powers into combo strings, which can help you hit harder, heal yourself, or even grant special ability cooldowns. You gain all of these as you progress through the game, and each chapter practically (and conveniently) introduces a new element up until the finale. Animation is rather fluid and satisfying to watch, making for a rather entertaining experience whether you're playing or watching the game. Controls are a bit wonky at times though, but the game is quite forgiving and leaves you at a place close to where you left off in the event that you die. Camera angles can get a bit weird too, but only in certain spots without any events going on at the time. Overall a great experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Remember Me brings to the table an absolutely sublime world known as Neo Paris. The designers have gone all out to craft a world that feels believable but is nevertheless, bursting, with novelty and creativity. Life has been brought to this world by a first rate graphics engine and texture art that produce stunning lighting and sharp detail. The score also merits special mention. Holding everything together is a fairly engaging story with a few surprises up its sleeve. Gameplay includes some novel elements (memory `remixing' and the combo lab, for example) that keep things feeling fresh and made the experience enjoyable--even for someone not usually fond of the `brawler' genre.The main shortcoming of the game is that it holds your hand too much. Everywhere you go, the next move you need to make is pointed out by an obnoxious orange arrow. Hesitate for just a moment during a boss fight, and a window pops up telling you exactly how to exploit the enemy's weakness. This excessive mollycoddling ultimately detracts from the player's sense of agency, making those gorgeous environments feel even more linear than they actually are.My advice: buy the game and enjoy the scenery. Just don't expect Skyrim.My playtime for a leisurely playthrough of this game: 13 hours.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												A cyberpunk vision of Paris, France. Remember me is breathtakingly beautiful, from the neon-lit labyrinth of the ghettos to the beautiful Saint-Michel district, almost every location feels like it should have been part of some big-budget animation somewhere. You will find no shortage of dramatic camera panning here. As soon as you walk into a new location and you can be certain you will be presented the eye-candy architecture of this world.Though as beautiful as it is, it is just as dramatically short. With about 7-8 hours of gameplay, you will find yourself on a very direct set of rails, with little to no ability to explore this world. But this shortcomming is made up with a well constructed storyline, an amazing soundtrack, and supringingly unique game mechanics. Bottom line: I'd recommend it, but its probably because I god damn love me some cyberpunk.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												If you want a picture of the future, imagine a hand ripping out human memories - forever.Remember Me envisions 2084 as a time when human memories can be manipulated like any physical item, and as such are bought, sold, traded, stolen, etc. much as physical items are. You control Nilin, a "memory hunter" - one with the power to manipulate human memories, up to and including large-scale rewrites. Recently wiped of most of her memories while in prison, she escapes and begins fulfilling tasks set to her by the Errorist known as Edge - a mysterious man who seeks the destruction of the privileged upper class the memory technology has created.---So, first off, the character design in this game is a bit lacking. Nilin isn't bad, but there's not a whole lot to really like about her, and no character, overall, is developed a whole lot - not helped by the fact that, due to the theme of memory manipulation, the whole concept of "character development" is harder to apply here.The art style is well-done and the text design, in particular, is fantastic. Less can be said about the music, but at least it's not annoying. On a recommendation, I played with French voice acting, and I can pass on the recommendation - even if (like me) your knowledge of French is spotty at best, it helps with the recreation of the Neo-Paris atmosphere.The gameplay...I mean, it's linear, and the combat system clearly has a lot of thought put into it, but gets rather repetitive regardless. Neither is inherently bad, but usually those are used in conjunction with a game focused on story, and that's where Remember Me falls a bit short.The real killer is that the story premise is really quite interesting. Unfortunately, with the relatively short length and lack of character development, most of that potential doesn't go anywhere, and (very minor potential spoilers) the fascinating ethical questions of memory manipulation are essentially tossed aside in favor of a sappy "people are not complete without their sorrows" aesop. Not at all what the asking price suggests about the game.I still enjoyed my time with Remember Me, and if all of this has kept your interest so far, I'd advise you to give it a try (probably on sale, though). But if you're having your doubts? Nah.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Wow...This has to be the most visually stunning games I have ever played, but I won't lie and say the game play is flawless because it's not.  Combat is like an 'Arkham City wanna-be' but comes nowhere near the fluid motion of any of the Batman games.  But if you can get past the first few levels and upgrade your combos it's not so bad.  Actually once I quit trying to play it like Arkham and started playing it for what it was, I started to come around to the combat and enjoy a tad bit.  There are also plenty of platforming moments that are all pretty easy.  They mostly serve to break up the gameplay and show off a wider view of the levels, and let me tell you.....The world of Remember Me is the reason you want to play this game.  When you move from point A to B don't RUN...hold back on the thumbstick a bit and WALK and soak in every bit of the detail.  These guys have made one of the most beautiful games I have ever seen in my life.  The level to detail is staggering and is Remember Me's greatest asset.  That being said, I do wish they would have went the Splinter Cell route instead of the Arkham City route and had more focus on stealth.  This could have been the Starcraft Ghost that we never got.  Can you imagine?!?!?  Oh well, it's still a beautiful game and well worth a playthrough, especially if your a little burnt out on the same ol', same ol' Call of Duty or whatever mainstream game that usually takes up your time.  Do yourself a favor and give it a chance.  It doesn't cost much and worse case scenerio you just don't like it.  I think if you open your mind and look past the clunky combat, and look at the world instead you'll find it's actually damn good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												I think the story of the game is unique but slow.  It's a shame to me how such a beautifully made world is limited to explore.   Our protagonist, Nilin, seems well rounded in character.  However, going back to being able to exploring the world, it seems odd how she can jump such great distances and parkour like a boss, yet she can't hurdle a 2ft wall.  The world is also not very interactive.  Only the items that will help you progress in the game's story (besides the boxes that boost your health and focus) can be interacted with.  I was expecting a reaction out of some of the robots when I punched or kicked them...nothing.  The same thing happens with the NPCs in Slum 404.  One thing that is a plus and minus is the camera angles.  When it comes to the parkour, some of the POVs are very helpful. Sometimes I couldn't see where I was supposed to jump to next because the computer took over my camera and I had no control of where I was looking (also happens when trying to get a glimpse at the surrounding city).  The architecture is amazing, and it's very hard to admire it because you see only what the designers want you to see.  If you want to play a CyberPunk game that is unique, play this one.  It is fun, but be warned that there is not a lot of freedom in where you go and what you can interact with.  It's good to play through once.  I don't see a point in playing through it again (unless you really want those pesky achievements).  Honestly, a bit of side questing, more interaction with the environment, and a bit more freedom would give this game a much higher replay value.  Just a thought if these developers ever read these things (highly doubt it).  Other than that it's a pretty good game...but for $30, wait until it's on sale.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												Remember Me is a game bursting with promise. The stunning visuals of Neo-Paris are an appropriate backdrop for amnesiac "memory-hunter" Nilin to leap and fight against, and several unique gameplay mechanics set this game apart from similar titles. Unfortunately, the game never really reaches its full potential. Gameplay is entirely linear, leaving the player feeling more like they're just along for the ride rather than making meaningful choices, and while the storyline hints at some fascinating concepts, the exposition seems rushed and skims over much of the deeper context that really would have brought this world to life. Nonetheless, Remember Me is a great game that brings something new to the table, and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys games that have some complexity and story to them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												In a sentence, "The Giver" with a twist.This is, first and foremost, a thoughtful title, a provocative title. From the look and feel of its world to its story and music--to even its journal system, where you can read entries on the history of the world, and be notified of "how many people remembered" and "how many people forgot." It's been described to me as an amazing 7/10 title. I thought that fit quite nicely. It's also one of the better sci-fi movies I've watched in awhile.To clarify, by sci-fi, I mean a movie that uses science-fiction elements to ask a philosophical question about the things that make us human. In this case, the question is about memory.Having said that, my biggest complaint with the game is that certain combat puzzles range from "oh, that's fun" to "WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥ DO YOU WANT ME TO DO."I really, really, really hate quick-time events, especially in a world as beautiful as this one. That aside, I wish there had been more thoughtful puzzles involving memory manipulation, even though every manipulation event made me feel very uncomfortable--like I was violating someone's private space.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												It's difficult to give this game a thumbs down, but it's also difficult to reccomend - especially to anyone familiar with action fighting games. Remember Me has great artistic direction and interesting philosophical ideas, but an extremely lackluster combat system and hand holding platforming hold it back immensly. It ends up being a game that would have felt better as a film.Combat is the biggest issue - it starts with the interesting idea of customizing combos for the use of different abilities. Unfortunately, these customizations are actually rigid - you repeat the same four combos over and over as follows (xbox controls):XXXYXYXYXYYXYYYYYYXXXXYYou can change what each button press does (extra damage, self healing, special cooldown), and activate five specials to combat enemies. The one redeeming quality is that the specials have a tactical use against the varying enemy types, which I eventually enjoyed. My personal problem was that this payoff only came from the repetion of those combos - it is droll. TL:DR - If you just like story, this game is cool, put it on easy. If you want solid gameplay, seek elsewhere.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												A fun, if linear, action game with an interesting, if convoluted, story. Great graphics and wonderful art direction are a high point. Sometimes boring/frustrating combat. Combat can devolve into button mashing if you arent careful, but even then the extent of the combat system is use one of the same 4 combos all the time and hit "A"  to dodge every attack.The game is quite linear, and it seems like you're almost on rails for most of it. There are hardly any detours from the main path and not much to explore in this beautiful world. Would have worked marvelously as an open world game with some parkour mechanics such as those in Mirror's Edge. The existing climbing and jumping feels somewhat stiff and not as fluid as, say, the Assassin's Creed series, and for being such a big part of the game, I wish there was more to it than following the premade linear path.Also of note is difficulty. I beat the game on Hard with only a few sections that made me angry. It seems the combat is either you're good at it, or you hate it.The memory remix sections were really cool but underutilized in my opinion. I'd like to have more of them. Cool soundtrack as well.6.5/10. Recommend for one playthrough, but there will be little to bring you back after that.Pros:+Graphics+Art Direction+Cool Soundtrack+Low-ish difficulty (could be a con to some)+Story Heavy+Strong Female ProtagonistCons:-Repetitive combat-Convoluted story that is sometimes difficult to follow-Very Linear-Not much replay value-Camera can be your worst enemy at times-Somewhat stiff climbing/jumping

												Remember Me offers a downright stunning cyberpunk Paris environment, interesting lead character and a gripping first few minutes of gameplay. Sadly the game's potential is squandered by a terrible camera, mediocre button-mashing combat, linear/repetitive climbing sections and somewhat hammy dialogue. The saddest part of Remember Me is that the game feels like it could've been an enduring cult classic with some more polish. It's enjoyable enough and worth picking up on sale for the absolutely gorgeous visuals and interesting premise, but I don't see myself going back to play it again in the future.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												The camera is iffy, the controls can be annoying, and the animations sometimes plod. Those are nitpicks however. Remember Me builds an immediately engaging world and fills it with interesting enemies, fun allies, and most of all new and interesting mechanics. Utilizing the manipulation of memory is the name of the game and it does it well, using it as a shorthand for superpowers in combat, and doing something truly remarkable elswhere. While by no means perfect, the world building is there, the writing is there, and the ingenuity is there. It's worth a play for game mechanics alone, but the story should pull you along as well.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I got this game as a bonus for a Humble Bundle so from my perspective it was essentially free.  That being said I feel like I overpayed.Do you like button mashing?  Do like linear gameplay? Do you like absurdly frustrating boss fights that result in you uninstalling the game (I can't be the only one).  If so this game may be for you.Aesthetically speaking I like it. The visuals are gritty and twisted, the style is mostly contigous. The story leading up to the first boss was definitely intriguing, the concept has potential. This however is the unrealized version of these things.The combat is in fact dreadful. Yes you can technically "craft your own combos" but what that really entails is struggling through an undescribed, unintuitive interface to select between different versions of the same thing, the only thing that really matters is that you can consistently hit the dodge button. This part was somewhat expected and so I was starting to overlook how tedious and unfulfilling the combat was, I mean hell I was on a role.  Then it happened...So I alluded to it previously but when you are building your combos in the interface different buttons map to different moves.  You don't get a legend or explanation for which button is which move however and in fact they are represented by these little symbols.  Meh, after getting your face eaten a few times you can manage to pull off one of the two combos you've created and then repeat until the battle is over.  Then you get to the boss, suddenly the tone changes from futuristic memory thieves to what might as well be wrestling, it's that over the top.  At first you even get to follow the same lack luster combat techniques used for previous encounters and then suddenly ... horribly ... in order to proceed ... you must respond to quick time events (okay you're saying, that's not the end of the world) but instead of the events being dictated with something you could recognize they are instead flashed on the screen as the cryptic symbols from the combo configuration screen.  So basically you have a fraction of a second to attempt to correlate that little symbol with one of the buttons on whatever device you may be controlling the game with, good luck.♥♥♥♥ this, ♥♥♥♥ them, ♥♥♥♥ quick time in general, but especially ♥♥♥♥ this cryptic♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t quick time that demands you memorize their little crappy symbols and how they map out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												Remember Me is one of those games that had incredible potential but squandered it with weak, nonsensical storytelling and broken game design.At it's core, Remember Me is a linear, story-driven action-adventure game of a sort we don't commonly see anymore. Think Enslaved: Odyssey to the West and you'll have a pretty good idea what you're getting yourself into. Unlike that game though, Remember Me takes place in a cyberpunk future where the world is dependent on devices called Sensen's that monitor and control memories. This along with several global disasters have created a society where memory is entirely controlled by a corporation called Memorize and while the rich are doing fine, the poor are left broken, living in slums and occasionally losing their minds, becoming what the game calls Leapers because reasons.You play as Nilin, a former rebel who has had her memories erased and now must listen to a mysterious voice in her head telling her what to do. She has the special power to "remix" people's memories, essentially altering details to change the outcome and thus, alter a person's thinking.While all of this sounds like a pretty great concept, none of it comes together to make any sense at all. Rebels are fighting against memory control but have these Sensens implanted in them anyway? Why? The limitations of these machines aren't ever adequately explained either. The very first cutscene of the game says that it's basically a  big memory backup machine but it becomes very clear, very quickly that people actually lose the memories they backup. So it's really a mass storage? Later, it's implied that the machine acts as a big hive mind and shares everyone's memories with everyone but people constantly talk about how they've forgotten things. So, which is it?This wouldn't be such a big deal except altering people's memories is the primary form of combat throughout the game as well as a major plot device used several times. Nilin gets a move called Overload very early on that acts as a finisher but that implies that memories are being shoved into someone's brain and overloading it, right? But other times, she takes people's memories and that doesn't seem to affect her at all. Also, does this mean she's shoving her thoughts and memories into someone else? Wouldn't that tell the enemy what she's doing? Wouldn't that mean she forgets what she's doing? Again, never explained. This is only the start of the inconsistencies as the plot gets more and more absurd, sending Nilin into situations with plot holes large enough to jump through.Not only do the actions not make sense but the themes don't even tie together well. It's not much of a spoiler to say that the theme of the game revolves around memories and how losing them causes us, as a society and individuals, to lose our identity. Yet throughout the game, Nilin "remixes" people's memories almost without hesitation. The slight hesitation she does feel at times doesn't end up ever having any resolution either so the whole story winds up just feeling hypocritical.The plot's forgiveable though if the gameplay is alright. The game works as a mix of Uncharted-esque parkour sections and combat sections more than a little reminisce of the Arkham series. It becomes formulaic pretty quickly but it isn't too bad for the first half of the game due to the interesting style of customization. Combat works by executing different combos made up of the X and Y buttons (when using an Xbox gamepad which is HIGHLY recommended). The cool bit is that you can actually customize these combos by giving each button press a different effect. You can't change the pattern of X and Y buttons but you can make certain button presses more powerful, decrease your special attack cooldowns and even recover your health. You unlock these different "pressens" by gaining XP. It's a neat little system with a ton of potential. Throw in five special attacks you get throughout the game and even a gun with different abilities and combat can have a lot of variety.The problem is in how restrictive the combat becomes. At first, the enemies are basic enough where you can freely experiment with your different moves and it's decently fun, if not a bit repetitive after you find your groove. About halfway through the game though, it seems as though they ran out of enemy ideas so they made new baddies that only respond to one specific way of killing them. The worst are enemies that hurt you every time you hit them so you need to hit them with only regenerating pressens or else you'll lose health quickly. As regenerating pressens make your combos weaker, battles become extremely tedious and these enemies show up in very nearly every encounter. Suddenly, all of your customization plans go out the window as the developers force you down a single path.The parkour sections range from alright to downright boring and tedious as well. The game is extremely linear with only  minor exploration allowed (think Final Fantasy XIII's endless hallway). The developers tried to break up the monotony by sprinkling collectables throughout every level but since the game is almost entirely linear with narrow corridors, these are pretty easy to find if you give even a minor amount of effort.If you're still reading at this point, you're probably wondering why I haven't discussed remixing memories yet. It's the major marketing piece for the game and is the gimmick that was supposed to be what the game was known for, right? Well, yes, and to be honest, remixing memories was my favorite part of the game. These sections give you access to the persons memory seen as a recording. You cycle through the recording by rotating the joystick, making it feel like you're editing video frame by frame. You have to find certain memory bugs, displayed as visual glitches, which you can than activate to alter the memory slightly. These sections all have an objective so you need to find the specific glitches that will add up to give you the outcome you require. They clearly put a lot of work into these sections as each bug and combination of bugs activated can give you very different outcomes. One particularly memorable one allows you to alter a medical procedure resulting in the death of a variety of people, depending on what you choose to do.Some people will find these too base as the puzzles themselves aren't that challenging but I appreciated the variety of outcomes and enjoyed seeing the little nuances of each sequence. The biggest problem is that there are only four of these in the entire game and they are all plot determined. That's right, the gimmick that the game was marketed for barely lets you use it and never freely.Ultimately, Remember Me is a series of great ideas strung together with terrible implementation. Poorly made enemies, extremely linear gameplay, awful writing and a lack of the game's best feature make this a game to pass on.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												I will start off by saying that I would give 6/10 for the game. But let me explain. The one thing that I cannot praise high enough for me is the art style of the game. Everything in the game is really well polished and it is a pleasure to look at. It looks really modern and sci-fi without being too far fetched. The art canvas that are unlocked as you play the game are stunning and a good reward for the play through. Congratulations for the artists and designers for these. With regards to the story, I found the story at times captivating, at others (and most of the time, really) to be a bit obvious. But what I found most interesting was the philosophical discussions and the struggle of the main character when she is still recovering her memory. Having said that, the whole story is very linear. These two points for me were the highlights. Now, some parts of the game that could improve.Although I found the mechanic of allowing you to create your own combos, however limited, it was interesting enough to the point that changing it during a battle could prove very helpful. Having said that, I found the battles to be a bit repetitive and fairly easy. Once you get the mechanic of an enemy or a boss, even on the hard difficulty, it was still fairly easy. With regards to the puzzles like climbing walls, jumping at ledges, climbing pipes, etc, it was a bit simplistic and at times rather frustrating, because as the game is not open world sometimes there were inconsistencies where you can leap up 4 meters from ledge to ledge and sometimes you cannot climb a 2 meters wall where you KNOW there is something behind it. And for me, the most frustrating part was when I was looking for an item (such as health or focus) and because of the linear part, you end up exploring a bit in order to reach the item, which would involve entering rooms to check it out. But if you happen to enter a room that was going to move the story forward, sometimes the door would just close behind you and would not allow you to go back, hence, you will lose the opportunity to get the item. Unless you play the whole game again, because there is only one save slot and the game auto-saves. The memory remix mini-games were quite interesting, although, it is fairly simple to deduce how to solve, or if you are feeling like exploring the alternatives, just try everything, it won't take long for that and might have some interesting side-effects. These parts are very surreal which, again, congratulations to the art team. Overall, for me it was an interesting game and experience, but it felt like a one trip pony, i.e. once you play once, it's enough. The replayability of the game is fairly low, because the second time you play, there won't be much novelty, with the exception of getting the missed items because of locked doors behind you.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
Remember Me—a story set in Paris, about 65 years from now. The world has changed. Smart phones and tables have been replaced by Sensen: a device that links to people's brain directly and stores the memories. The giant corporation—Memores, or somesuch—that invented it now controls everything and is performing unethical experiments on humans.You are Nilin, a woman with a pretty body and ugly face; a ridiculously athletic memory thief, who after a binge drinking session in prison can't remember a damned thing. Your job is to fight the enemy, steal or edit people's memories, and do comical acrobatics on ledges of tall buildings.  Remember who you are... and to figure out why the world in 2085 decided to use batons instead of guns.---This game is fantastic. I forget how much I paid for it, but were I to price it, $40–$50 is fair. The setting, premise, and great visuals of the game hold it against a few glaring plot holes and arcade, comical feel in battles and movement.Cons:  Camera movement takes a bit to get used to  Several glaring plot holes and minor issues with characters. Even though your character feels compelled to actually destroy the enemies, it's not too clear why she'd feel that way and you're propelled through the plot simply because there's nothing else to do. You're saving a damaged world, but it's unclear your methods are correct.  There are sound issues in a couple of places  Most of the movement is done by leaping across ledges, with your Sensen showing where to leap next with a marker. So you're essentially pressing the button the game tells you to press—no thinking is involved.  A central battle dynamic is either kicking or punching your enemies. You can setup combos to regain health, reduce power cool down, or do extra damage. This allows for varying fighting styles, depending on which enemy you're fighting, but in most of the fights, instead of watching the enemy movement, I was looking at the bottom of my screen, trying to execute a combo. This has an arcade feel that I don't enjoy much and the fights in the game were lackluster button mashing marathons.Pros:  Great premise: the company who made brain-to-electronics interface now pretty much controls the world. Very plausible.  Believable and immersive setting: the "future" is depicted quite realistically (aside from no longer using guns). All signs and many devices now appear as holographic augmented reality. There are serious issues due to climate change. A giant corporation owns everything good that's left in the world.  Unique gameplay dynamic with respect to editing people's memories—I only wish there were more of that.  Great visuals.  The story is interesting to follow, and holds up despite a few holes and cliches.  Despite being a bit muddy, the characters are believable and aren't annoying.  Great variety with how to kill your enemies: you have configurable kick+punch combos, 5 powers, and sort-of-a-gun.In summation, I thoroughly enjoyed the game. It has several unique elements and a great story. It's worth the money and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												I've got many feelings about this game. First of all, Neo-Paris is beautiful and hideous at the same time, the environment that we get to play in is simply stunning. I just wish we could explore more of it, but we cannot, because the game is EXTREMELY linear. There were many places I wanted to access, but the game simply didn't allow me to. You have to follow the path it provides you with and it's painful. A game such as this should allow players to discover at least small bits of the city and interact with characters. Unfortunately that's not how it is. The second big con is that combat is very boring and repetitive at first. It gets more complex and involving once you unlock more powers. The combo system is pretty creative but still I ended up repeating the shortest ones, because long combos are difficult to land without being interrupted. You will come across different enemies, but the variety of them isn't astonishing. Now let's move on to the biggest pros of this game. Visually it's stunning, I loved the aesthetics. Another big advantage of this game is the wonderful music, I'm going to listen to it on regular basis, it's really beautiful. Finally, the thing that I liked the most about Remember Me is the story. The writers deserve a medal, because the plot is the reason why this world is so interesting. It unwinds slowly, but once it reveals all it's secrets-you will feel bad for all the characters. It's a story about sorrow and regret. Neo-Paris is an utopia, where the citizens begin to lose their humanity. It's so touching, but at the same time gives a lesson that bad things will be happening no matter what you do. Do I recommend Remember Me? Oh hell yes, but keep in mind that it's not a game for you if you enjoy exploration. It's a game that you should play just to go through the amazing story. Remember you soon!

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
TL;DRVisual: Brilliant. This game is GORGEOUS with a wonderfully realised and unique sci fi aestheticMusic: Interesting digitally 'corrupted' orchestral score. Fits very well with the visual aesthetic. Narrative: Interesting thought provoking, overall it is pretty great. It falls short of its potential however, removal of repetitive and lengthy combat sections to have story and world building more competently integrated with the combat would have made this game better.Combat: Competent, but distracting from the plot and needlessly pads out sections. Leaving trash mobs and focusing on plot centric combat would have been preferable. With all of the poor ratings this game received I was a little skeptical going in but the concept was too intriguing to pass up. The concept of playing with memories, backing them up, remixing them, and using them to alter what a person is, was something that I found very compelling. Remember Me does its world building surprisingly competently, with a brilliantly realised visual aesthetic in a cyberpunk dystopic Paris. This extends to the sound track, an orchestral score which is subject to digital artifacts which fits in very well with the overall tone of the game. It also takes the idea behind the technology and runs with it pretty well, seeing what may come of such a technology. I would have liked the game to have gone further with this instead of having such a focus on the combat. The combat is an odd choice, it forgoes guns altogether and sticks with a  hand to hand combat system with the player unlocking attacks which they then construct into custom combos which can then have modified attributes (attacks can deal extra damage, charge up special abilities or heal the player). While this plays well, it does lead to a strange situation where a dystopic corporately controlled security forces wont engage you with more than a baton. Taking guns away does allow more focus on the technology and the story, but perhaps if the game spent more time on the narrative and exploration and characterisation, and less on a combat system, the game would have been for it. This brings me to the biggest issue, the characterisation and story is shallower than the central premise would lead one to believe. This is a great shame as I think it could have been a masterpiece if the focus had been on a narratively driven game, rather than trying to have beat-em-up arcade combat worked into it as well. Overall it wound up surprising me however and I would recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												I constantly wanted to hug Nilin, and I am sure she would not appreciate that. Or maybe she remixed my memories...?Anyway, the story offers a few twists (surprising or not - depending on how familiar you are with storytelling techniques) and is, overall, well told and paced. Neo-Paris is a gorgeous setting, fusing the antique cityscape with high-tech architecture. Very beautiful to look at. Ambient sounds and voice acting add to the atmosphere.Characters behave consistently and have understandable motives. As Nilin has lost her memories, she starts to question her mission as she regains them, making for a good character arch.Moving through Neo-Paris works rather well, the controls are console-y, yet the animation is smooth and camera angles are well chosen, adding to the mood. Generously distributed hints make it quite clear where to go next. Climbing around felt great, like Assassins Creed and Mirrors Edge.Combat worked well for me, too. Challenging, but not frustrating. Some fights require special abilities to proceed - should you be stuck too long, the game offers help automatically. You can mix your own combos with moves that deal damage, heal yourself, or shorted the timers on the special abilities, allowing you to tailor fights to your personal style of playing. Around mid-game, the 3-step combo of healing and timer-resets was my favorite one... Moving around the combat area, attacking and evading enemies is well animated and very fluid.As you play a memory hunter, you get to tap into people memories, and re-arrange them so certain key events are remembered differently. It is a nice integration into the game, and could have happened more often.While the game has a good flow, it is linear. There are no choices in the dialogues, and no choices regarding the actions of Nilin. On the other hand, this allows you to follow the storytelling a bit easier.Annoying bug: the audio system does not play certain sounds; I had to change my sound card configuration to stereo (from 5.1), then the in-game HUD messages played. Still some cutscenes were silent for me - activate subtitles, so at least you know what everyone is talking about.As the game is not overly long, you might want to wait for a discount. Especially on the Combo DLC, which gives you a few additional moves to add (I would not feel they are worth 4 EUR extra). Then if you play the game: give Nilin a hug from me.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This game is overall very good, but it has some flaws.Story itself is interesting and has some good plot twists. It is told through cut-scenes, and dialogs and monologs while you walk/run/parkour around areas. Characters are well done as well. The setting of the game is spectacular. Neo-Paris is just beautiful and every area is gorgeous and unique. I have played at max settings and every corner of the game was just amazing. After many games I finally felt that it was actual a city with people living in it instead of just place for hero to beat the bad guys. Music was fitting and well executed, especially when you walked into a place where you could see Neo-Paris in its glory, then special music started playing and you just had to enjoy that view.As for the gameplay, for myself it was not the best, but still very enjoyable. Fighting was not easy and you had to pay attention or your health went down quickly. Unfortunately camera was mediocre at best. Sometimes it would be doing exact opposite of what you would have wanted. Fighting could get a bit repetetive even though you can make your own combos, but that basically just change whether you hit opponent harder or you heal yourself or make cooldowns faster. But I did enjoy boss fights which were each different and challenging. They are QTE in the end sequences, i like those, but some might not feel the same. But especially in later stages of the game I was almost forced to run around and just dodge enemies because attacking them would be the end of me.Your character throughout the game unlock special abilites that you can use in combat to gain an advantage. Every ability is different and gives you the edge in some area of combat. You also unlock abilities outside of combat to help you get around the enviroment. Parkour and freerunning is done really well. Always jumped where I wanted to and it was easy and intuitive to use.There are also some riddles to get your brain going. Some are easy some are a bit difficult.But the best part of the game was pretending to be a DJ :D Remixing memories is a cool ability that allows you to change memory of your victim. You tinker with little things, and people and enviroment reacts accordingly, rendering new outcomes. You must ultimately accomplish what game asks you to, but you can get different results while remixing and get even achievements for doing so. If you "mess" up, you just rewind and change some things again and new possibility awaits! Great feature, but unfortunately there are only couple of them :(To summarize my experience: It is a beautiful game with a good story and some great gameplay ideas, okay combat and sometimes annoying camera. It is about 8 hours long on normal difficulty.I would give it 8/10Remember you soon...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2013
												This game is probably one of the underrated of 2013 I have had the pleasure of coming across. The game is not perfect or the best of, but rather is a balanced mix of things. It touches upon a few elements over the course of the game; brawling, exploration and scaling heights and ledges, puzzles, and an interesting memory remix element.I feel if one tries to dig too deep into or wants exclusivity on any of the things the game brings to the table, I feel that is where most disappointment comes in. It is true there are other games out there that do any of its elements better and with more depth, but Remember Me does a decent job of blending these together and telling a story of a world that has fallen from trying to find ways to be perfect in this digitized memories society. This is a game where one needs to take everything in equally and not in pieces.Remember Me is a living form of art. The level design, ambience, culture, scenery, sounds, and music, it's all gorgeous. I have found myself stopping to admire what a world these folks have shared. The ride I was brought along on was quite satisfying from start to finish. Combat in the game is pretty basic, but has intereresting ways to change your combo sets to inflict damage, heal, reduce cool-downs, and chain up previous hits for an added bonus. You also learn other abilities along the way that utilize focus, a type of energy you build up as you damage opponents, and nicely enough, when they damage you, too.The game has an intriguing plot that I was interested in following the whole way through. Plenty of things in-game give you stuff to read up on for subjects not quite explained or just to get more in-depth information on. It's not a long game by any means. One could probably get at least 10 hours from it. Possibly more if you're like me and like to take in the details now and then. Despite this, though, the length felt about right for the direction the story was going. It's a linear game, but that is no flaw by any means. While there is no true freedom of open-world exploration, it's not needed for the type of game this is. In any regard, there is plenty to see and experience along the way if such a thing is not a deal breaker.Normally, I sometimes tend to wait on games for prices to drop as I tend to have a lot on my plate to need to worry about getting any new ones right away. But, I admire the developers of this title for pushing to have a female lead and struggling to find a publisher that would take this game seriously. The sad story was that most turned them down because they felt the game would not do that well. I would look around online for stories about this. I wanted to support them for their efforts and give this game at least a bit more attention than it's currently getting. I really hope to see more of this universe as I can see quite a bit going for it. I normally also don't don't recommendations like this, but this is the first time I really felt compelled to. I hope this little gem finds your way to your collection, should you feel it would be one deserving of such an honor.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												This game brings nothing spectacularly new to the table. What it does is very much what Tomb Raider 2013 did; Refine existing ideas. Remember Me doesn't do that quite as well as Tomb Raider did, in my opinion, but it's certainly not a title to miss. The story, is good. Cheesy, but good. Graphically, this game is gorgeous. The set pieces are astounding, and the art and camerawork, mix with the music to give a very Scifi Movie vibe. This art direction and music direction are very consistent throughout the entire game.Nilin the Memory HunterSpeaking of the music, Remember Me features dynamic fight music. Landing a combo successfully on an enemy will cause the music to play louder and more naturally, while getting hit, or losing too much health will cause it to degrade to just the basic beat, or sound like it's "glitching out". This creates a sort of reward for doing well, and when the music starts hitting it's high points, and you're on a roll, it feels amazing. The music is on a whole other level. It's a mix of Classical string and brass with digital beats and Synth effects. It comes off as epic, and distorted but in such a way that it accentuates the story.Madame FightAnd now about the combat... I feel the combat is good. There are a few things that cause me to dislike fighting in the game, but it's mostly just annoying enemy types, or too many enemies attacking at once. If I had to sum up the combat in this game I'd say it's like Batman's but the enemies don't wait, or take turns. For some, this is great, and it seem more realistic, but from a gameplay perspective, I feel it adds unneeded frustration.The FightYou play as Nilin, a Memory Hunter, who's memories, ironically, have been stolen. You wake up in a lab, and someone from your past, named Edge, is trying to help you escape being turned into a human vegetable. The story is dark, and while much of it can be seen from a mile away, I felt there were a few good twists here and there. Some of the acting is a bit cheesy, but I'm usually a fan of cheesy acting, and storylines.Combat MusicThe setting is Neo Paris. Pretty much what would happen if Paris became Taris from Knights of the Old Republic. Grungy under-city, and posh higher society areas create a contrast-heavy universe where it's never hard to tell where you are. Things in the environment feel lived in as well as alive. Beams. shutters, pipes, holographic screens, people, wind. Everything is animated, and feels like it's right where it belongs. The lighting is another thing of note. This is one of the prettier Unreal Engine games of last gen. It seems like the developers, even though fairly new, had a deep understanding of UE.Title ThemeIf you're in the mood for a dark, scifi game with a pretty unique and engaging setting, then I would say this is 100% for you. The developers put a lot of work into this one, and it deserves far more than what it got in sales. It's not perfect, but it's great.Our ParentsAfterthoughts:I want another game in the same vein, or even in the same world of Remember Me. Neo Paris is just too cool and the vibes I get from the music are intense. It's the perfect playground for a Deus Ex-style game. ;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												TL; DR: Buy it on sale. I would recommend any price ~$15 or lower (I got it for $12.50) if you like good stories or beat-em-ups.For those inclined to actually read into the details, I enjoyed this game, but let me get into why:This game is in fact a beat-em-up. Not so much in the vein of the recent Batman games, but the combat is at least a little less vanilla than batman.During combat, Nilin (the protagonist) has combos that she uses to take down enemies. The lower level enemies can be simply taken down with basic combos, but different levels of commanders normally accompany these grunts. Most of the commanders cannot be taken down directly and most of the time require a little bit of ingenuity to dispatch using Nilin's Sensen abilities. In short, when she fights or gets hit she gains focus meter (very similar to meter found in most fighting games) that allows her to do very strong abilities to help eliminate enemies. Most of the first playthrough you'll be using these on a *need* basis moreso than out of convience. However, you can upgrade the amount of meter you can hold and thus allows you to speed up progress. On this subject, you'll be fighting one of about 5-6 kinds of bosses, most of which can be eliminated using the same tactics. Two pairs of bosses you'll fight will be identical--they can be eliminated exactly the same. It is a little stale, but there's about 8 boss battles, so you're not missing out on too much.Most of the bosses do require a certain combonation of abilities and moves. Don't be worried if you cannot figure out the formula as the game will happily point out an exploit, and you can go on your merry way.The story is nice: it's not going to be the next Hollywood film or anything but there were a couple of twists in there that were appreciated. The story did seem to drag on towards mission 7 (out of 8) but quickly picked up for the final mission.Hidden items: There are a few. One of them increases health and is quite common while the other increases the meter mentioned earlier. The last is nonbenificial and is a hidden item for the sake of being a hidden item.Overall: It's an RPG meant for the modern crowd. I would sort of compare it to the latest Deus Ex in that it is dumbed down quite a bit but unlike Deus Ex this game is stupidly linear. This game was a fun experience: since I just completed my first playthrough I plan on gettng the hidden items and then leaving the game alone. I would expect ~15 hours after all unlockables and that should be that. TL; DR #2: Buy it for cheap. Good, but not exceptional.

												     An outstanding work of interactive audio and visual art.  Although I do NOT normally play third person perspective games, this one was well worth the time and money.  If you are Deus Ex and/or Fallout 3 fan then, you will love this!  This games' story line is linear, very well thought out, and will not disappoint.  And, the graphics are just amazing!  In fact, I look forward to playing it again to accomplish more the achievements.     There have been many complaints about the controls.  I am a PC gamer who uses a keyboard and mouse.  The controls felt good and worked just fine.  They (the controls/visual perspective) took some time to get used to but, once familiar the enemiy attacks are fun to  dodge and avoid.  If you are using a game controller, this game will definately test your hand/finger coordination,  dexterity, and stamina!  In my opinion, the controls are fine and work very well for this game.     Excellent Game!  5 Stars!

It's not that she was really difficult, moreso the last quick time event wasn't working for me--the prompt says to press the dodge button, so I do, but she just throws me back into the phase two fight again and again. I tried holding the button, pressing the button gently, spamming the button, and even rotated the analog stick while spamming in a desperate attempt to get past that point, but nothing. It might have something to do with my SteelSeries controller, but I had no problem with the game up until that point. It's a shame, really. All the same--Remember Me is definitely worth checking out if you enjoy a good beat-em-up.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2013
												A decent game that is worth playing for the graphics, mood, and story alone.  Indeed, the game is more like a very long movie that you are allowed to interact with.  The little touches bring the city to life.  It's not often that a game claims the setting is in x and actually puts little x touches in it.  In this case it's Paris and there are French accents from the deco, to the words on papers, to the food everywhere.They have also managed to create very believable cast of characters that you want to know more about.  They have a depth of feeling and drive that certainly make them interesting and support the story.The game, though, does have it's faults.  The customising the combos isn't really custom beyond chosing what type of hit or kick it is and even then it's no control on the stype of hit or kick.And there is the actual game glitches.  There seem to be issues with graphs to sound for almost everyone that either have to be fixed before the game is played, suffered through, or stop the game from playing at all.  However, we are not in the late 90's when games had to be released with perfection or die and many games suffer from this.  In comparison to other games, they are minor glitches.The saddest part of this game though, is the length.  I could have used more game play and there were parts of the story that could have been filled in to do this.  Such as parts between episodes could have been fleshed out to give more hours of gameplay and deeped the story building.Overall though, a good game and I look forward to more from this developer.

												This game had quite a great story to go through. Your character has had their memory removed and they are as puzzled as to what is going on as you are. The fighting in the game is fluid for the most part but sometimes with the amount of enemies they add the combo system can become fairly annoying to get a full chain. The boss fights are all fairly unique. Each boss fight ends with a quick time event of you kicking, punching, jumping, or actioning at the right time but if you fail you just have to fight the boss a little longer and try again. Overall, the games story is what will pull you in on this game. The fighting will keep you around.So, what is wrong with it? This is what you really want to know. There are two issues I would like to call out. The first is memory remixing. You only remix a few memories in the game. It is one of the coolest things about the game but it is used only for certain characters. It was kind of a let down when I found this out. The other is that the game is too linear. You are in this big city and trying to get from point A to point B. There is only one path and it is always going to be obvious what it is. They hold your hand and throw in a few if you don't jump quickly you fall and have to start over sections to spice it up. Even with this it is worth the play through for the story.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												This game does a good job with familiar game mechanics while presenting a really good looking, futuristic environment and a good story.This version of the future has everyone with a special device installed in the back of their heads.  The device allows them to see virtual signage (lots of which you'll see), selectively replay memories, or purchase new ones to experience for themselves.  The main character, Nilin, is a memory hunter, an agent who infiltrates or invades different environments in order to steal or alter the memories of a target person, usually to influence big business to the benefit of the client.  This is a cool and strange consequence of the whole memory market that this game presents.  Things go wrong when Nilin wakes up in prison without her memories, a common punishment in this society.The two main aspects of the game are, simply put, fighting and athletic traversal.  Thankfully, you're never doing both at once.  There's really nothing to the athletics.  You guide the Nilin to predetermined holds along ledges, walls, and ladders, trying to get to the next point in the story.  Points to grab on to are highlighted nicely.Fighting is an assorment of strikes done via predetermined combinations of X and Y buttons, as well as some super powered maneuvers that you earn throughout the story.  Interesting, though, is you assign different punches and kicks to your combos for one of three effects: damage, health recovery, or super recovery.  Customising these combos is a nice little puzzle.  And getting the results you want in combat--like recovering health by striking weaker opponents and maximizing damage on harder opponents--is really satisfying.  Frustrating, though, is the inability to spread the combo among multiple targets; changing targets mid-combo means you have to start the combo over.  (Personal side note: lots and lots of games are relying on guns to defeat enemies, often addining a minimum number of gimmicks.  It's very cool to see all the martial arts and hear different things besides tired gunfire.)Different enemy types and different super maneuvers eventually make combat more and more interesting and challenging.  It's fun, but doesn't drastically change the genre.Somewhat changing the pace are sections where you play through a person's memory, rewinding as necessary, to manipulate certain predetermined aspects with the goal of changing the person's conclusion about the event.  These are amusing, since changing certain things can cause different outcomes that don't represent a solution and yet you still get to see the result anyway.  Mildly entertaining; neither welcome or unwelcome.Overall, gameplay should be familiar for avid game players and the real draw should be the environments and story.  I really felt the desire to understand who Nilin was and why her mysterious benefactor placed such an importance on her mission.  All the while, seeing all the ultra modern society made it really cool and inviting.  Shamefully underated; recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is really, really good fun. The fluid, graceful chaining of moves and dodging feels very tight. I'm not having any difficulty playing this with mouse and keys, but some may prefer the controller. First boss battle was not overly difficult, but challenging enough to feel a sense of triumph when succeeding.The environment is stunning. Rich, full of detail and ambiance. The pace of the story is good, I'm only a few hours in as of this writing and I feel drawn in. The first "re-write" of a persons memory...what a great way to handle it. From the mouse input feeling so natural to "scrub" through the memory timeline, to the great visuals...very well done.Traversing the environment is not anything super-amazing, but it's well done enough and handled decently. Your moves are executed confidently and appear natural and smooth. This is not "Mirror's Edge" so don't expect over-the-top parkour. Your acrobatic moves during combat will make up for it.Combat may at first appear shallow, but there is some depth to be found for the patient seeker. Finding your pace and timing in combat feels really good when you get into the groove. Evading, flipping over an opponent to continue a chain, rapidly switching targets to maintain control all feel rewarding. Winning a fight against multiple opponents feels like an accomplishment, not just the result of random button mashing.I always reccomend watching gameplay videos and watching/reading plenty of reviews before making a decision to purchase. Chances are, if you like the dystopian/cyberpunk genre, this game will appeal to you.It goes without saying, people are different, they like different things. Some will hate this game, some will love it and others will be ambivalent. I can only say that I'm having a lot of fun playing it, and I think it's an experience worth your time and money. Some may disagree, but in my opinion this game is an underrated gem and I'm glad I picked it up.Thanks for reading, and Good Gaming.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I cautiously recommend this game.  The story is interesting, but unremarkable, in contrast to the graphics which are impressive, but underservered by the very linear levels.  The game has a nice variety of enemies, of varying [imposed] difficulties, that seem to exist more to draw out the limited gameplay, rather than as a real challenge (I'm looking at you Elite Enforcer!).  But it is the controls that will be your greatest foe in this game.  They are, at best, dodgy, and at worst (particularily when trying to target a particular enemy with ranged attacks), unresponsive.  Boss fights will require a peek at a walkthrough to understand what you are supposed to be doing, but it's the mass fights in increasingly confined spaces that will cause you to walk away from the game, thanks to the inaccuracy of the controls.  The idea of remixing memories is interesting, but only occurs a few times in the game, and is as logical as a '90s Sierra game, and will probably come down to trying random combinations, or just looking at a walkthough.It's not a bad game, but has too many problems to be more than a decent game.   Buy it on a sale if the graphics appeal to you.
