												Remember Me is a great third person, parkour, fighting game. This game is bassed in the distant year of 2084 where everyone has a device called sen-sen which lets you remember everything, upload and share their memories on the net, as well as remove unhappy or unpleasant memories. But this sen-sen device also can turn people into leapers, which are memory-addicted people who have absorbed too much memories which makes their sen-sen degrade and makes them mutate into a subhuman form. Nilin's ( the character you play as ) job is to destroy sen-sen to stop the leaper plague.This game is full of plot twists, has a unique fighting style, a great sound track and a great moral to it

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I bought this game on launch because I'm a sucker for a unique setting and art direction.  I was not disappointed.  This game is a great visualisation of Neo-Paris later this century, its very different but fully fleshed out environment was a great backdrop to a game which I thought was quite interesting.  The combo combat was quite different - especially for the PC - while especially the main character but all the characters made me care about them a lot more than most games these days.  The protagonist was a multi-layered character and while the start of the game started with the whole 'I've forgotten everything' cliche: it makes sense in the context of this game unlike most games that trot this out.There were some patches where the game did get bogged down in repetitious combat, but on the flip-side, the boss battles were as interesting as fights that you'll see on the PC for a game such as this.  The combo customisation did keep things fresh, and there was just enough of a break-up between combat and platforming to keep me moving along at a rapid pace through the game.One of the few games I've bought on launch in the last couple of years, and even fewer still of games on launch that I've bought and not regretted the purchase.  I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												A nice game in the line of the "old school" french games, which were mostly focused on characters and ambience. Here, it's a success. The views are breathtaking, you feel you're in a coherent universe, every detail is tailored to make you feel like you're in that cyberpunk-ish Paris, ... And the character development, while it's not the most fantastic I've ever seen, is really worked on and can really catch you. You can easily feel some empathy for that amnesiac girl who doesn't know what the hell is happening. Some were critical about the gameplay itself. While it's no Arkham City, it's still pretty smooth and you quickly find yourself using various combos. It could have been more inspired, indeed, but all in all, it's far from bad. Actually, I'd see it more closer to a Skyrim than a Call of Duty. Not because it's an RPG like Skyrim, but because you don't only play Skyrim for the combat but also for the general ambience. Skyrim's combat system isn't so great, its main story isn't so great either, but that's not what you're looking for in Skyrim. Same goes here ! If you're looking for a great dystopian video game, you'll have what you want.Bonus point for an actual good main female character. For once, it's not a friggin' bimbo, nor is it a poor lost princess, or some big hulk. It's a refreshing change.Finished the game in around 9 hours in normal mode, but I didn't explore much (I wanted to finish the main storyline).

content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												This game undeservedly went under many radars, which it simply did not deserve. Remember Me is built quite linear, but it has some hidden things to find to keep you looking and enjoying the (mostly linear) visually beautiful level design. You simply have to adore the developer Dontnod's amazing mixed architecture style for Neo Paris. From time to time you will maybe encounter smaller problems with camera placement and the climbing passages are far too easy, thanks to an automatic system which shows you where you can hang on to or jump to.The combat system is combination based similar to the actual Batman game series, but with the unique twist of giving you the ability to design your own combos with different effects for different demands. Some very well implemented special abilities will also wait for you. The sound is pretty fitting and the music is also adaptive, which means that, for example, if you make a successful combo the music boosts up. Story wise the game is interesting enough, especially that it plays in the future where your thoughts can be harvested and even redesigned aka remixed, to keep you want to find out what the fuss about the main character Nilin is all about. I've played this game via a gamepad, because i just don't think that games like this should be played with a keyboard/mouse combo, simply because they aren't meant to be.Overall Remember Me looks good, sounds good and feels good ! Definitely worth any game collection.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												I'd recommend this game. Visually this game is stunning at times and the futuristic vision of Neo-Paris is awe-inspiring. There are some low-resolution textures there-abouts in the game that can take away from the beauty but in general, it looks fantastic. The main protagonist is a fairly interesting female character who is well voice acted, although there are a few choice lines from the script that can be off-putting. Her character has some abiguities at times with her morals and decisions, which I find intriguing and although the story was decent, I felt it had a much higher potential and could have gone deeper into some of the grey subject areas this game touched upon with memory manipulation. Quite a few of the antagonists, on the other hand, are a bit weak and encouters with them can be very cheesy. Voice acting beyond the main protagonists, such as random NPCs, can also be very weak.Combat is similar to the Batman system in that you punch, kick and evade enemy hits but it's different and a little less fluid. It differentiates itself with a unique combo system. You have four 3-8 hit combos that are fairly simple but what I like about this system is you can assign traits to each hit in the combo such as more damage, health gain, or regenerate your special ability. This allows you to customise combos to your needs and depending on how you trait yourself, it can make the difference between an impossible fight, a challenging one or even a simple one (on the hardest difficulty). The camera leaves much to be desired however and can sometimes impede your view of the fight, though evasion warnings are easy to spot and it's not necessary to keep your enemies in view at all times.The music is this game is probably the best part of this game. It is simply amazing throughout and a joy to listen to each piece during the credits.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Remember Me is a short game, but it might be one of the best that I've played in the past months. The story is very linear, and you should abandon any hope for decision-making right now, because you play basically along with the story. In fact, I fared pretty well (expectation-wise) as soon as I decided to see Remember Me as a story with several gaming elements instead of a game which also tells a story. Maybe a predictive story, but nevertheless an interesting and (at least for me) emotionally touching story. My opinion of the gameplay (apart from the story) is mixed: The fighting is fun; you get to design your own combinations by adding up different techniques, and the fighting itself is definite eye-candy. Controlling Nilin during everything else apart from fighting is a bit boring; the pathfinding system works maybe too well, climbing is no challenge at all, and have I mentioned already that you don't get to decide anything? The camera is not very helpful - I think that camera settings are well-made if you hardly notice that it is there at all. But in this game, I've tried countless times to change the perspective - only to find out that I could not. Other aspects:The graphics are beautiful. I could just play it again to look at the architecture, the streets, hell, even the advertisement managed to look interesting.The soundtrack is great, too - it captures the atmosphere of the game in general and of each scene in particular very well. I would recommend it to my friends (I already did) - but before you play it, please reconsider your expectations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
StoryFirst of all, Remember Me explores an interesting concept of controlling, remixing or deletingmemories that is available for anyone in the society. While at first, the user opens up to a glorious image of individuals being able to share their memories together, or being able to store the memories forever, there is a much darker side to the entire concept that is displayed throughout the events of the game. During the story, the player also explores the concepts of identity that is tied to our memories, as well as the conseqeunces of tampering with memories. The story itself isn't bad, it has its moments, and actually manages to pull off a few nice twists and turns. However, its downside is the horrible pacing of the game. Remember Me feels very slow and at times it can even be called boring. On the flipside, the latter parts of the game lift the story up a notch, but unfortunately the pacing still continues being an issue.GameplayThe combat within the game is unfortunately a pretty undeveloped concept. It revolves around mixing and matching different moves to create combos, unfortunately there are only four combos which ultimately makes this system too simple to actually make the combat worth remembering. Furthermore, the enemies are also very predictable and there really aren't any segments of the game that really challenge the player in regards to the combat. The game also features a large portion of climbing sequences which use a simplfied climbing system that  can be seen in almost any adventure game that came out within the last 10 years. The high point of the gameplay is the amazing design of Neo-Paris and its inhabitants that the user can explore, it is a feast for the eyes and any fan of cyberpunk should enjoy inspecting it. Overall, I think Remember Me is a good game, but with many ideas that could be further developed and explored. If you manage to persist through the uneven pacing and the somewhat uninspired combat system you may find yourself enjoying Neo-Paris and Nilin's story.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												If you want a picture of the future, imagine a hand ripping out human memories - forever.Remember Me envisions 2084 as a time when human memories can be manipulated like any physical item, and as such are bought, sold, traded, stolen, etc. much as physical items are. You control Nilin, a "memory hunter" - one with the power to manipulate human memories, up to and including large-scale rewrites. Recently wiped of most of her memories while in prison, she escapes and begins fulfilling tasks set to her by the Errorist known as Edge - a mysterious man who seeks the destruction of the privileged upper class the memory technology has created.---So, first off, the character design in this game is a bit lacking. Nilin isn't bad, but there's not a whole lot to really like about her, and no character, overall, is developed a whole lot - not helped by the fact that, due to the theme of memory manipulation, the whole concept of "character development" is harder to apply here.The art style is well-done and the text design, in particular, is fantastic. Less can be said about the music, but at least it's not annoying. On a recommendation, I played with French voice acting, and I can pass on the recommendation - even if (like me) your knowledge of French is spotty at best, it helps with the recreation of the Neo-Paris atmosphere.The gameplay...I mean, it's linear, and the combat system clearly has a lot of thought put into it, but gets rather repetitive regardless. Neither is inherently bad, but usually those are used in conjunction with a game focused on story, and that's where Remember Me falls a bit short.The real killer is that the story premise is really quite interesting. Unfortunately, with the relatively short length and lack of character development, most of that potential doesn't go anywhere, and (very minor potential spoilers) the fascinating ethical questions of memory manipulation are essentially tossed aside in favor of a sappy "people are not complete without their sorrows" aesop. Not at all what the asking price suggests about the game.I still enjoyed my time with Remember Me, and if all of this has kept your interest so far, I'd advise you to give it a try (probably on sale, though). But if you're having your doubts? Nah.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Wow...This has to be the most visually stunning games I have ever played, but I won't lie and say the game play is flawless because it's not.  Combat is like an 'Arkham City wanna-be' but comes nowhere near the fluid motion of any of the Batman games.  But if you can get past the first few levels and upgrade your combos it's not so bad.  Actually once I quit trying to play it like Arkham and started playing it for what it was, I started to come around to the combat and enjoy a tad bit.  There are also plenty of platforming moments that are all pretty easy.  They mostly serve to break up the gameplay and show off a wider view of the levels, and let me tell you.....The world of Remember Me is the reason you want to play this game.  When you move from point A to B don't RUN...hold back on the thumbstick a bit and WALK and soak in every bit of the detail.  These guys have made one of the most beautiful games I have ever seen in my life.  The level to detail is staggering and is Remember Me's greatest asset.  That being said, I do wish they would have went the Splinter Cell route instead of the Arkham City route and had more focus on stealth.  This could have been the Starcraft Ghost that we never got.  Can you imagine?!?!?  Oh well, it's still a beautiful game and well worth a playthrough, especially if your a little burnt out on the same ol', same ol' Call of Duty or whatever mainstream game that usually takes up your time.  Do yourself a favor and give it a chance.  It doesn't cost much and worse case scenerio you just don't like it.  I think if you open your mind and look past the clunky combat, and look at the world instead you'll find it's actually damn good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												I think the story of the game is unique but slow.  It's a shame to me how such a beautifully made world is limited to explore.   Our protagonist, Nilin, seems well rounded in character.  However, going back to being able to exploring the world, it seems odd how she can jump such great distances and parkour like a boss, yet she can't hurdle a 2ft wall.  The world is also not very interactive.  Only the items that will help you progress in the game's story (besides the boxes that boost your health and focus) can be interacted with.  I was expecting a reaction out of some of the robots when I punched or kicked them...nothing.  The same thing happens with the NPCs in Slum 404.  One thing that is a plus and minus is the camera angles.  When it comes to the parkour, some of the POVs are very helpful. Sometimes I couldn't see where I was supposed to jump to next because the computer took over my camera and I had no control of where I was looking (also happens when trying to get a glimpse at the surrounding city).  The architecture is amazing, and it's very hard to admire it because you see only what the designers want you to see.  If you want to play a CyberPunk game that is unique, play this one.  It is fun, but be warned that there is not a lot of freedom in where you go and what you can interact with.  It's good to play through once.  I don't see a point in playing through it again (unless you really want those pesky achievements).  Honestly, a bit of side questing, more interaction with the environment, and a bit more freedom would give this game a much higher replay value.  Just a thought if these developers ever read these things (highly doubt it).  Other than that it's a pretty good game...but for $30, wait until it's on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Remember Me is, at it's heart, an action-packed fighting-type game, but don't let that fool you; the interesting take on a 'cyberpunk' future is itself both visually stunning and extremely fresh. In a world where technology has managed to make people's memories more like flash drives, the world is severely corrupted and blinded to what makes them 'human'. As Nillin- a freedom fighter who's had most of her memory removed, you're trying to get your memories back and stop Sensen, the technology that has made these things possible. Nillin also has the ability to change people's memories herself, something that has a variety of consequences and makes for an extremely interesting gameplay mechanic. When you couple the action, unique vision and the emotionally charged story, it becomes a game more than worth checking out.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Very nice game. I didn't play this when it came out but I picked it up while on sale and it would have well been worth full price. This game reminds me of a mashup of Prince of Persia + Assasin's Creed. A really really really cool idea in this game is the "memory remix" puzzles, where you basically rewind time and mess with different objects and then press play and watch what happens. Moving different items at different times produces different results and you have to get the right order to cause the memory to continue with the desired outcome. I hate that there are so few of these because it is the standout feature of this game and I would jump to play a full game full of these types of missions.Fighting is not the main objective but basically a means of showing progression through the very interesting story. It has a unique although hard to get used to combat system, similar to the Assasin's Creed games although not so timed and it is harder to dodge. It has all the fun parkour of Assasin's creed with fun Prince of Persia style jumping puzzles.A great game I would definitely recommend. Perhaps it will encourage them to create a new game or reuse some of the aspects of this game in a future title.

												Got the game on sale. I made 12+ hours out of it (first playthrough on the hardest difficulty with no looking at guides). I say if you like cyberpunk you should take it. 												A great story and absolutely jaw dropping visuals (although texture and model quality falters under scrutiny) are offset by boring and frustrating fighting mechanics and overly easy to navigate platforming. Memory remixing is an incredible gameplay element that scratches the surface of interesting philosophical discussions; I wish they had more of that and less punching dudes in the face to regenerate health. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												I wholeheartedly recommend this game. It's one of those underdogs which never really got a real audience, despite receiving a fair amount of critical acclaim.The setting and the narration are very well done and manage to immerse you in the story and game, as well as motivating you to play on. The graphics are superb, making you pan you camera to either look at Nilin, the protagonist, or at the breathtaking scenery around you. The voice acting is superb, at least if you are lucky and wise enough to play it in English. If you are in doubt, I do recommend the English version - the voice overs for Nilin are very well done and render her as a vulnerable, reflecting person, despite the combat prowess she possesses.The only thing that bugged me are parts of the gameplay. Okay, it's a button masher game, at least on the easy difficulty setting, which I admittedly used. I wished to enjoy  the story without having frustrating moments of being beaten around in the combat scenes. But despite the easy mode, I still felt the game to be quite challlenging, which is probably due to my lousy reaction time. The quicktime-events in the boss fights surely made me growl, but luckily my memory is better than my button-mashing skill, so I simply memorized the correct keystroke-sequence.With combat being the defining gameplay element, I have to say that I found it annoying to be dumped into "arenas" for every fight, which kinda broke the immersion for me. Once you enter a fairly large enough room, you simply know there is a wave of enemies waiting to attack you. So you hop in, walk forward and then go through the ordeal, rinse and repeat until you stumble into the next large hallway.On the bright side, the player is prompted to alter "dreams" of other persons, meaning that you are called to juggle around bits and pieces of someones memories to make him or her believe in a different reality. With quite drastic consequences. I really enjoyed playing through these sequences, because it's been interesting and fun to watch the consequences of my"real time" editing of the dream sequence.But well, all said and done "Remember Me" is really worth playing:- If you enjoy a dark, cyber-punk setting. - If you enjoy good music, good voice acting and believable characters. - And if you are able to go along with a quite monotonous combat gamepleay.If you are still in doubt, just wait for the next sale and get. It's a sweet piece of eye candy and cyber-punk narrative, which gives you the chills as well as the faint feeling of sorrow that you have to part from your heroine once the credits come rolling down the screen.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												A fairly simple example of it genre, yes, but Remember Me is a rarity on the PC, as most adventure games of its type are console-only.  It may have its flaws; some hackneyed dialog, plot holes, linear level designs, but as a whole Remember Me offers a competant play experience. The environments are gorgeous. Neo-Paris is incredibly detailed to the point of being cluttered. There's just so much to look at -- even someplace as sterile as a prison.  Sadly, the linear nature of the levels makes exploring limited. Character designs are just as beautiful though. 3D models unlock with achievements for you oogling pleasure. This high detail makes cutscene trasitions near seamless. Combat is easy to grasp; one button to dodge and a variation of two other buttons to combo attacks.  A simple leveling mechanic allows to later customize and extend combos, adding a little strategy and depth.The most unique feature of Remember Me is the memory remixes -- changing a person's (victim's?) memory of a specific event to manipulate them. Remixes themselves are basically cutscenes which can be edited to change little details in the person's memory which compound into completely changing the outcome of the event.  This leads to the person's outlook or personality to completly change. Remixes also add some experimentation and replayability to the game, as there can be multiple outcomes in these manipulations. (only the 'right' way will progress the story though)Overall I recommend Remember Me. Its short length (about 8 hours) benefits the pacing of the game, as no chapter (level) feels slow or trodding, nor do the linear levels and combat feel too shallow.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Tomb Raider + Cyber Punk + Total Recall + FF Spirits within = Remember MeStory : 9/10 :I felt the story was good and enjoyable perhaps a bit linear as they didnt intend for this to be an aventure but more of an action game. It's a one , play once time story; but none the less a good story. Protagonist: 9/10:I personally Liked Nilin's personality she is a strong, confident woman and sometimes shows fear but unfortunatly keeps it quickly bottled up though...  It's hard to know more considering that her memory is wiped in the begining. I expected her to have a differnt reaction meeing her father though. He had a more expected reaction than she did. One thing I liked, is she knows she can fight and isn't afraid to show it.Voice Acting: 10/10I felt this was well done and engaging. Cost : 10/10 I feel that this was worth the experience and time put in.Music: 7.5/10 Music is good but it seems to get cool the dive off . I tend to hit hard here and be very critical. It wasn't til almost the end that I felt it became epic.Combat System : 7/10 : I felt they had something here but I realized that there is technically only 5 ways to activate a combo and I only used 4 of them as the 5th one was too hard to get off as enimies would swamp you in that time. When I realized that I probably wouldnt use the strongest and last combo, I just kept to the same patterns that worked .  Also I felt croud control to be the most challenging thing about the fights. they're a few guys that you have to think about how you kill but over all its more about crowd control more than anything and sometimes that feels like all enemies move together like a flock of geese.Boss Fights: 9.5/10Boss fights are awesome! I mean I enjoyed them a lot! I didn't like the quick time events to finish them off but I really liked the fight.Other thoughts:Memory remixing was probably one of the coolest things in this game! I enjoyed it a lot. others complained that there wern't enough . I felt it was just right.  I in the end didnt want to remix any memories cause it meant screwing with people and the last one you do ,  I really wanted to talk things through, rather than screw somebody over.you can beat this game on skill alone, which is cool.Puzzles were pretty neat too . Creative.Cons:Some times I felt like I wanted to explore as the world is very pretty but this isn't that type of game.I wish they had a bit more epic of music, like it was in the end; Still good though.The last fight I expected it to be awesome (It was ok) like the fight in the prison.. MAN that prison fight was EPIC!!!!!I expected to see enemies with guns and it seems like they out lawed guns or something. Felt weird, to be honest.Over all I would give this an 8/10. It's a good experience and worth ones time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Okay, overall, I had fun with this game. I'm certainly not feeling like I was really cheated out of my money, and I can think of several things that make me recommend this game to the community as a whole... That said, this game still lacks a lot of polish and when you carefully look at the game as you play, it's not hard to see that this game wasn't given the full potential that it coulda been.The story is interesting, and it certainly has me going forward, and there's a lot of material that the game can play with when it comes to the premise that memories can be downloaded and shared just like MP3s today, not to mention be deleted altogether... but it still falls kinda short, like there was supposed to be more that the game could do, but the devs had to cut it short for one reason or another.The gameplay itself is solid, but lacks some polish. There are moments where you're tasked with 'remixing' memories to change the result, and by extension alter the behavior of that particular character, but they are too few and far between. In addition, the control scheme for these events is somewhat finicky, and it gets frustrating when you have to keep rewinding to change things. Moving about in the game is fairly easy, and anyone familiar with games like Uncharted or Assassins Creed would easily latch onto the standard set of movement mechanics without much trouble. The combat is both interesting and a curse. The combo creation system is a great idea in theory, but the game limits you to changing the effects of the buttons rather than altering the combos themselves. (i.e. you will always have a combo 'X-X-X', and you can alter the last two 'x' presses to any combination of 'heal' 'deal extra damage' or 'reduce cooldowns') It's sometimes difficult to get the right combo going, and it is rather hard to pull off a specific combo when you're in a large crowd (the game claims you can dodge and keep the combo happening, but I haven't had it happen often enough to be reliable.) Finally, there are enemies later game that are really best dealt with by using special attacks, but when you use one, there's a cooldown on that ability that's upwards of 2 minutes.... yes you can use the 'reduce cooldown' effects in combos to lower that, but when you're dealing with enemies you can't attack because it would be either countered, you'd take damage for hitting them, or they're just plain invisible.... yeah, it gets tired quick.I enjoy this game, I really like the story that's running through it, and I don't feel cheated out of my money. Anyone looking for a brawler-style game won't really be unhappy with it. However, I really feel sad because this game coulda been SOOO much more as a open-world game. I could see a lot of potential in this setting through that. There's a lot of things that you can read about, but would have been so much better if you could GO and SEE these sights. If it's on sale, go ahead and splurge a little, it'll be fun... But if story-driven games with bugs and less-than-optimal polish bother you, yeah, not really your cup of tea.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												You know, it's a real shame when Metacritic is so far off of the mark with a game like this. I only paid $6 for it, but it was actually an enjoyable game. I think deserving of closer to a 78 than the 65.This is a reivew playing on the hardest difficulty:The combo system works well. It's not overly complicated and gets the job done. I had a little trouble with aiming a device you get later in the game during a fight, but setting yourself up to be positioned better helped without too much fuss. The main character isn't incredibly engaging interesting herself, but the environment she's in, your Navigator, and the story that she's involved in is interesting enough to drive me to keep playing. You also meet some somewhat interesting characters along the way.This is not an open world game. THIS IS OKAY. Not every game benefits from being open world. Not every open world game is inherently good because is "open-world". This game is focused and linear with optional collectibles that are only slightly off of the beaten path. It annoys me to this day that people are disappointed that all these games aren't open world. Open world usually means less focus on the experience and a bunch of non-interesting side quests littered all over the place unless you're a big bugdet title and can afford to make a proper experience even in the nooks and crannies of your world, like Witcher 3, SWTOR, World of Warcraft (?), etc.It was just under a 10 hour game for me getting probably half of the achievements as well. I'll likely pick up the rest of them at a later time.Fun game. Not a 10/10 by any means (but I don't give a 10/10 to hardly anything -- this ain't IGN), but an enjoyable experience for someone that has missed this game on release, and really doesn't have anything else new to play right now.

Posted: April 5, 2015
												I was really surprised by how much I enjoyed this game. Not to say it was perfect, but it was quite, well, fun. Some random thoughts:It wasn't crazy difficult, the platformer gameplay wasn't necessarily original (felt a lot like Tomb Raider), but it was a good balance of action, puzzle solving and story. The memory remix element is pretty interesting and isn't just a gimmick; it is crucial to the story. The environments are gorgeous, but, even with my reasonably good gaming computer, I had some areas with pretty significant frame rate issues... game could use some optimization. There are very few loading screens! They did a great job loading content on the fly.The combat gets a little repetitive but it does in any game like this. Being able to create your own combos is nice. You also choose how to integrate healing and other elements in to your attacks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												(LONG REVIEW, WITHOUT SPOILERS)First things first: you, reading this now, the game deserves a chance, buy it! (but not at full price)I liked Remember Me, actually, i liked it a lot. Primarily because it's a breath of fresh air in this FPS-infested gaming community.Why? because of its plot (not superb, but really good and interesting for a change), and thus, its setting: having Neo-Paris at your back while you're going around is a blast. Backgrounds and environment all-around are incredible, devs did a great job making you feel like you're in the future, that this could actually happen sometime. Grafics are amazing, quite beautiful.A very decent combat system (and fun to an extent), New Game+, and some ingenious game mechanics (manipulating memories have never felt so entertaining), adds to the experience and make this game worth playing, with a little bit of replay value.So, with those strong points, why isn't this game ranked higher? why was it a failure commercially?Well, as it has very positive things, it also has a lot of problems.* 1- Holds your hand all game long, and doesn't let it go:Most notorious issue with the game. Go here, jump here, hit this enemy, activate this button, etcetera, never ending indications. The game makes you follow a predetermined path, without any other possibilites. So, you better follow the non-stop instructions or you'll never go anywhere. Don't try jumping here or there, trying to see if you can go any other path, is pointless.Is super frustrating: there's the intriguing Neo-Paris on your back and you can't explore it!I'm not even asking for an open-world game (which would've been epic, none the less), but at least give us some freedom to explore more! I hate when a game has to guide me through it.Also, please for the love of God, if you despise this too, as I do, never EVER use the "Aug-Eye" feat in the game, as it directly spits on the player's intelligence, telling you how to solve every single situation. Please no.* 2- Super short length:Only 6 hours, total (could be a lot less), if you don't mind about getting all the optional stuff. Really guys?It's a breeze, and it's a shame. Because you feel that it ends when you're starting to get into it. Leaves you with a "that's it?" face at the credits.* 3- Platforming and combat lacks development:When this game came out, people said it was "Tomb Raider in the future". No, just... no.Platforming here, because of point 1, is pointless and so scripted that you'll grow tired of it at some point. Yeah, there are a couple of sections in the game where you've to think a little bit (without Aug-Eye, that is), but doesn't help in this topic.Combat is decent, batman arkham-like, but fixed combo lenghts and button combinations still restrict you to repeat the same patterns over and over again.On a side note, how's that this game doesn't have counters??And the answer is the dodge... because it's an insta-win move. Why? you can dodge EVERYTHING, it's so fast and spammable, that you can keep dodging and never get hurt. You can dodge while doing a combo and if done correctly, the combo won't break and you can finish it. Again, a shame, because it could've been so SO much better. Feels like there's no risk while in combat.* 4- Abused linear storytelling:This isn't really a negative point per se, but this game abuses it too much.There's a great game mechanic called "Memory remix" that its fun, and something new for these kind of games. But, having only 1 valid outcome for them, destroys its potential. Imagine if the devs let us continue the story with other results, setting up your own paths on the story and changing it based on your decisions when remixing. That'd be awesome. But no. At the end, it's just a trial-and-error mechanic.Finally, after 4 big negative points, why should YOU then give this game a chance? why I still recommend it, when it seems like it wanted to mix so much things that it couldn't reach success in any of them because of that, right??Well, my friend, because even if the game has important flaws, it's still very enjoyable, and above all, it's a game TRYING TO DO SOMETHING DIFFERENT. This is not you copy-pasta big-budget game, it's a well thought game that couldn't quite get to where it tried to.There's SO MUCH potential on this, and that's why you should give it a chance.For me, I'd love to see a Remember Me 2. An almost impossible thing to happen due to its sales, but fingers crossed anyway!

Posted: April 7, 2015
												I really enjoyed the story with this game. I did play it on the lowest difficulty though and finished the game incredibly fast. It's not a very long game. If you're in to melee action games it's great. The story was amazing and interesting but the combat got too repetitive for me especially from how there's only two buttons to use when fighting, "x" or "Y" (depending on your controller). They did try to make it interesting with the combo creation and adding chains to either gain health or deal more damage. There are also some cool abilities you can use during combat too, but for me I felt that wasn't really enough. There are cool little memory remixes you can do to manipulate a character's past experiences which I thought was an awesome touch to make the story more enjoyable. I thought making the game world more open than it was could've changed a lot, and potentially adding side missions to explore would've made it more enjoyable for me. But if you play it for what it is and enjoy the story, it could be a good time.Pros:Story richLikable charactersSome cool combat abilitiesNillin is just a total badassCons:RepetitiveShort storyLimited combat options

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												When I play a game I want to like it, and there is plenty to like in Remember me. There are of wonderful elements to appreciate in this game from the amazing soundtrack, to the incredible visuals, to the fun and intriguing cyber punk story, and a unique take on a free flow melee combat system.The game is far from perfect of course. A few mechanics don't quite always work and it seemed like there were a few hit detection issues, sometimes enemies seemed to have an unfair reach, and at times they seemed to have a near precognitive ability to know right where I would dodge so that they were waiting to get another cheap hit in as soon as I landed. Some of the cheap shots and other issues seemed to be alleviated as you found the best rhythm in each fight. Quick combos to regain health then dodge dodge, quick cooldown combo and etc. The combo system, combined with your various special abilities, do give combat a very strategic feel and there is a nice array of enemy types to always test you. Overall it can be very rewarding when you manage to pull out a win against all odds, or bring your health back up from the brink of death, but on the flip side it can be terribly frustrating. Not often but in some of the bigger battles certainly.However, I would still highly recommend this game. I was surprised how much I liked the story and it certainly went certain places and explored certain themes I had not expected. This is a game and setting with so much potential. Sadly, I feel they didn't get to explore the full potential in this game. But then that's all the more reason to support original IPs like this. Its entertaining and it felt incredibly unique, which is often hard to do these days. So pick this one up and give it a try.

Posted: August 3, 2013
												"Remember Me" exemplifies everything I love about video games. The depth of the storyline pulls you in, makes you care about the world and the characters, and leaves you determined to change what has gone awry. I even got a lil emotional at certain points of the game... T.TAnd like, the gameplay... got awesome all over my face.The ability to craft combos was neato, and the fluidity of the fighting mechanics was really enjoyable. The jumping around/traversing heights was a nice touch. Even with the indicators lighting your way, there was still a need to find a safe path inherent. The creators even threw in a few riddles to solve.*GASP* The game actually makes you think? The horror.Which brings me to the memory remixing... super fun! Some of the remixes weren't really easy to determine a progression of events that would shape the desired outcome. This led to a fumbly bit of trial and error that, initially, left a bad taste in my mouth. However, as the game moved on, the memories you resculpted offered a series of choices that began to highlight a specific pattern to uncover.Yes, more thinking. D:Also, the game is realllllly pretty.This game has everything. I will be replaying it veryveryvery soon. <3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
												I took a chance on this game and I'm pretty satisfied that I did.Set in Neo-Paris in 2084, Remember Me drops you into a world where our current social media obsession has evolved into the Sensation Engine (Sensen) - a technology that allows someone to upload and share their personal memories, experiences, and emotions with the always-online world or even go so far as to erase bad memories or live someone else's.The player takes the role of Nillin - an amnesiac who finds herself locked up and about to be lobatamized but escapes with the help of the mysterious Edge. Edge claims he and Nillin are vital members of the resistance fighting to take down the company who created the Sensen and as a result have indirectly achieved incredible power and influence.The gameplay balances 3rd person melee combat with fairly straight forward platforming sections. While the combat is no God of War or Devil May Cry, its simplicity doesn't actually hurt the game and presents a challenge in its own right as the player encounters numerous enemy types with differing strengths and weaknesses - forcing you to adopt different strategies, use different abilities, and create your own combos. Platforming on the other hand is more akin to the Uncharted series rather than the open world type found in Assassin's Creed.Overall the game is quite well polished, it looks fantastic, the voice work and animation is great, and the soundtrack is superb. The only real downsides to the game is that some experienced gamers may find it too easy even on the hardest difficulty as well as the fact that the game might only be six or seven hours in length.The most important thing to know before buying this game is that it's a linear story/character driven experience. If you were a fan of Ninja Theory's Heavenly Sword and Enslaved Odyssey to the West you'll enjoy Remember Me. If not then you're taking your chances with it.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												Personally i think its a good game. Definetly built for a console more then a PC (A lot of fixed cameras). The strory is very interesting and immersive, but for the deeper immersion the developers had to build the game in strictly linear way. The combat system give you 2 playstyles. First, you can abuse dodge, forget most of the combos and you will be untouchable and bored (For those who dont want to experience a combat system in this game). Second, customize your combos and use them (personally i needed only 3 of the 4 combo chains you will be given), thats where the combat will shine and will start to be interesting and challenging. All of the Boss fights are different, interesting and require some tactics. Good looks, fine voice acting, a lot of awesome movies. I had 2 problems with this game. First, some failed scripts forced me to restart the checkpoints couple of times. Second, none re-picks of the taken routes. You took the path and you can forget about the other one. Just cause of horde of checkpoints but only an ability to reload the last one. That means, if you took the path that doesnt contain the collectible or a boost pack you can forget about them until after the end of the game when you will be given choice to reload every Episode you have played (VERY annoying). It took me 12.6 Hrs to defeat the game in the hard mode with 86% of completion. IMHO, i recommend this game for those who like a very good stories,animations and deep immersion into the games. Those who want to experince only new combat systems and want to feel some adrenaline rush will not find it in this game.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												A Great game, but needed just a bit more.This game, made using the Unreal engine, is gorgeous. When you have the time, stop and look around, you'll find exquisite detail, and jaw dropping back drops. Gameplay is... passable. I love the combo system, and I love remixing the combos, but i felt a little restrained, like the game wanted to give me more control, but just couldn't. A few more available combo strings would have been nice. The pressens were varied, and I loved chaining them together and watching new animations.Now the exploration could have been a little more actiony. The mechanics for traversing the vast city was a little robotic, and not very fluid. The same could be said for the combat. though the combat made a little more sense, on the fact that you were able to throw random animation together and in any combination, I would have like to see more fluid traversal, since that was something the devs had control of. Not to mention, if your gonna be a terrorist in a neo-cyberpunk Paris and you end up on roof tops, ya best be parkouring over every little piece of architecture you can find.The music, a lot better than expected, it had a nice ambiance, and didn’t get annoying, and the tempo kept you rolling with the best of them throughout. Some vocal tracks would have been a nice touch.The story. Now this is where this game gets interesting, the character Nillin is an errorist and starts the game with amnesia(how many times has this happened in games now), which provides a vehicle to move along how she learns all of her abilities, and how she also is made into and errand girl for all of the game........ALL OF IT. This character talked about the freedom of choice and was more willing to follow a disembodied voice for forever and a day. Which is funny, because the character talks about how she hates doing that. The basic premise of the story is small band of rebels, and big bad corporation, and the meaning of memory. A classic story trope, and done well, especially in the setting, it’ll be a great play for anyone who picks it up7.5/10

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												The Matrix meets Inception, that is perhaps giving it a little too much credit. Set in a cyberpunk future "Neo-Paris" where memories can be copied, shared or stolen. Remember Me has style for sure however when it comes to one of the most central parts of the game: the combat, it falls short.I wouldn't recommend playing with mouse and keyboard if you have a controller, I played with an xbox controller and even that felt clunky. The combat is frustrating for a number of reasons, there is no Lock-on feature when fighting, the only lock on is for your ranged weapon. Dodging is awkward and a little buggy sometimes you can find yourself stuck in a dogpile of enemies if you do not compensate for that eventualilty. The combos can be really hard to pull off even though they aren't that complex buttonwise, the problem is when fighting multiple enemies one always sneaks in a jab and breaks your combo, you can dodge and resume the combo but the time you're given to do so is very short. The combo editing system had the potential to be really awesome mixing and matching damage, health regen, cooldown reset and multiplier moves however it simply isn't mainly because a jack of all trades combo set isn't good at anything and you are much better off focusing one of the four sets soley to do damage or regen health ect.7/10. Great visuals and story, great sound design and voice acting, poor music however and then of course the flawed combat.

Posted: December 9, 2013
												BEST GAME EVER - 11/10! If you enjoyed Mirror's Edge and the Batman Arkham Series, and you have a knack for gadgets and futuristic landscape art with amazing lighting effects, this game is DEFINITELY a MUST-PLAY adventure. They did such a great job of implementing new mechanics around the storyline. In chapter 3, you're still learning how to do new move types and combos, and gaining new abilities, which can then be used to unlock more puzzles. Plenty of secrets to find throughout the game, and collect. Certainly is an absolutely stunningly beautiful game, with an amazingly compelling storyline, attractive main character, and all the fist fights you can ever hope for. Music is great too, done by the Philharmonic Orchestra. It's such an incredible game, and I believe it's worth the price. Fantastic job with this one DONTNOD Entertainment!

												Simply an amazing game. If you are a fan of Blade Runner, Inception, or the like, you will love this game. The story is simply astounding - and the idea of remixing memories is novel, as is an economy built on the commoditization of them. The plot twist I was expecting (but didn't happen) is that you in fact aren't the main character, just another person who had her memories transplanted in you.The game is satisfying, if linear. The only criticism I would have is that the places where the bonuses are hidden aren't very well indicated many times, and if you make a wrong turn and continue the story, you can't go back.Outside of that, time and money extraordinarily well spent.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Remember MeAt first, I was very wary of this action-adventure game set in a cyberpunk setting. It had mixed reviews and while the game is far from perfection, I can't say Remembe Me is bad. Far from it actually! But sadly, there is a few irritants that unable Remember Me to be outstanding. To make it short, you are Nilin, a memory hunter, in Neo-Paris set in 2084, that somehow, got herself arrested and get's a mindwipe that erases most of your memories. You're liberated from a shady contact, called Edge, who wants you to remember who you really are and also, wants to change  the world as they know it since it is very repressed. The people in this game's world buy/sell memories either good/bad like some simple commodity. There is some addicts who are living in the slums and they've lost mostly if not all their personality.The gameplay is quite similar to the Batman Arkham games except don't expect a "detective mode" when you're roaming the places. The combat is almost a direct copy of Arkham's except you setup your own combos how you want them once you have unlocked sufficient points. It took me a while to figure out how it works but once you do understand it, the gameplay will be much easier! I played the whole game with the Xbox 360 gamepad since the Keyboard and Mouse controls were really atrocious in this game. But the controls, even on the XB360 gamepad, they're very wonky and even laggish... and during combat, you can't have wonky unresponsive controls! The story unfolds at a good pace. Total playtime is fairly decent for a modern game as they usually clock under 10 hours. The platforming moments are pretty easy as they're highlighted properly. Remember Me has a few Quick-Time Events that mostly occurs on bosses and they aren't too intrusive. There's a few puzzles mostly towards the last three episodes and they're fairly easy to resolve!My gripes are mainly on the movements. Secondly would be the annoying patrolling drones that you can't disable, only evade they're detection field.PROS:+Fascinating dark vision of the future.+Truly impressive visuals (graphics, 3D modeling, etc).+Fitting soundtrack on this cyberpunk world.+Remixing memories (manipulating memories) is a cool feature enabling you to craft memories into an individual.+Edward Snowden would love this game... as it explores hot-topic issues like surveillance and social media.+Nilin is a strong protagonist that make's her feelsvery human.CONS:-Cumbersome camera that get's in the way very often.-Ordinary and stiff combat that get's frustrating at times, until you figure out how the combo-setup/system works.-Extremely linear and little exploration. Level design feels constricting. You see the superb Paris on backgrounds yet you never get to explore much.-Not enough Memory Remix and sadly, only to main characters. Would have been greater to do that at others!-Dialogue is mostly all cheesy in this game.-British accents for French citizens? Hmm... something's wrong here!-Little replay value (only if you seek all achievements and collectibles that is!).OVERALL:A fun game that has a few irritants which holds Remember Me from being a very good game. Granted it is DONTNOD Entertainment's first game and clearly, these irritants can easily be fixed in a possible sequel or another similar game. The combat and platforming are the least interesting parts of Remember Me, and they're what you'll be doing most. You don't have much exploration to do as once you reach a certain area, you're locked out. Though Neo-Paris is unforgettable, your journey through it isn't.RECOMMENDATION:Yes, I do recommend this game. If you can ignore its issues, you're surely going to enjoy Remember Me. It's not a perfect action-adventure game but in my opinion, it get's the job done in entertainement!RATING:7.0 / 10
